=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A thematic, original, fun/light/silly racing game with a semi-unique tile-laying component.

The game is played out over 3 rounds, with the goal being to obtain the most money.  At the start of each round, you construct your spaceship out of bits and pieces off the scrap heap (tiles, many of which are hidden), however you have to do this using a "Factory Fun" style mad grab for the tiles, and do it with a time limit as well.  This results in sub-optimal ships being constructed as it's also VERY important to finish building your ship first, so you can start first.

Next comes the first of 3 races.  Each race involves a series of event cards, many of which are complete screwjobs (asteroids, pirates, diseases etc.), with some being good opportunites to score points (acquired goods, defeating pirates, etc.).  Points are also awarded at the end of the race for finishing the race (yes, sometimes you will NOT be able to finish the race!), and for having the best constructed ship (at least the best surviving ship).

Each subsequent race, your ship is larger and therefore a bit more crazy to build, and the race is longer (more event cards).  The winner is the person with the most money at the end of all the races.  The interesting thing is that it is possible to do poorly in the first 2 races and still win the game if you finish strong.  

The game is fairly light and cannot be taken too seriously.  It is more of an experience game, as it is quite fun, very original and thematic, and has excellent components.  Seems to scale well from 2-4 players.  Definitely a game that would benefit from expansions as well, and I think there's one coming out soon.  Chvatil is definitely a designer to watch with this and Through the Ages under his belt.

Own the [boardgame=38378]Big expansion[/boardgame] the [boardgame=97845]Another Big expansion[/boardgame] expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Very cool and fun puzzle-ish game where you have to build your space ship, and then go out and try to make money while not getting blasted to pieces. It has cool little space dude pieces, nice looking cards, and a cool theme. It's great fun going out and exploring deep space, finding planets with goods on them or possibly pirates that will attack you and destroy sections of your ship. You have to try to take home the most valuable cargo while fighting off pirates, slavers, and asteroids, and get back before the other players. I've played a couple other puzzle-type games before, but GT was by far the most entertaining, probably in part due to the theme. Though you know what most of the upcoming cards will be, the game has a nice 'exploration' type feeling to it. Seeing your ship be torn to pieces, but still cruise along through space and barely survive is cool and exciting.

The "Combat zone" cards or whatever they are called probably do a good job of simulating everybody getting caught in some kind of battle (some interstellar war going on or something?) and the weakest player get thrashed, but the "combat zone" cards don't give any context or anything, so I was left thinking, "What is happening here? Are we fighting each other? Are we all being attacked or something?" That card could of been done better.

The only other thing I can think of that would make the game way cooler would be some pasted-on Star Wars theme or something like that. Each player is a smuggler who is building/fitting their transport and trying to pick up illegal goods and make it back to Nar Shadda or wherever the start planet is to sell their stuff. Bounty Hunters, Imperials, Mynocks/space slugs, and local law enforcement try to blow you up. Throw in places like Kessel, Tatooine, etc., give the goods more flavor, like spice, weapons, stuff like that. I always called the brown aliens Wookies anyway; they should be Wookies!

Just a thought.

RATING: 4
Vlaada, why? Why did you ruin such a good idea with a bad game implementation?

The designer is always coming up with intriguing and original game mechanisms, but seems completely obsessed with burying them in complex non-intuitive rules because...EUROGAMERS!

The whole game of Galaxy Trucker should be as fast paced and exciting as the ship building. But it's not. You build a ship--fun--then grind for VPs through a bunch of event cards--holy boring-my-face-off, Batman. Ships rarely even blow up as advertised.

RATING: 9
I enjoy playing this game. It's light, easy enough to for new players, plays relatively quickly, and is just plain fun regardless of what happens. Sometimes, you fear each card, knowing your ship is poorly built... and you come out fine. Sometimes, you get amazingly bad luck and your actually-good ship falls apart. Still, despite the huge luck element, the best players do tend to win. And really, it's fun for everyone regardless: you built three ships, you had three voyages full of potentially-hilarious things happening to your ships, and you made money. Happy to have this one in my collection, still thinking about whether I need any expansions.

RATING: 8
Sehr gutes Spiel, welches sich in 2 Runden gliedern läßt. Eine Speedrunde wo simultan alle Spieler ihr Raumschiff ausstatten so gut es geht. Dabei gilt es aus den gemeinsam zur Verfügung stehenden Plättchen sich die passenden zusammenzusuchen, was nicht einfach ist, da die anderen Spieler sich aus dem gleichen Pool bedienen und somit Gute Teile auch schnell vergriffen sind.
In der 2. Phase fliegen dann alle gebauten Raumschiffe auf der gleichen Route und versuchen möglichst viel Geld dabei zu machen und nach Möglichkeit natürlich nicht kaputt zu gehen. Nach Zieleinlauf gibts dann eine Wertung und dann folgen noch 2 Runden mit dem gleichen Prinzip, wobei die Raumschiffe größer werden und die Gefahren gefährlicher. Sehr lustiges Spiel, aber am besten, wenn man es mit 4 Leuten spielt.

2016-02-08
8->7
Galaxy Trucker is an example of a game that is much more complicated to explain than it is to play. It also comes with an awful amount of bits and pieces that are great looking but also add to the duration of setup and cleanup.

What I like the most about GT is that it genuinely is fun to play. The initial hurry with ship building and the unpredictable events all complement each other. It is so fun that I do not actually mind if my ship gets blown into pieces. One might even say that the game gets boring on the day when you have mastered the building process and manage to get home unhurt time after time. I guess this is why they brought the expansions with rougher events to the market.

Here you have the biggest shortcoming of the game. While offering a challenge at first, it quickly becomes a bit easy and repetitive. You are always executing the same style of blueprints and the events offer you no surprises. At that point, all you have left is the ship building, which is still great fun.

However, I chose to sell my copy of the game since I got somewhat bored with it. I had my eye on the expansions but finally judged that they would make the game even harder to explain and maintain, thus creating a behemoth that requires too much energy to control for it to be fun anymore. This is also the reason, I am degrading the rating from 8 to 7. Galaxy Trucker is great fun for a time but you have to ready to invest into an expansion to keep it fresh. And to get to play that expansion, you need a group of sworn fans of GT so that you are not required to teach the game more than once. 

Personally, I am more than happy to play anytime.

RATING: 9
Bringing my rating from an 8 to a 9 after several plays.  Save one player, everyone I've introduced to this game has loved it, and it's getting a good deal of play.

It's fast and fun, but you -must- be able to laugh at yourself.  Stern gamers who get angry if they look foolish, even during their first play, will not have fun.  You can only learn how to build a good ship by having several of your own blown to bits first.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An agility game, where players will have to build their ship by picking tiles from the middle with a time limit. The ship needs a balance of engine, laser cannon, shield generator, goods storage, battery and crew member while checking for mistake in connections. Player also get to 'recruit' alien as well to boost engine and/or cannon power. After building the ship, each player's ship will go through an adventure. Ships get to land and collect goods, saving abandoned ships and shooting the enemies - to collect points. However, there's also threats from meteor, pirates and slayers constantly trying to destroy the ship and forcing player to 'give up'. Player with highest points wins.

It's fun. Witness the funniest and ugliest ships ever built. Laughed and laughed everytime this game is played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

great game, a bit of luck, great fun!

RATING: 7
Rating after one play of two rounds with two players.  Not sure I'm going to dig the timed element, but it was pretty cool.  Weird pacing, though.  "Where is the game?  Is it the assembly?  The flight?"

Update: Full game under my belt now.  Neat game.  Heart pounding.  Fun in ways that are hard to quantify.  Definitely unique.

I really want to test this out with three other players who will delight in the destruction of the fruits of their labor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very fun!

Downgraded from 9 to 8 (5/01/08).  (And I thought my rating would go up!)

I really enjoy this game, but there's a strong inequality between experienced players and inexperienced ones.  For the ship construction phases, experience *really* pays off.  I've won most of my games (plays 2-5, I think) because I'm good at looking at the cards and building a ship I want to fly.

While the luck elements are certainly present (dice-rolling for asteroids and laser fire, for example), construction skill dramatically offsets them.

My next step probably should be printing out the Rough Road expansion cards and handicapping myself with them when I play new players.  Even if I were to do that, I'm not sure it would raise my rating.  Can't say I think I'm a huge fan of a game that requires its owner to handicap himself in order to play with others.

Downgraded from 8 to 7 (4/08/09).  The expansion, or at least the Rough Road Ahead cards, improves on the basic game so much that I will never play without it.  NEVER.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I played this game just twice, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

Fast, crazy and silly. I enjoy this game because of the frenetic action that offers, its originality and the idea of building a spaceship. Of course it's far from being a strategic game, because it's chaotic over every possible limit, but it's a fun filler and completely unique.

I have a couple of problems with the game, that are not so big at the end of the day: 1) The randomness: I know it's supposed to be part of the fun, but you can really be annihilate by not drawing the tiles you need, by getting the wrong cards or the wrong dice rolls. I know I should enjoy it here - and I partially do, but simply I cannot accept it completely. 2) The Scoring: Again it's a smaller issue, but I keep disliking the scoring sistems of this designer, because they seem a little unrefined to me.

Still Galaxy Trucker is a good game - especially with the right people at the table, which can amplify the laughter that the game already brings.

RATING: 7.2

RATING: 10
Why I think you should play this:

*To me, this is actually the best PIRATE game out there. You customize your ship, smuggle cargo, fight off enemies and war with other players. The pirate aesthetic means different things to different people, but for mine, this game does pirate better than anything else. 

*The real-time aspect is fun, but more importantly it involves rich choices, something I've not seen a lot of in multiplayer, real-time, games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Vlaada Chvatil may well be my favourite designer. What impresses me is his range.

On one end of the scale we have the manic, frantic space ship building shenanigans on offer here - in stark contrast to the very brain intensive Through The Ages it is possible to have a great time here on your very first go.

Once you have built a spaceship from ill-fitting, ill-suited components, it flies across the galaxy (well, a bunch of cards are drawn - use your imagination!) and gets smashed to bits.

Or not.

It depends how well you built your ship.

Unless you were really unlucky.

It also has one of the funniest rulebooks ever, but does require a bit of front loading of rules (the components are varied and wonderful) but it's more than worth it.

A fabulous game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

-> As Russian edition's cards differ from the expansion's ones (and for now there are no news on localizing addons), we got English cards from Czech Games.

RATING: 3
If I owned this game, it would be trade piled. I hate this with a passion. There is probably nothing more I dislike than an egg timer in a game. And there is nothing more I dislike than fighting players real-time in a mad rush for tiles to build a ship before the timer is through. As a new player, I also had a big disadvantage because I didn't know to scramble for key tiles until we got to the third round. Ugh and double ugh.The only redeeming quality of the game is the quite fun event cards that play after your ship has been built, which "battleship" your ship or grant it resources or money.

RATING: 7
The best part about this game is building the ship. That seems to be the part of the game with the most interaction and the 'funnest' part of the game by far. Flying your newly built ship through the dangerous galaxy is a mere plus. I for one enjoy watching my ship get blown to bits. It's definitely a a tongue in cheek game and one that will need the right mindset to be enjoyed to its fullest. If your group is hypercompetitive and enjoys working through clever uses of mechanics and solving a game's efficiency puzzle then Galaxy Trucker might not be for you.

However, if your group enjoys a fun game with great components then pick up this game immediately.

RATING: 7
Great game for a group that isn't more worried about winning than having fun
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I'm always worried when a game comes packaged with an egg timer. Well, Galaxy Trucker is in fact pretty fun at first. The timer does at least make sense—the idea being that it keeps you honest so you definitely make as rickety a ship as possible. The game is an absolute blast...for about 2 minutes. Once you're done frantically assembling your ship from random parts (and many of the shipbuilding rules regarding facedown tiles are unanimously agreed to be stupid), you then...watch a movie for about 20 minutes wherein all the ships get subjected to dice and cards. Fun.

Except not fun. At all. It's just on-rails at that point. I don't mind a rickety piece of space junk dying like a garbage fire, I mind not being able to really do anything. The choices are insipid: do the risky thing or not do the risky thing. Great. Well, if you're ahead you don't take risks and if you're behind you do. Woo. Any knucklehead can play this "game", though it's hard to call it one in good conscience.

It feels like there's a much better game about building ships and sending them out on an adventure that got buried in some insane person's garbage fire of ideas. I would say that's the worst part of it but it's not: the components. Those little spacemen and the ugly ships...just really every piece in this game is ugly or out of place. It reminds me a lot of how Mage Knight felt like a bunch of spare board game parts were dumped in a pile. I wonder if Mage Knight and Galaxy Trucker are connected somehow...?

Give Vlaada's game a pass. Again. It's just a good idea wrapped in a bad game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent game. Some real time tile laying components, and then a turn based decision making/luck phases. Quick, and alot of fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Definitely a puzzle-building game, and I'm not a fan of puzzle building games.
I was disappointed in that it wasn't anywhere near as "fun" as I had been led to believe: in this case, the fun of madly scrambling to produce a "perfect" space ship, and the fun of watching it getting blown apart. I didn't find too much tension in building ships; and I didn't find the "blowing up" part overly engaging. Give me Pan Chvatil's Space Alert for that!
I mean, it's a perfectly fine game; but, for me, it wasn't at all the madcap romp and race that I had been led to believe it was. 
Then there are the rules. The rules are just too complicated for a game that is so light. I'd have no problem with the rulebook if the game were heavier.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
Pretty cool build and destroy game.  You first build your ship in a "mad grab" for the best components, then everyone sets sail with their space ships to see who survives the destruction.  The destruction (mostly) comes at all ships with the same type and same location of problems, so the best designed ship will usually win; however, if you have one weak spot, it may get hit during an unlucky roll, making your great design fall to pieces.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The iPad version is a lot of fun, but I'm not sure how much set up/clean up is involved in the tabletop version.  It's cool to build a crazy looking ship and see what it can do.  You can play against each other for score, but you can also enjoy building a ship that is aesthetically pleasing to you and testing it out.  I'm astounded that a game like this was designed by the guy who did Codenames and Through the Ages.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Galaxy Trucker is quite a bit less strategic than I initially expected. There is a lot of chaos in the tactical decisions you must make, and I'm not entirely certain if the game is balanced very well at all. Despite that, I still find it to be a fun game for what it is. There is a certain charm in being forced to quickly cobble together a good ship that will stay intact for your journey through space. 

But every time I've played it there have been players that are dramatically better/worse at riding the chaos to the point where the competition just isn't very fun for them. I suppose that's the nature of a real-time chaos driven game, but it does hold GT back for me. I personally enjoy it, but the disparity in skill level can make some sessions dramatically more fun and other sessions dramatically less fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The first half of each round is a speed puzzle in which you assemble your ship.  In the second half, cards are flipped and your ship is nibbled away by various hazards.  There are a few decisions in the second half but they're all bleeding obvious.  You do this three times, building progressively bigger ships to face more powerful hazards.  

Such player interaction as exists lies solely in robbing an opponent of the tile or goods they want.  The two times I've played, Galaxy Trucker has taken way over the published 60 minutes. One for the jigsaw puzzlers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Although this is a family favourite an argument will usually break out at some point - normally whenever the timer gets flipped. Good for my kids from 8+ as long as you give them time to build.

Random enough to give everyone a chance, but not entirely at the mercy of the dice / cards, it's a good balance for a lightish family game.

RATING: 7
A LOT of fun.

Building the ships is chaotic, and you're usually pressed for time, and some of the ships you end up with are just ATROCIOUS to look at.  But they're nice and random and interesting.  It's a lot of fun, just building them.

Going through the delivery... well.. it's usually disastrous.  You will most certainly not make it unscathed, but it is STILL fun.  Can you handle all the challenges, from Pirates to Slavers, to asteroids?  Only if your chaotically built hunk of parts happened to be prepared for it!

Highly recommended for a fun game to pass an hour or two =).

Recently dropped my rating down some.  The game is still a lot of fun, but in truth, after the 'ship building' stage, what do you really do?  You just watch to see if your ship makes it.  It's still fun to watch, but there's not a lot of actual gaming going on.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
If you enjoy puzzles, humor, and can enliven your game with crazy stories, then this game provides a nice palette for you to paint from.  From the absurd construction of your ship to the often ridiculous odds of flying through space with reckless abandon - you will have opportunity for humor and good times.  So why doesn't the game rate higher?  Game play can end up feeling like you had all but one engine pod blown off and your drifting through hoping to get to the end.  Its suppose to be a haphazard, seat of your pants experience.  If you are building perfect ships you are missing the point.  If you are handling the obstacles with anything close to tedious attention, you've gone 'Major Tom'.  Play it like the rules are written - with tongue firmly in cheek.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Rating is a 9 for kids, and 8 for adults.  May not be the deepest game in the galaxy, but it's fun to build ships and then watch them fall apart.  I find this game to be screaming fun all over.  During the race portion you should try to be first or second.  More methodical players do not care for this one because the first portion is a race to build a spaceship as fast as you can

If you liked Factory Fun, you'll like this.

Try to avoid the 1st ed. unless it's been upgraded.  The pieces aren't compatible with the expansions, and the spaceships are very sharp.

RATING: 6
Rated after two plays.  I wanted this because I find another game by Vlaada, Space Alert, to be utterly fantastic.  Galaxy Trucker, though, definitely isn't in the same league.  The building phase is sort of fun, and I love the puzzle aspect with all the connectors.  The problem is that the sand timer just isn't implemented well; why is it even in the game?  The cd tracks in Space Alert made sense because your ship is about to explode!

It's also enjoyable to see your ship torn apart, but I can see that getting old after a few more plays.  Still, it's an extremely original game and one that I wouldn't mind playing every now and then.

RATING: 9
This one is a hoot. On paper, it really should not work - you have the "ship-building" part of the game, which feels like space Carcasssonne on ecstasy, and the lengthier "flight" part which is basically playing itself. And yet it works great. Everything is so charming and breezy, from the rulebook, to the components and gameplay. It's hard to play this game without a constant grin on your face.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

A big yet very silly game. Taking the role of interstellar mechanics/pilots, players over the course of three rounds randomly pull tiles from the board to build spaceships, trying to build the best ship in the shortest amount of time. Then they go through a series of events, sometimes positive (like find a station and loot the place, or a bunch of planets were you get goods from), but mostly negative (like pirates and asteroids that take plunder and destroy your ship).

As I said, it's silly. The rules were great at both teaching the game and providing nice little quotes for everybody to laugh at. While you send lots of time staring at your own player board, the theme and the game structure creates jovial atmosphere. I find interesting one how vague the win conditions are (IIRC, if you have any credits left, a winner is you, and if you have the most credit, more of a winner is you).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Excelente juego. Muy sencillo de explicar. con muy buenas mecanicas y que deja momentos de buenas risas. creo que es demasiado caro para los momentos que da y aun así necesario de tener. El objetivo es fabricar una nave y llegar el primero al destino llevando de todo un poco. Al final el juego se reduce a la diversion de montar la nave y de ver como se va quedando en nada... lo de menos el viaje y la puntuación. Así que como juego logra divertir una buena parte del tiempo. Pero la sensación que deja al final no es la del Caylus ni lo pretende. Es para lo que es: excelentes momentos con mis cuñadas... Creo que va a ser el siguiente que saque en mesa para mis amigos después de una cena. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've had a blasts playing this one.  Going on about seven plays thus far.  Even my seven year old had fun and grasped the building rules quickly.  I do see this game getting played out in the future, but do not forsee it happening in the next 20 or so plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow.  So far this has been fantastic fun!

The game is basically split into 2 phases for each of it's 3 turns.  The first phase is where most of the real decision making comes into play as players race to construct a star-ship that is fast and sturdy with plenty of space for crew and cargo, and with enough laser cannons to deal with hostiles.

this is all done in real time as players grab the components they need from a big pile of face down tiles.  tiles with components you want are installed on your ship (Carcassonne style, where the sides of the pieces generally have to match up) tiles you dont care for are placed back in the pile face UP and available to everyone to pick up.

There are incentives to finish first and penalties for recklessly built space craft which creates a nice tension between being careful and fast.

The second phase is the voyage where a random event card is dealt and the players see if their starships are up to whatever challenges the galaxy can throw at them.  Players will be bombarded by meteor showers, assaulted by pirates, race through empty space, and snatch up juicy cargo for bonus bucks.

It's great fun.

There's a lot that can go wrong in a voyage and well built ships can still be foiled by bad luck.  Still...the best ship will usually score the most points.  It's not a brain-burner on the level of Tigris and Euphrates, but there are some interesting decisions to be made and a lot of fun to be had a long the way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Και δεν έφταναν όλα αυτά, προστέθηκαν και εξτρά κάρτες με καταστροφές και άλλα "αστειάκια", έτσι για να μας σπάσουν ακόμα περισσότερο τα νεύρα. 
Τρελή διασκέδαση!!!

RATING: N/A
07.02.03.03
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
OMG! This is FUNNY!!! Sometimes you feel like you're watching the game rather than playing, but this can be hilarious!!
The purpose of gaming is having fun, isn't it?

Galaxy Trucker is another Vlaadaesque brilliant piece of design, about space delivery of space sewers using spaceships made with the aforementioned space sewers.

The game lasts three rounds, each one consisting of a frantic building phase and a flight phase.

The building phase is the core of the game: it is a crazy race to find the right tiles to build a viable ship, with the players working at the same time at their space vessels, drawing tiles from a common pool. When the first player completes the ship, everyone else has on last sand timer to do the same, then the flight begins.

The flight phase is about watching the ships trying to pass a various array of hazards without falling apart, and also trying to be the first reaching the final destination.
This phase has rarely any meaningful decision, but since the ships rarely manage to avoid the "falling apart" part, it is often a hilarious process of watching (hopefully) the others' being torn by asteroids. Or blasted by lascannons. Or the crews abducted by slavers. Or...

Galaxy Trucker is not a game for everyone, and not a game I'd play every day. But with the right people, in the right mood, is a BLAST!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This game is different than every other game in my collection.  There is a controlled chaos to the game that makes it a joy to play.  It is a challenge to develop a strategy for building your ship while operating under duress: racing for the best pieces and racing against the timer.  It is interesting when another player builds a small efficient ship rather than a large ship and flips the timer to squeeze all of the other players.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my all-time favourites. The goofy theme, the demanding skill requirements, the hilarity as everything falls apart, the game is a lot of fun all the way through. However, I would not necessarily recommend it to everyone. This is a game that can be heavily influenced by luck, which can make you feel like all your hard-won strategies and planning were all for naught. Personally, I find this game fun no matter who gets hit with all the bad stuff; as long as somebody's plans are a mess, the game is full of laughs, since I am happy to laugh at myself. Second, this game has a very heavy skill component; you need to practice building your ship a few times before you get particularly good. This makes it a lousy game for beginners, or people who need a constant success ratio, or people who don't want to suffer through a learning curve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The plastic crew members are pretty adorable and building your ship is fun, but it's nothing more than an experience game.

RATING: 7.5
Galaxy Trucker uses a unique tile placement race mechanic that allows players to each build their own unique space ship.  Players then test their space ship against a random mix of cards.

I haven't decided whether skill or luck will win the day in this game.

Galaxy Trucker is frantic and wild ride.

RATING: 7.3

I have also have some very mediocure games when playing with individuals who get irritated when one person attempts to speed up building ships to other players disadvantage.  My enjoyment with this game really depends upon the group.  For this reason, it is not played quite as often as I would like, but I would have not to have it aroudn when the right group sits down for a game night.

RATING: 9.5
Really like this game. A lot of fun, really unique and goofy. Each player attempts to building a working space ship from tiles that are spread out in the middle of the table. Each player is racing to complete there ship first, after which all of the ships are sent on an intergalactic shipping route where all sorts of bad things happen. Very fun game that is very goofy. Your ship will blow up and you will die, but it is so fun and goofy that it is in no way frustrating.

RATING: 8.5
This really seems to be a love it or hate it game. I certainly love it. The tension and the challenge during the building phase is brilliant. First players tend to forgo the look at the cards but to me this seems key to building a good ship. During the flying phase the game is just pure fun as you're watching the beginner ships disintegrating all around you. Needs some additional challenge when you get to know the game. This is provided by the big expansion.

Components: :star::star::star::star::nostar:

RATING: 6
For a somewhat complex game, this is a lot of comedic fun. That's a rare feat. I really enjoy the building of the ship, only to see if it can successfully withstand all that the forces of chaos can hurl at it.

Components - strategy of engines (race points) vs cannons (enemies points) vs cargo (goods points) vs flexibility of batteries/shields/green cans&engs vs crew

quality smooth ship building - exposed connectors invite damage and no opportunity for gain

Cards -

RATING: 6
A strange mish-mash of game styles.  The first part of each round is very involving as players are focused on assembling a really good quality ship.  The second part of each round is very light and silly as players watch their carefully crafted ships get blown to smithereens by random dice rolling.  I'm just not that fond of the blending of these 2 unique styles.  I'd be willing to play again, but I won't actively seek out a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun but difficult at first go.  I would suggest playing just 1 and 2 ships for a first game.  There is a lot to keep track of, a lot to learn very quickly.  Drawing the tiles can be hectic, especially with more players.

This is a game where you are playing against the game as much/more than against the other players - something I like and would like to see more of.

Brutal - but it can be a real pleasure to watch *someone else's* ship be destroyed.

RATING: 8
Such an amazingly unique design, like most things Vlaada. It's just really fun. Playing the iPhone app made me truly fall in love with the game. It takes quite a bit of play to truly enjoy the game I think, although newbies can still find it fun. But it definitely rewards familiarity and experience. The theme is completely original and hilarious. There is not a ton of interaction among players, but opponents are certainly a factor when considering how to best prepare one's ship for the race half of each round and whether to land on a planet or keep first dibs on upcoming cards, whether to use energy on double guns and engines, etc. There is some luck, but skill will win the day.

RATING: 8.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Galaxy Trucker 7>6
Had the author dared just a little more, Galaxy Trucker would have been a great game rather than the moderately fun hybrid it is: it looks like he tried and threw a stone, then had second thoughts and hid his hand before others could spot him.

What I mean is, there’s lovely chaos all over the board when players scavenge the pieces they need to build their ships but, as the worst euro fashion requires, as soon as you’ve put down a piece on your board you may no longer move it. This is so frustrating that it both prevents any fun and makes the journey through space shine, even though there’s no way to directly mess with the other players.

But it’s one of the few science-fiction themed games my eurogaming friends are likely to play, so I have to make it do. [i](November 2012)[/i]

[b]Update[/b] - No doubt I’ve overrated Galaxy Trucker: thus I took advantage of my Fall 2015 rating revise to adjust my rating slightly according to the comment above, lowering an excessive 7 to a better fitting 6 until I’ll have the chance to play and rate this game again.

RATING: 7.5
This game was really fun. And I say that after having had no idea what the heck I was doing in my first game (not much of the game was explained to me). There's a huge learning curve, but even though I got killed (in the third round), it was still really fun. I can see one of my groups really liking this game as a longer filler. It's not worth it if you're only going to play infrequently, though; you really need to know what kinds of obstacles you're going to run into. It's not as much fun when you're just sitting there watching everyone else play.

RATING: 8
Decent puzzle game.  Fun to build a ship and hope she holds together in space.  Not sure if it has legs to play on a regular basis.  But perhaps the speed pressure can add to that as the better you get the faster you go.  We were fairly leisurely in our building.  But it's easy enough to get people to jump right in.  

Jan 2017 - finally played it a second time.  Not sure why I dropped to a 5, but I pushed it up to an 8 (overreaction perhaps)?  I really enjoyed the game and it was super fun to fly your ship and hope it holds together.  Yah, it's an 8 now, I want to play again, soon, with max players.

RATING: 8.5
Vlaada Chvatil at his most crazy--which is a) very crazy, and b) a great, great thing. The basic concept, the humor in the rulebook, the graphic design would all make this game a winner even if the game itself were just ok, but the game is both unlike anything else out there on the market, and surprisingly engaging given that, after ship construction, you're just flipping cards over and resolving effects. Toss in the coolness factor of building your own ship, and this is a game which is surprisingly easy to introduce to new players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Clever game of racing the clock to build the most efficient ship for salvaging and mining missions in space. Slight drawback to the game is that that players replaying the same set may learn the imperfections on the backs of the chits (paper tear, nicks, etc.) and have an unfair advantage over inexperienced players or those new to the set. However, there is a neat "story-telling" narrative that this game has that most euros don't: you can tell other players "what happened" when the game is over. There is point of diminishing returns on replayability as there is a bit of repetition of events on journeys--the later ones simply take longer to finish. A friend commented that the system could be used as a vehicle for role-playing or licensed for sci-fi franchises
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Good but not great game in the real-time genre.  I like it in small doses.  For me the game runs a bit on the long side for the amount of fun that I get out of it.  Also, as twisted as it sounds, I would prefer to use the "Enterprise" (IIIA) ship in every game because it's fun and challenging.  The game plays differently with 3 versus 4 players because there is often a scarcity of useful pieces in the 4 player game.

Personal goal:  I need to focus less on perfection and more on speed in the 3rd round.  A crappy ship in the final round can drop you from 1st place to last quite easily.

Others say:  some skill & good amount of randomness/luck, build a ship then use/abuse it for profit, a heavier beer & pretzels game.

RATING: 9
Okay, this one has been a hit with the family. I really enjoy putting the spaceship together and watching it get beat up in the event cards, although the times you lose because you run out of crew is kind of annoying and seemed far more common. Played with two and four - I've seen comments elsewhere that it's not as good with two, but we've really enjoyed it. Four player is fun though, as it really puts a crimp in how many tiles you get to build your ship with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Chaotic fun in about an hour.  Build your ship then brave the galaxy in a race fraught with peril!  Seems the most fun when your ship is getting pounded to scrap and being the victim of unlikely events.  Quite light overall and not a game for people that will take the battering of their ship personally.

More plays in I still enjoy this game quite a lot.  We're getting better at building the ships, so they're taking less damage during the flights, and that tends to leech some of the joy out of this game.  It does not happen all of the time, and we still have people end up flying a small scrap of what they started with from time to time.  I'll pick up the Big Expansion soon, for the nastier event cards, 5th player and new ship components.

A very unique game.  Combines the pressures of timed problem solving with limited information and spatial relations, with some random destruction tacked onto the end.  I've seen any one of those attributes throw people off of this game, but for me they all work as great positives!

I also love the art direction on this game.  The combination of cutesy art plus the lighthearted manual grant a unique atmosphere.

RATING: 8.3
Really fun game that invovles throwing together a hastily built starship and then running a mission through space.

On your trip you can face various sorts of events that allow you to gather things-face aliens-run into meteor fields etc.

Dependings on how you built your ship you will see it fall to pieces right in front of you.

This is a game that makes me laugh regardless.

The only mechanic I am trying to wrap my head around is the tile choosing mechanic in your "shipbuild."

I wish that some tiels had dual useage vs simply one as I think it would tighten up the planning phase when doing your build.  Say that some engines could also be guns or maybe one or the other.

What this would create is a part of a ship that could be more quickly assembled knowing that a player might be able to use it to bridge to other pieces more successfuly.

This would be a great idea for an expansion possibly.  Just throwing in about 10-18 more tiles with more dimension.

RATING: 8
Otro gran juego del Vlaada Chatil de Dungeon Lords, TtA y otras tantas glorias. El juego consta de tres rondas cada una de ellas con dos fases. La primera es muy divertida y consiste en ir construyendo una nave espacial con losetas (cada loseta otorga ciertas características a la nave) y la segunda consiste en utilizar esa nave que has creado en una carrera espacial, haciendo frente a los eventos que vayan sucediendo. Las rondas van creciendo en complejidad, tanto por el tamaño de la nave, como los eventos que te van ocurriendo. La tercera ronda es una locura. 

Juego muy divertido y totalmente recomendable.

Still somewhat unsure about some of the 'how to use the timer when building' mechanics.

RATING: 9
Love this game. I like everything from the frenetic tile-flipping and puzzle-like aspect of ship building, to strategy of putting together a competent hauler (going for speed? weapons? alien passengers? a little of all?), to deciding how to use the limited energy and abilities of your ship once actually in-flight.

We played this as a focus game at EBGL and I haven't written this review until almost a year removed, but I find myself thinking of this game on a semi-regular basis. One or two more plays to cement that it is as good as I remember, and I may bump this to a 9.

Update 11/09/2015: the more I play this game, the more I find additional strategies in the Adventure phase. Bumping to a 9.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My take on this game - it is a blast. It offers a challenge with the timer, which (mercifully) limits the building phase. Got to know what you are doing or your ship will be not be as effective as you might need it for the various trials encountered for the pick up and delivery of the goods. Some players are put off by the timer, but it makes sense to keep ships from being 'perfect' and discourages slow-pokes from dragging the game. The game plays best with three players, since there are more parts avaiable from the warehouse. This balances out the rushed time limit allowed for building. With four players, certain parts become taken too quickly, resulting in weaker ship constructions and thus fewer players making it to the end of the run with cargo. However, with some players, part of the fun is watching ships disintegrate, so it depends on the crowd.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If I was fifteen, I would probably enjoy this game a whole lot more. Having said that, I really enjoy this game now. The building component is frenetic, and the traveling through space watching your ship deteriorate is just silly fun. Take the humorous rulebook to heart and just enjoy the game for the fun and not so much for the strategy.

RATING: N/A
A classic. Construct your ships out of random parts and prepare for a space adventure. Either riches or failure awaits you in the space lanes as your try to pilot your hastily bolted together ships to their destination avoiding pirates, plagues, asteroid storms on the way and picking up whatever trade goods you can find. I'm not very good at this game, I always struggle to make all the parts I pick at the start line up correctly. Even so it's fun to watch my shoddy ship either fall apart or escape through more luck than skill and limp over the finish line.

RATING: 8.5
Promos:
- Galaxy Trucker: Another Big Expansion Bonus

Expansions:
- Galaxy Trucker: Another Big Expansion

This game has been on my radar for a long time. Several months ago my FLGS finally got a few copies in and I was able to snag one of them. Unfortunatly the game has sat on a shelf since then...

On 5/14/2013 I actually got around to playing it with my Tuesday night group. The short of it is that the game was a huge hit and will be a regular in the rotation for awhile. We actually played two games of this. The first time we only played one round and used the bigginer rules in the rulebook. I highly recommend reading the rulebook out loud to the group, it's pretty funny. The second time we played, we played a full game.

RATING: 8
Going into the game with the expectation that nothing will work and you're going to lose horribly is the best way to have fun with Galaxy Trucker. If you're the kind of person that needs to have everything planned out methodically and gets frustrated when well-laid plans go bad, then it's probably not the game for you. 

That said, I've been enjoying the hell out of this game. Brilliant, silly fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very fun, wacky game. All of the ship tiles give really interesting powers and combinations, and the expansions are an absolute must have. You have to go into the game with a sense of humor, though, because you will get screwed repeatedly and probably won't be able to do anything about it. Eurogamers beware.

My only complaint is that to do well you have to spend some time carefully putting together your ship, which actually gets a little boring if everyone else is also going slowly. If you want to make the game more fun, fast, and hilarious, you can try to build your ship quickly, but the results will be disastrous during the race. The end result is either a boring first half, or a miserable and disappointing second half.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of those games which is simply fun - no doubt experience will help with completing the first stage shipbuiding task under the time pressure but for the second stage you pretty much just have to sit back and laugh as your puny spaceships are smashed to bits by irresistable galactic forces.  Great fun - the comparisons to factory fun and space dealer comes from the need to build your spaceship from the common stock of components - you turn over a tile then either play it on your board or put it in the common area where anyone can take it - and the fact that the first person finished not only gets a bonus but turns over a timer which puts a limit on how long the others have to finish.  Then the real fun part is heading off into space to see how well built your ship is - i.e. how well it stands up to meteor storms and space pirates etc. - that is when large chunks start to float off - to hoots of laughter from your opponents - there are other ways to score on the voyage but the main score comes at the end for finishing positions, any cargo you've picked up and a bonus for the best built ship - or rather best remaining bit of the ships that started - then pay for your repairs and head off on voyages 2 & 3 - on increasingly bigger ships.  Very different games but slightly reminiscent of Railway Rivals in that the first part of the game is spent building your railway/spaceship and the second is spent testing how well it stands up to the demands of space travel.  And in both games the dice can occassionally be cruel to you no matter how well you built in stage one - to the delight of your opponents.

RATING: 7.5
Galaxy Trucker is a good party game: despite other similar games (Munchkin for the aesthetics, Carcassonne for tile management), it offers an optical gameplay where is possible to apply a strategy. Spaceship building is maybe the more fun part of the game, while exploration is actually a necessity to assign points ti the players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Had a lot of fun with this one. Build your ship up, Factory Fun style, then watch as it gets blown to pieces trying to get to the outer rim. Although the two games aren't remincient at all, it reminds me of Duel in the Dark: both are two-phase games (planning then execution), and both have just enough game in both parts to be fun but not to go overboard. The building of your "truck" is where most of the fun is, as you get an inkling of the upcoming hazards and make choices about how to outfit your ship. The actual run then is mostly decision-free, but there is *just* enough there to keep the players engaged, it moves quickly enough to be fun, and it succeeds at being very thematic and entertaining.

The one possible problem I noticed was that going first can be a big deal. Getting the first crack at beneficial encounters can make a huge difference, or can allow you to fairly cheaply hose the other players. So the game might reward speed a little bit more than you might like. But I'm not sure yet. If it is an issue, it's an issue for replayability; out of the box, the game is great fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A very cool puzzle-race with a really well implemented theme and the most hilarious rulebook I've ever read (though I haven't read the Space Alert or Dungeon Lords rules yet).

RATING: 5
This is a very enjoyable group game (and one my wife just loves).  I'd really like to see how this plays with others and how it holds up over repeat plays.  Our group seemed to have decided that being first to finish was less important than having a complete ship, which I think undermined the chaos of the building stage a touch.  Given that quite a few of our missions ended with people being forced to give up, maybe we needed still more time.  The mission cards didn't seem to add a lot (that is, most of the fun was in the building), and the decisions of whether to stop at this or that planet were usually obvious.  

I think this game fills an important place in a gamer's collection.  It's not exactly a "filler", but its a wonderful change-of-pace game to wedge between say, the brain-burn of Agricola and the competitive nastiness of Brass.  It's almost like a party game that's actually...you know...a game.

RATING: 7
Another really unique game from Vlaada. Players build a spaceship in real-time before flying it in space and trying to survive. I really like the variability the game has through the building phase and the shuffled card deck creating the obstacles for each round. Be warned though, the game is very random which may turn off some gamers and it could be a bit heartbreaking to see your ship crumble to pieces after spending so much time building it. Definitely a good game, but not the type that I'd want to play every day.

RATING: 9
This game absolutely oozes theme. The real-time scramble for building your spaceship gives everyone lots to do and is simply plain fun at the table. 

Sure, more experienced players have a significant edge here, but since the whole activity is so entertaining, I think one's enjoyment of the game is far less dependent on one's own fortunes than with most other games. In that it feels very much like a party game. It's that sorta lively atmosphere at the table.

For a jaded eurogamer like me it's a bliss to discover something so fresh, fun and original. It's a blast and a design I very much admire.

RATING: 8.25
With The Big Expansion and Another Big Expansion

This game is so phenomenal. I first got introduced to it on the app, and loved it. So I ordered the cardboard version. I expected it to be rowdy and crazy while grabbing tiles from the central pile at the same time, and sort of tense during the journey. I turned out to be completely wrong. RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
You really have to be down to play a game where all of your best-laid plans can blow up - literally - to enjoy this.

This is a game in which you try to account for every possible outcome (which you likely cannot do, because you're under time pressure and competing with everyone else for parts), and then see how well you did. If that does not sound fun to you then there is no way you will enjoy this game. If you can just let go and enjoy the experience, though... if you can just laugh hysterically at the fact that you just plain forgot to put in enough power stations to power your lasers because you were so focused on getting the damn lasers in the first place and then laugh EVEN MORE when your ship gets obliterated by an asteroid, then this is a whole barrel of chaotic fun.

I suppose the best thing I can say about this game is it captures how fun "frantic" can be. How racing against your friends in real time and constantly worrying that they're going to get all the best ship parts, or that you'll forget something, or a GIGANTIC ASTEROID IS GOING TO OBLITERATE YOU is actually fun. Honestly, I think I only enjoy this game more over time as the meta game of trying to build The Ultimate Ship every time I play and thinking about how I fared last time vs. this time becomes my main concern.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
[u]May 2009:[/u] An odd game in my collection. I took a long time before taking the plunge, hating all things related to randmness and dice. However, the game did seem fun and I thought it might not bother me in this game. I was right. I only played it with my girlfriend as of yet (2p then) and it was a great deal of fun. And it is true that even watching its own ship getting destroyed is really fun, even for very competitive player such as Laurène and I (playing games is the only moment when we argue!).
Moreover, the game is beautiful with the green translucid beads for batteries, little tic-tac looking astronauts. The design of the tiles are very nice too. The cards seem a bit flimsy but nothing really problematic. A beautiful and very fun game though.

I'd have 2 minor complaints though.
First, I regret that you start from scracth from on round to another. I can understand that this is a design choice to prevent the game from being over at the first round. You can always make up in the next ones, since what you did in the first one doesn't matter anymore. However, it feels a little bit as if you're playing 3 different little games in a row. Not a big problem of course.
Secondly, once the ships are built and the adventure begins, there aren't a lot of decision making and it feels a bit anti-climatic.

All in all though, this is a great game that I'd recommend to anyone wanting a fun game with a little bit of strategy (the strategy relies on how you'll build your ship, how much firepower, how many astronauts, how many containers and of what type... You don't have the place to do everything perfect so you have to make some choices) and I'm excited to get the expansion! Specially since it apparently solves my second minor issue.

[u]December 09:[/u] See my review [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/477834/great-game-for-almost-brainless-fun]here[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game is awesome! My wife loves it too, though it’s not a very good game with just 2 players – but it’s great with 3 and 4 players as they add a lot of tension and pressure to finish first (as, in this game, if you have built a decent ship, being first or second is absolutely crucial if you want to win). Everybody knows that, so it’s a race to finish ahead of the others, but when you’re building so fast, the chances are that you will miss something and make some errors which will later on most likely be devastating for your ship – great fun! That’s also why you shouldn’t take this game too seriously; it’s not all about winning but only about having fun (yes yes, I know, that’s how every game is like, but I feel Galaxy Trucker has a very different vibe than, say, most eurogames; these cannot be said to be “funny”, but rather very thinky, and the best player often win in these).

You can remove pieces when playing with 2 and 3 players, but I don’t fancy that as you might remove a lot of the same type of pieces. Still, it’s the best possible solution, but I think I would always prefer to play GT with 4 or maybe 3.

I don’t know how, but I’ve won every game of GT I’ve played; that’s because I often build a pretty good ship and often finish first or second; in case I don’t it’s because other players have rushed and built some ships that are bound to be crushed later on! I often take a peek at the 3 deck of cards as they help you shape your building strategy for your ship; this helps mitigating the randomness of the events, but I think it’s great that you add some cards every round that you cannot look at – in order to ensure that there is some randomness which can ruin your carefully laid out plans! It’s always a great deal of fun when your own or another player’s ship loses half of its side due to a meteor… After I played GT I knew that I had to own it, so I got the Anniversary Edition – I can’t wait to try the expansions! I’ve actually already included the Even-Steven cards as I want to handicap myself; as I said, this game is all about having fun and not about winning, so I feel like it’s more fair if I’m handicapped in each game (and it really does mitigate the advantage of more experienced players).

All in all Galaxy Trucker is a great game, and I must say that I admire the ability of designer Chvatil to constantly make games that feel so different (not that I love all of his designs; GT is definitely his best in my opinion). One minor complaint I have about GT is the timer; it’s too slow, and I’ve considered playing with a stop watch and set it to e.g. 2 minutes – THAT would make the game stressful and tense! The fact that I’ve played GT 6 times during the first month really says a lot as I often play a new game only once or maybe twice during that first month.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm not familiar with all of Vlaada's work, but between Galaxy Trucker and Space Alert, I admire a game designer that can imagine such unique games. Galaxy Trucker is an odd game, with simultaneous tile grabbing and laying to build up your ship, followed by a destructive phase where that precious ship you built gets pummeled by meteors, space pirates, and all other sorts of nastiness. 

Galaxy Trucker is just a bit too complicated for family gaming, yet the die rolling and chaos/destruction is too random for "serious" gamers. For me, though, the game is just flat-out fun. There's enough planning and decision making to keep it interesting, and the build/destroy dynamic generates plenty of laughs with the right crowd. It's a party game for gamers!

If one of my goals is to fill my collection with unique games (which I think it is), then Galaxy Trucker will always have a place in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

You build your ship at speed against your friends, and then fly it through a number of challenges to see what bits fall off.  Superb fun if everyone is up for the challenge and like pulling teeth if they aren't.  Play with 3 or 4 on the base game and enjoy!

[b]Still Play Regularly? - [/b]An occasional treat.

RATING: 9
Wish I had given this gem of a game a chance sooner - but the iOS port showed me how much fun it was, followed by a price cut for the game, making it a no-brainer decision to pick up a physical copy.

RATING: N/A
SU&SD
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is primarily an experience game rather than any sort of deep strategy game.  Most of the game consists of building a well constructed ship, which somewhat relies on the luck of which tiles you flip.  Certainly, there are some clever decisions you can make, but they can be torn apart by bad luck.  Given that, I prefer to play the "shorter" game with round 2 and round 3 ships, foregoing round 1.  I realize that does increase the luck a little bit more, as there is less time to recover - but I think this game wants to be shorter than it is.

After all of that, this is a fun game to play.  Watching everyone's ship get blown apart is pretty funny... and building ships is just plain fun.  I could see this game wearing out its welcome, but I think it's worth the price of entry.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

RATING: 10
2008 Christmas gift from Seth and Nikki! Simply a unique and fantastic game. The real-time ship building is such a rush. I am not a fan of putting together puzzles, but I could put together ship components to make spaceships all day long. It is chaotic, but you have more control than you think. 

The resolution round is fun too. Getting to watch how each ship handles the journey can be very amusing. Everyone I have played with has had a great time no matter what the outcome. I have never played a game that gets everyone laughing and smiling so much. The game is best with more players.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What a ridiculous thing this is. You build a spaceship, you send it across the galaxy, and nine times out of ten it blows up. I don't know why, but even though I develop tiny personal attachments to the ships I build, I'm never that upset when they fall to pieces. It's always just too funny to get mad over.

But the clever thing about this game is that it's not just the random nonsense it initially seems to be. You can get better at it. You start to prioritize specific pieces when building your ship. You realize that being in first isn't always the best thing to do. You develop different strategies for making money. Do you want to build a gargantuan ship that can hold a lot of cargo, at the risk of being more exposed to the elements? Do you want to build a svelte ship with a focus on weapons and engines and simply destroy everything you come across? Something in-between?

I think more variety in tiles will eventually be welcome, so I'll probably pick up one of the expansions at some point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Enjoy the concept and it’s definitely different, but it’s just not a hit for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
After living in Paris for about a year I was finally able to round up 4-5 guys to play games about once/month. These guys ranged in age from 25-65 and were all inquisitive in nature. They were light hearted, good natured, and looked for the best in people. They are what I call 'salty' people. We had a good time playing games such as Catan and Railroad Tycoon. Then I bought and introduced Galaxy Trucker to the mix, and we had an excellent time. From that day forward that was the only game we played. Good times and fond memories.

Fast forward a year and I am living on a French compound in Nigeria. Seeing that my French sucks I naturally gravitated towards the other non-french speaking person on the compound. I am quite sure that we would not be friends otherwise as we have radically different personalities, but he was my neighbor and he was english. In fact he even challenged me to a game of Trivial Pursuit because he wanted to prove that he was smarter (what??). I declined because I do not enjoy that game with people I enjoy hanging out with - I could only imagine what it would be like with him! But instead I brought out Galaxy Trucker and told him my buddies and I loved it and I was dying to play again. So, after a long hiatus Galaxy Trucker was back on the table!

Fast forward to mid-second round and he looks at me and says, "I know why you and your buddies like this game. Only a 14 year old boy would find this game amusing." I looked at him and said, "game over" and swept my arm across the table. That was the day I started to learn French.

What is to be learned from this tale? Don't play this game with people you cannot have a good time with to begin with and don't buy this game if that is the case-you will hate it. If you (or your inner child) like to build stuff (and more importantly see it destroyed) and like to be silly on a Friday night - buy this game immediately.

Why this game is better with more?
1. With more people, the tiles to build the space ship become more scarce. So you can't (or it is harder to) build a perfectly clean ship. This can make even a small meteor shower devastating.
2. With more people someone is more likely to get totally destroyed. That is when the game becomes really fun.

RATING: 9
Awesome theme! Great components, and a fun rulebook. 

The first portion, where you build your ship, is fun...and the time pressure is usually not a big deal. Its mostly a mechanism for not allowing one player to keep the whole table waiting forever, in their indecision.

I love watching the event deck be revealed and see how my ship holds up. Ultimately, the way the scores come out feels like it may not have a huge deal to do with skill...but the narrative that's created really makes the game shine. There is no game I can think of that fills this niche. Galaxy Trucker is truly unique and a fun original design.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Galaxy Trucker is a weird game to rate...I think, in terms of experience, this is amusing to play, but in terms of the actual game, I find it rather random, and I don't think much of the puzzle aspects. Note that I rate this game as being significantly better with the Rough Road expansion, it increases my enjoyment of the game significantly because it insures that ship will take some damage, sometimes...a lot of damage.

The real quick and dirty on this is that you are building a ship and then racing through the galaxy, trying to pick up trade goods. The ships are built on a board, and are puzzley aka: Factory Fun. The building is less structured than Factory Fun though in that there is a large pool of tiles, and you just freely pick them up, and try to add them to your ship. Components in this case are things like pods for your astronauts, lasers, engines, shields, power cells, and the like. This part of the game I find amusing only in that the finished ship is often ridiculous looking with things like engines hooked onto the side of lasers.

After the ships are built, then players head out and face a random deck of encounters where things like smugglers and meteor storms are encountered. All of this is quite random not only in what you encounter but what happens. For instance, meteors come from a certain direction based on the card, but then dice are rolled to see what specific part of the ship they try to run into, and this is huge in terms of what happens to your ship. The goal of the race is to survive and/or be in the front of the pack, and preferably to pick up a few trade goods along the way.

As I mentioned in the opening, in terms of a game, there just isn't much here to talk about. I find the racing part extremely amusing...for instance, in the first race, I didn't build my ship carefully enough, and a meteor hit me such that my ship was literally broken in half, which resulted in raucous laughter on the part of everyone at the table. 

Subsequent plays indicate that some experience makes it much easier to complete the race in one piece, which takes my enjoyment of the game way down. The best solution? Rough Roads combined with Evil Machinations from the Big Expansion, which crank the game back up to the difficulty that I like it at. Also, be sure you have a social group before pulling this out or it'll undoubtedly fall flat, it's not anything close to a serious game, and it's a bit long for its weight.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Party game, quite fun, but no serious gaming included. The ship design is totaly chaotic and in the mission you are just a passenger who throws 2 dice now and then

RATING: 8
Great game!

It has problems with the level of experience of gamers. New players are completely slaughtered most of the time and though it is in a funny way it still can be frustrating for them and for experienced gamers wanting a close game.


After not playing for a few years the issue of imbalance based on experience is definitely an issue - especially with the expansion.

RATING: 9
Ez a játék, ez zseniális. Először realtime építgetünk egy űrhajót, majd feltöltjük legénységgel meg energiával és kilőjük az űrbe. A játék második felében próbálunk minél több árut és pénzt összegyűjteni és reménykedni, hogy elég erős hajót építettünk ahhoz, hogy túlélje az út viszontagságait. Amikor lőnek ránk, vagy meteoritok jönnek felénk az egy az egyben egy ellen-SettlersOfCatan. Dobsz a két kockával és reméled, hogy azok a gyakori számok jönnek ki, amiken kifejezetten bevétted a hajódat. De tapasztalt Catanosok tudják, hogy a nagy számok törvényének demonstrálásához nagyon sokat kell dobálni, sokkal többet, mint egy-egy játék alatt összejön. Egymás után két 9-es dobás effektíve ketté tud vágni egy picit gyengébbre épített hajót: ha nincs szerencséd megy vele az összes hajtómű is. Fel lehet persze ilyesmire készülni az építés közben, de mindenre nem lehet felkészülni.

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
This game gets requested a lot from my various family gaming groups.  Definitely for puzzle lovers.  Building your spaceship, competing with other players for good pieces is quite exciting and fun and constitutes the first half of the game.  This part of each round is one of the finest experiences of gaming pleasure.  But... in comparison the second half of the round is seriously lacking in strategy and interaction and is more of a waiting and watching episode as your ship gets torn apart (especially if you built it poorly).   If the second part had have been more deep and involved, this game would have earned a "10".

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Introductory game with the girlfriend had her exclaiming [i]Oh, I like this better than I thought I would, it's not just about grabbing tiles, but it's also about adding them together semi-intelligently.[/i] Exactly. Why else would I have bought the game...?

After having played about 8 games or so, I conclude that the part grabbing mechanism is nice and works well, and that you get a lot of evocative bits to play with. Unfortunately, this is not a game I'd want to play all the time. There are several reasons for this. [u]First[/u], it all becomes a bit repetitive. There really isn't much variation in what space throws at you, and so the basic requirements your ship should meet are nearly always the same. Lots of guns, lots of engines, lots of cabins, a bit of cargo room, and a few batteries. A shield can be a boon now and then, but that's it, really. Therefore there is no need to be truly creative when building ships, and once you begin to get the hang of it, the only thing holding you back is not finding the components you need on time. [u]Second[/u], although precognition is a very important tactic in this game, there are events which are nigh impossible to plan against. Large meteors and large cannon fire will chip away at your ship (almost) no matter what, so although you can fit your ship with the necessary tools to blast pirates apart and take over abandoned stations, it won't be certain that you actually [i]have[/i] them by the time those cards are turned over. This is a mite annoying, as the payoff for these cards is rather big. [u]Third[/u], there is no direct competition between the players once they are on their way. It is difficult to claw back from a last position, and most of the good stuff will be taken before you can. This forces the building into a bigger gamble than I deem proper: someone who is lucky and builds a slapdash ship might actually survive before someone who constructs a mighty cruiser which can take anything. There should have a been a reward per unit ship flown in as well—after all, this is about supplying stuff to the outer reaches of the Galaxy, not just flying there—to encourage somewhat more thoughtful ship construction. [u]Finally[/u], the game takes too long for what it then, all things considered, becomes. This is unfortunate, but unavoidable.

As a result I'm not really sure how to rate the game. Technically, it's pretty groovy, making use of a rare simultaneous tile grabbing mechanism. And indeed, better players have higher chances of pulling off a journey, but then the burden shifts to your skills in crafting together a ship in record time—is that a good way of setting up a competition between players...? I don't know. I feel there are two sides to Galaxy Trucker: one is novelty and subject, where the game easily reaches an 8, perhaps even a lofty 9. But in terms of gameplay, wellll... I doubt it goes beyond the 5 I've given it. The journey is one of humour as well as a bit of luck, and like all things funny, should be taken in moderation. I like the game, make no mistake, but not sufficiently to play it all the time with its current ruleset.

[b]Update[/b] Bit the bullet and let it go, including all expansions I'd collected. It's really just another Vlaada effort: terribly enticing in theory, flat and not very gamelike in practice.

RATING: 8
I really love playing this game. Space is absolutely my favorite theme, and any game that captures that independent freelancer spirit also is worth trying, and on both accounts GT is a hit. This game has excellent components, a fairly easy to read rulebook with just the right amount of depth, and enough replayability to satisfy. After awhile, experienced players will get almost too good at building ships, but the downloadable rough road cards allow those players to take it to the next level. Overall, an excellent game.

Note: Fun as 2 player, but best with 3+

RATING: 7.5
Not unlike Space Alert, this game requires you to frantically plan ahead for circumstances you can't predict.  You try to piece together the best ship you can imagine, and then set course, hoping for the best.  Along the way you'll encounter asteroids, space pirates, and unexplored planets.

If you keep your sense of humor intact, this game is great fun.  I had a lot of fun losing, and that's a good thing.  This is a unique game that would round out any game collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fantastic push your luck game centered on ship building.  Do you sacrifice time to discover what is in the event decks, or attempt to build a solid ship?  All this while attempting to pressure the other players into making ship building mistakes.

Definitely one of my favorite titles.  I always laugh as everyone's ship plunges on through a horrible trial of ordeals and is summerarily torn apart in the process.  You certainly can't take setbacks seriously.

This game truly shines with 4 - 5 players (with the expansion) as valuable tiles are in short supply, forcing everyone to build quickly.  An increase in build speed usually ends up in build errors or weakness in your ship design.  This becomes punishing on the second and third rounds.

I've found that most people I know develop a poor impression of the game if the learning game is not done in a slow manner as to ease people into learning both the rules and ship building stratagies.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Frenetic fun. Getting better at shipbuilding is fun at first, but eventually the challenges aren't enough. 

Does not handle disparate play-levels well; an experienced player building their ship quickly/well hurts the newer players in multiple ways: better players start in front, better players are probably well-equipped enough to use up all the one-person-only opportunities, in later rounds the better players use up many of the more-desirable components by building faster, and if the better players are cutthroat they'll flip the timer early enough that newer players will have barely-functional ships. Great for the first half-dozen plays, though, if everyone's learning together.

RATING: 6
The frantic build-your-own-spaceship part of Galaxy Trucker is absolutely briliant and unique, but after that it all comes down to staring at the board and waiting for dice to determine whether your ship (and its valuable cargo) is going to be blown away by meteors, blasters or an overwhelming combination of both. It's a fun game to play, but way too random and chaotic to be taken seriously.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Components: All around great components. The modules are easy to comprehend, despite their variety; the cards have clear iconography; the astronauts, aliens, batteries, and spaceship pawns are all cool. The only downside is the shear number of components; I found it necessary to buy a tray to house them during play.

Experience: What a fantastic game; a brilliant concept that delivers. In the first part of a round, there are opportunities for strategy, for how I hope to best avoid the many dangers to come, especially if I'm looking at the upcoming cards. It's so fun to build my ship, trying to cram it full of necessary components.

In the second part of a round, I'm just watching what happens, hoping for the best; there are a few decisions, but mostly it is passive, but still fun, seeing my spaceship fare against the system. There are several different ways to score points. I am fully engaged throughout the game. And it is incredibly satisfying to laugh off a minor asteroid by saying “well-built”.

First Played: 2009-06-12
Last Played: 2012-02-22
Eagerness to Play Again: Within a year

Plays (17):
3 players: 14
4 players: 1
5 players: 2

RATING: 3
Very long personal comment because I'm ripping on a "popular" new game.  Keep in mind my comments are made in the context of me WINNING the game, these are not sour grapes.  A rating of 3 means "Likely won't play this again although could be convinced.  Bad."  This fits my opinion of this game perfectly.  The frantic building race at the start of the round lacks any real decision making.  You're simply trying to build the best space ship.  Can't use a part?  Keep digging.  (Contrast this to the real tension in Factory Fun's real time building decisions:  You can and will get burned if you can't choose rapidly in FF).  I'm not just ripping on the real-time building mechanism,either, I rate Factory Fun a 7.  The "race through space" in the second half of the game sucked.  It contained no real decisions.  Do I spend one of the green chips to use my laser or do I let my ship get blown in half?  Hmmm, I'll have to think that one over for a while (note, this last sentence was sarcasm).  I do not see what other people apparently see in this game.

RATING: 7

This imbalance was solved in expansion(s), which transform(s) Galaxy Trucker into beloved game by many; but this is "just" base game. And as it is, it´s just good (enthusiastic 9/10 for the building part and bored 6/10 for fly part).
