RATING: 7
My first play was with others who'd played MANY games of this, and I found myself lucky to be alive at the end of each round with little or no income, while watching others rake in the credits.  I left the table with a feeling of indifference toward the game.

Recently, I found a copy on the cheap, went for it, and tried it at home with my wife (who'd never played it).  The experience felt very different, and definitely more enjoyable.  Despite being interrupted by a nursing baby, she won!

She liked it, and said so even before she won (which usually helps her opinion of a game).  But it was a fun gaming experience for both of us, I can't think of anything I didn't enjoy about it, and I'm looking forward to many more sessions.  So for now, it's an 8.

Update: down to a 7 because apparently my wife would rather play others in our collection.

Update: Traded.

RATING: 7.5
Plays: 5-10
For me direct player interaction is an essential element of a good boardgame. Galaxy Trucker is not about interaction. At all. 

Yet it's a very fun game.

So what makes this game so much fun? Puzzling to build your ship - nervously watching the progress of other players. But the most fun part: watching the ships fall apart. Piece by piece...

No deep strategy, no tactics, just fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think I honestly enjoy the ship building aspect of Galaxy Trucker moreso the actual core gameplay. Despite that, there is something delightful about throwing together a piece of junk with all your engines on the wrong way around and then watching it explode in space.

Very often when I've played this though, we usually end up getting bored by the time you have to build your second ship. The random events are not diverse or interesting enough to see me want to go through more than once, which is an honest shame.

This is a great game to play while waiting for other people to show up - once they do, you can simply declare whoever has the most intact ship the winner, and then move onto something a little bit less dry.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Galaxy Trucker equals great fun. Building your own ship is interesting and seeing whether it makes the trip or not is just as good. What I really like this game is that there is virtually no downtime. When you are not furiously grabbing parts and building your ship you are flying it and (hopefully) dodging asteroids. I do not recommend this game for serious people or those playing just to win, but for those who can watch half of their ship blown off and laugh at it!

RATING: 8.5
Designer: Vlaada Chvátil (Dugeon Petz, Dungeon Lords, Mage Knight)
Publisher: CGE
Player count: 2-4 (best with 4)
Weight: Medium light
Mechanics: tile laying / real time
Setting/theme: science fiction
Play time: 60 minutes

Rating based on a handful of games with 2 and 3 players, which was a lot of fun. The rules are clear and sometimes hilarious and so is the game. Should not be taken too serious, sometimes almost a party game.

Verdict: keeper

RATING: 3
1. Spend ages sorting pieces, setting up and (if there are new players) explaining the rules. 

2. Frantically piece together your ship in about a minute - this is the game. 

3. Spend ages working through the journey, during which you have very few choices, and watching your ship fall apart. 

4. Repeat.

Imagine a space-boot stamping on a human face - forever.

RATING: 2
I was pretty disappointed by this game.  The first play through was fun, but it quickly became very easy to 'break' the game and constantly have a winning strategy.  My wife stumbled upon it first: just make your ships have little to no exposed connectors on the outside.  Bam.  You have just drastically increased your odds of winning.  Also, the cards and 'randomly' come up become very predictable and boring, and the game never feels new or fresh, or like you have any control over what you're doing.  The game plays you, you don't play the game.

RATING: 4
After one play, not impressed. The ship building mechanism via tile draws doesn't appeal to me. It's either going to be like slapjack if you play with the standard rules, or take way too long if you draw tiles in a round-robin fashion.

Once the ships are built it suffers from a "poor get poorer" problem where one catastrophe generally leads to another, which significantly drops your income. Unless your opponents suffer a similar fate, it's game over man, as I was in about the first 20 minutes of the game I played.

RATING: 7
What I liked:
Bit of tension to building up your ship, especially on the first play. Then watching it crumble as you play the game.

What I didn't like:
Nothing broken as such.

There is a fair bit of luck involved but it isn't really a game you play to win, you more play it to watch the carnage that ensues.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This designer is one to watch for; many of his games have been quite good and are all very diverse. With this title, his witty rules delivery and wacky theme creation are on display, big-time. It's a multiplayer solitaire game in which players repeatedly construct spaceships, only to send them hurtling through the galaxy to be blown to smithereens. Spaceship construction is done in real-time, which makes for tons of laughter and all-out madness. If you like a game that doesn't take itself too seriously and is just plain fun, get this game...NOW, do it now!

Update: After playing countless times with several different groups, I'm liking it more and more. I'm increasing my rating from a 9 to a 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game in two acts: one beautiful, the other plain.

Ship construction is a dynamic, hectic experience that is packed with fun and tricky decisions.  Timed gameplay is a rare thing and this is to be savored.

The actual journeys feel like a letdown by comparison.  Though there is a great deal of drama and the joy of watching ships get mangled, the lack of decisions removes much of the desired tension.

Fun but flawed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I should really like this game more than I do because the theme is well done.  But I'm not a fan of real-time games that don't offer many decisions.  Are there really any tough decisions in this game?  You draw a bunch of tiles as fast as you can and piece together a ship.  You want engines in back and ideally guns facing out on the 6,7,and 8's.  Throw in some cargo holds, and human/alien quarters. So the game is all about looking for the right pieces to fit your puzzle.  The winning move is to recognize what you need and build it fast.  In the 2nd half of the game there are really no choices as you rely on luck to survive cards and dice rolls.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

Also, for whatever reason, both times we played I won rather easily, making my desire to play the game rather low. Why bother playing a not especially deep game that I win so easily again?

RATING: 9
A wonderfully themed space game that is a delight to play with a couple of friends. The mechanics are different and it's quick pace makes it a game where nobody is bored. There is a time element and a puzzle element which is unique.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Players construct a spacecraft out of spare parts, then run it across a series of events (the "flight") to try and turn a profit.  Amusing game where ships are constructed from Carcassonne-like tiles in real time.  The bits include crew quarters, engines, cannons, holds, etc.  The object is to build a ship that can do everything - beat off pirates, survive meteors, pick up loot along the way, etc, and still hold together to reach the end of the journey for the big payoff.  However, bits are likely to fall off and if it's the wrong bit, your ship may literally split in two (especially if using the Rough Roads Ahead expansion).  Lots of laughs in this one, especially in the rulebook, but there is a game here.  Bit like Frankenstein - the assembly of the ship is frantic and thinky, while the flight is fast with lots of laughs and groans.  Brilliantly done, and surprisingly getting better with each play.  If that keeps up, Factory Fun and Space Dealer are destined for the trade pile - this game seems to have them both covered.  Great bits, too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love the spatial puzzle aspect, but I'm just not a fan of realtime games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I had some serious beginner's luck on my first play. I've since played the app a few times, and either the computer is cheating, or I'm terrible. Either way, this game isn't about winning anyway. It's really about building a spaceship, and the components really make you feel like you are doing just that, which is something that cannot be conveyed in the app (no matter how well done it is).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
More tense than the light-hearted design would suggest! If you freeze under pressure or hate when a card draw completely wrecks your plans, this isn't the game for you. But if you can roll with the inevitable ship-wrecking asteroid strikes and accept the imperfections of building a junky ship under the gun, GT can be a lot of fun.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Charming in the extreme, never too taxing on the mind, and it clips along at a frantic pace. Even though some of the sub-games aren't exactly new, the synthesis feels quite fresh. It is certainly fun and unlike most other experiences, and I'd find it hard to turn down a game from.

First comes the 'race to grab parts and cobble together your spaceship' phase, which is amusing to try and see if you can even get the thing assembled! Then the ships line up and make it through a deck of challenges: pirates, meteors, war zones, you name it. As you make your way through you might pick up some goods, but more likely you'll have large chunks of your ship fall off. Especially if you build ships like me, where one little connection is the only piece keeping the whole right side attached to the rest of the ship! Rewards for being in first place, selling cargo, and for tidiest ship. Unique, positive, and especially fun! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very funny and innovative game. Will see regular gameplay!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Idea:
Build your spaceship from junkyard and race to finish line avoiding events and gathering stuff from planets.

Mechanism:
First build ship by going through pieces on board (flip them upside) and either put it to ship or leave up for others to pick it. Each piece has 'exits' so that it must fit to your structure and position of piece affects its function (gun direction, shield direction, engines to back only, crew cabin location). You can also look at even cards that will appear but meanwhile others can build their ship
Then you go through cards and resolve effects. If you built your ship right and have some luck you get to finish line with most points.

to who:
If you like to think visually how ship builds up and like easy to learn games this is good.

RATING: 10
Build a space ship from various components in real time, with everyone grabbing tiles as quickly as they can (with some restrictions, like only being able to use one hand and having to finish placing a tile before grabbing a new one).  Then take your ship on a journey which throws various hardships at you to test how well your ship was built.  You need to find some amusement in the thought of watching your ship get cut in half by an errant meteor to enjoy this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Galaxy Trucker stands out as a spectacular game from the most ingenious board game designer in the world.  The timed building aspect of the game is something very unique, very fun, and rewards repeated play.  Expansions that make the game optionally harder for experienced players, balance out the gap in ability between new and veteran players.  Thematically strong and mechanically tight, Galaxy Trucker stands out amongst any other game I've played.  Highly recommended.

iOS implementation amongst the best digital board game ports ever made.  Absolutely rekindled my love for this game.  Czech games and Vlaada are the best.

5 on the Cindometer (she does not like the timer aspect!)

RATING: 5
I just don’t get why some people like this game.  I’ve played this a few times and honestly, I guess its aimed at people that like to go to the beach, spend all day investing time and effort to build an intricate sand castle and then get immense joy taking a shovel and smashing it to little pieces before they leave for the day.  
After building your ship (in a corny real-time one-handed manner), your ship is haphazardly torn apart by events that are completely chaotic, random and out of your control.  I’ve seen some players get all excited when they roll a number and an asteroid just misses their ship or takes a wing off another, but I just don’t get it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
My group played this to death in one session.  We were completely annoyed by the silly flip-over-a-hundred-counters part of the game, nor were we big on the way you were allowed to peek at the cards showing some of the hazards you were about to face.  That almost instantly became an automatic strategy to the point where we might as well have laid out those cards face up.  Only an idiot would throw his ship together without viewing as many hazard cards as he could; there was simply no reason NOT to do so.

The ship building rules were fun and cool (how you could add tiles to your ship), and watching ships get destroyed was fun.  But the constant tile-digging-and-card-peeking stage drove everybody crazy.  Peeking at hazard cards was the obvious thing to do, and what you saw there totally drove your ship-building "strategy."  Pointless.

RATING: 7
A Vlaada classic. I don't love the simultaneous part of this game, as I really want to make the best ship possible, but that's just not what this game is about. This game is about making the most "good-enough" ship as fast as possible. The game escalates nicely over the three rounds, and I have yet to play another game that comes remotely close to recreating this experience. Also, the app is top-notch, and I like the turn-based component selection variant (though it is not really a sustainable option with big groups).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Lately we've seen lots of luck heavy, dice-driven Eurogames that, for whatever reason, just don't feel too fun to me. These new games seem to sacrifice good planning for the addition of dice and randomness to their games. 

To me, Galaxy Trucker is exactly what these games should have been. GT is full of luck in all sorts of different ways. The turn of a tile, the turn of a card, and the roll of a die, they're all here and they all combine to make a luck-heavy Eurogame very fun.  

7 to 6: It was fun my first few plays, but I just haven't had any type of desire to play it again. 

Update: The hype has seemed to have faded on me and GT. I've played a few other puzzle games recently and I've also sent GT by the wayside. I enjoy some basic puzzle games quite a bit - ubongo, take it easy, on the dot, high score, and the list goes on. For whatever reason, they scratch the puzzle itch more than GT. If you've played the basic puzzle games I've mentioned and you're looking for something with more theme and 'game' feel (vs the sheerly puzzle solving appeal the other games have) I would definately try GT.

RATING: 8
Galaxy Trucker falls into the category of "experience" game, where the fun is in the process of the game and not in the winning and losing. The game even recognises this by saying that as long as you made money, you're a winner! Still, the game does deliver. The most concrete part of the game is in building the ship, and that is fraught with a weird combination of randomness and dexterity. But the rest of the game really just runs on autopilot.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Two games in one: a tile-laying ship-building phase, followed by a resource allocation phase. They first is fun, mad scramble for parts while the second is a bit fatalistic as you watch your ship get torn to bits by forces beyond your control. Great fun, but don't take it too seriously. Game length can be easily adjusted by altering the number of rounds played.

[b]Status: UNINSTALLED[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Apparently you either love this game or you hate it. Apparently I love it and my wife hates it. Actually from the groups ive played with, the women hate it and dudes love it. Probably because it's hilarious when a ship that was built with care gets ripped to shreds on the first adventure cards and everyone laughs at that person. Yea, its unfortunate but hilarious. You have to go into this game realizing that your ship is going to be dominated almost every round unless you have the perfect ship. The building phase is very tense, fast-paced, and basically a puzzle. The adventure cards do usually affect the first player more often than the other players so some rounds can feel dry for the person in last place or the second player in a two-player game, but the game itself is fast-paced enough that it's okay. You just want to survive the travel. So what if your ship gets torn in half on the first card, there's always next round. The ships become more complex with each round and the adventure cards become more demanding and dangerous. This game is tense in all the right ways and I bought the expansion before I finished the first game (not really, but I should have). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Very original game, as you build a wacky space ship, then watch it get ripped to shreds.  Lots of fun, even if you're doing poorly, because your ship is a result of your creating work.  It has a real-time puzzling aspect that won't appeal to everyone, because it's half puzzle and half boardgame.  Negative comments remark on the amount of chaos because of the dicefest, or that the puzzling of the ship assembly phase didn't appeal to them.  A polarizing game that you'll either love or hate.

See my comprehensive pictorial review: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/759764

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Amazing components. Great theme. new mechanics. Lousy rulebook. I'm a bit concerned about the fun factor being primarily in the shipbuilding, and the cards being mostly an elaborate way of scoring. I suppose the cards make it a game, not just an activity, but they just don't quite have the same aura of "Wow!" about them that the first part of the game has. So I guess I'm on the fence on this one.

That said, there seem to be "hmm..." games where one contemplates their next move, and there are "fun" games where one gets excited and things blow up. Some games seem to merge these edges of the continuum and make for intriguing and exciting gameplay. I tend to prefer games that fall more on the "hmm..." side of that continuum. I think it could be argued that GT is a fine example of a game well onto the"fun" side of things.

RATING: 2
2017-02-20: DID NOT LIKE THIS!
I think the stress element leaked into the rules explanation since a bunch of rules wasn't explained until shit just happened.
On the first round, we hit 'Open Space' first, then the second thing was something that killed all my crew. "Oh, you died!" said the most experienced play which at that moment I wiped my board. But strangly enough you can still operate the shields while no crew is on board but not land on planets. . . wierd.
On the second turn someone actually brought out colored aliens from the box. Aha? Interesting? Would it kill someone if that was properly explained in the beginning? Also, on the second turn, everybody flipped their board I guess but I didn't and nobody told me I had the wrong side up. Good luck with that ship!
In the last of the three rounds, I read the rules and happily introduced the rule that cannons firing to the sides and backwards only count as one point. . . SINCE THAT SEEMED TO BE THE WHOLE POINT OF THIS FRIKKING GAME! (i.e. to miss rules and explain them at the worst possible time).

We actually played the 'Anniversary edition' but without expansions. The components were absoluty fine except frikkin player aids are needed to explain what the frakk is happening.

I've played Tzolkin, Great Western Trail, Terra Mystica, KanBan, The Gallerist, Vinhos. All with probably some rule not explained properly. . . NONE of all those quite advanced games were quite as frustrating as this to miss rules in. . . there is no time to ask for rules clarifications!

I guess this game grows with when you learn the rules but as an experience now for me? A solid frikkin turdlike 1 . . . HATED IT LIKE NOTHING ELSE!!
Current rating = 2 ( I can't count all of the missed rules into actually judging the full game. So congrats on the extra point crappy Galaxy Trucker!)

RATING: 9
I am a huge fan of most of Vlaada's designs.

I love the implementation of the timer (any player can start it if they feel they are ahead), which is an excellent way to balance the game's difficulty against the players' skill.

And it's just great fun to watch space ships being blown apart piece by piece.

Dentro de um tempo limitadíssimo nós devemos montar uma nave espacial cargueira que em um segundo momento vai passar por uma série de eventos. Dentre eles, coletar recursos nos planetas, chuvas de meteoros, ataques de naves inimigas, etc. A nave pode ter compartimentos para tripulantes, compartimentos para alienígenas, espaço para carregas, propulsores, lasers e escudos. Tudo isso deve ser montado em um período de tempo curtíssimo. O grande problema é que ao final dos eventos a nave pode ficar bem avariada e acabar transportando poucos recursos. As avarias são definidas na rolagem de dois D6. No final da cada um dos três turnos as mercadorias se transformam em dinheiro. Quem tiver mais dinheiro no final do jogo vence. Muito legal o jogo.

RATING: 8.7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Galaxy Trucker is played in two distinct phases. In the first, players build their spaceships in realtime, grabbing tiles from a common pool and assembling them in the best possible way. In the flight phase, those ships are sent out to earn money and on their voyages have a number of encounters, both good (e.g. trading opportunities) and bad (e.g. pirate attacks, asteroids), but mostly bad. This is where the previously built ships have to prove that they are more than the scrap heaps they look like.

It's rare that a ship comes through unharmed, and points are scored depending on how well the encounters went, and how much of your ship is actually left. Repeat three times, with the ships getting bigger and encounters getting meaner, and the player who made the most money wins.

Whether you like Galaxy Trucker or not depends mostly on whether you like the frantic ship-building under time pressure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
There's a lot of randomness and craziness, but this is an extremely fun game nonetheless. If you're not expecting a game where you carefully analyze each decision then you will have fun. This is a game where you will make a lot of mistakes, but it's fun as long as you remember that your opponents are too. 

You ship is often hideous before leaving the port, much less by the time it's been shot at and pummeled with meteors. That's half the fun.

My only complaint is that it takes way too long for being so light. Having three phases helps with the randomness and bad luck, but you can trim it down to 1 or 2 phases if you need a fast game.

RATING: 8
Lightish game that is played in two phases, a real-time shipbuilding phase by bringing tiles to your ship and deciding whether to use them or not.   Second phases is the journey and trade portion where your ship is subjected to the rigors of space.    The ship-building part is a lot of fun, the second phase is just average.  It's worth it for the frantic chaos ship-building phase and if you have the right table, laughing at other's misfortunes where their ship is destroyed in the randomness of the journey phase.

RATING: 7.4
This is a fun game with two parts.  The first is building your spaceship (in a set amount of time), trying to make sure you have enough engines, crew quarters, guns and such to be able to survive pirate attacks, pick up treasure and have someone left to fly the ship.  The second part is watching your ship get blown to bits by pirates, asteroids and your own bad ship design.  I like both parts, but for me the second part is not as fun as the first; I most enjoy building the ship that looks like the Enterprise.  A fun, quick game with strong theme.

RATING: 8

My friends don't seem as into the whole "dying is fun" thing, but they put up with the destruction of their ships with some humor.

Update - I don't play this as much as I used to. Sometimes feels like a chore to get out and set up, especially with all the expansion content making it harder to teach new players. Might be an idea to separate the expansions back out for a while!

RATING: 8

I've learned I need to reinforce that connectors can't go to nowhere and that exposed connectors are counted per side (not number of connectors shown!). I've only played with 2-3 players but looking forward to trying 4 or 5 eventually (with the first expansion).

RATING: 8.5
Kickass game.  *Great* early impressions.  Tons of fun and laughter.  Lots of praying that you don't get hit in *just* that one spot. If someone is flipping that timer constantly it makes the game a hell of a lot more fun as it forces people to satisfice with their ships and make mistakes.

RATING: 6
Quite unique and fun! Vlaada is fairly consistent in his design technique. The 2nd half of the game rounds are indeed chaotic and silly, but the tension of the ship building is what it's all about. Those with an engineering mindset will love this, because you must build something functional within time constraints! That mostly what I enjoy. The actual missions/scoring points seems way too random, and really favors whoever is in the lead. I'm not the best at this game, so there are rounds where I feel like I'm not really doing much of anything for half of the game. This is a major design flaw if you ask me...never lose the engagement of your players.

RATING: 7.5
Tons of fun at first, but has limited replayability once you get to the point where you've become an expert at building ships. At this point, it's necessary to play with the max 4 players, because the only way your ship design is going to vary is if the pool of pieces to draw from is being depleted by three other greedy hands. It's also very imbalanced if you're playing against people who aren't as experienced as you, since the ship building is something that takes some getting used to. Which is unfortunate, because this is a game that I want to introduce everyone to because of how dang entertaining it is. But I know that I have to seriously handicap myself and purposefully build slowly and poorly in order to give them a chance.

I have the expansion, but I haven't gotten the chance to really break into it yet. It looks like it will nicely alleviate the replayability issues, especially as the expansion is actually several modular expansions that you can swap in as needed.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Galaxy Trucker is a soundly engineered game that does exactly what it was built to do.  It's also definitely not a game for everyone.  Among those who should stay away are those who dislike real-time gameplay, those who don't like games with a solitaire puzzle-solving feel, those who are allergic to luck, those who prefer to take their games seriously, and Dave Vander Ark. Galaxy Trucker is not a serious game. It's a wild ride. Once you've done the best job you can in slapping together your space ship, you merely hang on for dear life and hope the thing comes through in one piece. Which it pretty much never does.

I want to stress that Galaxy Trucker is by no means a novelty game like Space Dealer. It has legs. The process of building your ship is difficult enough and strategic enough to remain interesting over the course of repeated plays. Advanced players will be scouting the flight cards, tailoring their ships for the road ahead. Most of the game happens during this ship-building phase, but the flight phase has just enough going on to keep everyone involved and entertained. The flight phase is definitely not the meat of the game, but it's usually funny, often quite tense, and always creates a good narrative.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
also looking for expansions
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is very good at provoking your emotions -- panic, fear, despair. The rules are brilliantly written. If only it were more portable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
We love this game. My kids can't get enough of it. Its just so different from any other game. Placing tiles as fast as you can against the (egg) timer to complete different ships in ever increasing size. Trying your dangest to get the best tiles before someone else does, whilst balancing guns, engines, cargo holds, shields, crew, aliens etc etc to make your ship ready for flight to deliver said goods through meteor showers, pirates, smugglers and combat zones, with a hopefully intact ship, to the company for cold hard cosmic credits. 
Have been playing with the Big Expansion since 17th play. It has taken the girls a while to get the hang of the new tiles. They aren't game enough for the Rough Road or Evil Machinations cards yet. That's because they still get annoyed if their ship gets blown apart. This game has definitely given me some of my fondest gaming experiences with my daughters. It plays in under an hour with the three of us.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is just a fun game. It is a stress game where you are building a space ship on time and pray that it will arrive in good shape filled with lots of goods. While the meat of the game is building the ship I don’t think that resolving what happens on the trip is less exciting.

While not very similar mechanically, it got the same excitement as RoboRally as there is stress and lots of oops moments and you have to have some spatial skills to do well in the game. This is not a game where people who can’t handle stress will do well at.

After a few games the decisions get trivial, although not less fun. This is something the first expansion fixes. Best played with four players.

RATING: 6
This is an interesting game.  At its heart it's a "quickly pick up Carcassonne-like pieces to fill in a strangely shaped grid before the other players" game, but if you're not the fast type, you can still do *okay* by building your ship well.  After each round of building, a number of disasters and events will occur, and those with better-designed ships will fare better.  It's all highly random, but it's a fun, frantic time.

RATING: 3
[Played once] 3. "Likely won't play this again although could be convinced. Bad." Very disappointed; this seems to have had the potential to be so much better. Some people have compared this to Factory Fun because both games have a substantial real-time element, however I think even that similarity is superficial: in Factory Fun, the real-time choices you have to make are interesting, and you must be quick. In Galaxy Trucker, on the other hand, you just keep looking at pieces and junking them if they're no good: it seems more like lazy design than genuine innovation. Should I chance to give this further plays, I can easily see my rating sinking even lower.

RATING: N/A
als "Galaxy Trucker: Jubiläumsausgabe (aka Galaxy Trucker: Anniversary Edition) (2012)" s.u.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If you don't take this game too seriously, it is pure fun... build your spaceship against the clock, and against your fellow space truckers, and then watch as bits of it get blown out of the sky by pirates, slavers and other miscreants.

The ship-building aspect definitely suits some people more than others.. probably those with good spatial, mathematical or engineering skills, and with good hand-eye co-ordination too! 

The space exploration aspect has some decisions to make, like stopping for cargo, points etc. and sometimes it distinctly helps not to be the lead ship... however a lot of the outcome of the exploration is pretty random with die-rolling to see where your ship is hit etc. But it's always funny to watch half your ship float off into space because one key component gets taken out that was holding everything together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 8
I once heard that Galaxy Trucker was a party gamer for gamers. I can't tell if that is true, but I can say it is a lot of fun.
I generally turn down dexterity games and time based games, it is, in a sense, both, and yet I can only say good things about it.
Deceivingly simple, Galaxy Trucker is easy to recommend to almost everyone.
Plays well with all player counts, but becomes harder with more people if you use only the base tiles (as there will be too few for all 4 to build well with).

RATING: 8
I would probably rate it lower if it had a mundane theme, but I'm biased toward Sci-Fi, and the components are pretty cool, even though I would have preferred more detailed miniatures. The ship building phase is nice, although quite derivative of "Factory Fun". The flight phase, however, has very little and very obvious decision making, and there is a lot of luck with the cards and dice. Also, a defenseless player can be saved from the attack of enemies by simply being behind a well-armed player in flight order. Although thematically justified (the enemy is destroyed), that is the bit of randomness that annoys me the most.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
sand timer

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Yera

Como juego de mesa, es un tanto raro. No es un euro de pensar y de mecanicas reposadas, tampoco es un ameri de aventuras y ñecos. de hecho en realidad, cuando te lo describen, lo que piensas es en un juego de MB de aquellos de los 90s... pero luego resulta que es un gran juego. 

La tematica es que somos cargueros espaciales (galaxy truckers) y tenemos que construir "la mejor nave posible", y luego ganar fortuna con ella en el espacio (que es como se gana, o no, la partida). la gracia del asunto es como se construye la nave. 

Cada jugador tiene un tablero vacio con una "planta" dividida en casillas, de la nave. y hay un monton comun para todos los jugadores de fichas boca abajo que son con las que se construye la nave. hay motores, cañones, escudos, pilas de enegia, espacios de carga, habitats para astronautas y para alienigenas (la nave para el viaje lleva tripulacion, que pueden ser humanos o aliens. hay dos tipos de aliens con normas especificas para cada uno), conectores, etc. de variadas configuraciones (conexiones por uno, dos, tres o los cuatro lados de la ficha). el metodo es coger fichas a voleo del monton, una a una, y combinar con ellas en el tablero (en el cual, si plantas una ficha, no la puedes sacar. te creias que iba a ser facil, eh? xD) hasta llegar a construir la nave. esto lo hacen todos a la vez y hay un limite de tiempo marcado por un reloj que puede manejar cualquiera de los jugadores. un free for all en toda regla. :D

luego de eso hay una fase en la que los jugadores se comprueban unos a otros que la nave del otro es "legal" (que no hay conexiones mal hechas) y si hay conexiones mal hechas se quita el cacho que esté mal y lo que cuelgue de el hasta que sea legal. si te has equivocado a lo mejor pierdes media nave antes de empezar la fase de puntuacion. 

y por ultimo llega la fase de "viaje" que es en la que se puntua. con un mazo de cartas aleatorio, las naves "viajan", cargan mercancias segun su orden de llegada y se enfrentan a peligros (piratas, naves abandonadas, asteroides, etc) con el objetivo de cargar las mas y mejores mercancias posibles, evitar o destruir los peligros y llegar el primero al final. en funcion de lo logrado, se otorgan puntos. gana el que consiga mas puntos. 

entendido? si? a jugar! :D

top5 de los "juegos ligeros". 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 8

Board game crack.  

Much more control than some give it credit for.  Every attack can be prevented with proper ship building, and there is definitely room to keep getting better.  If you get your ship blown apart it's probably your own fault, though you can also luck out and sneak a crappy ship through.  I expect as we keep playing, scores will continue to rise.  

EXCELLENT rules, theming, and components, all with a sense of humor.  Great fun, and absolutely highly recommended if you like speed games, puzzle games, factory fun, or just plain fun.  

It's not too long by any means.  The last game we played, we extended the game even longer with the 3a ship.

I really hope this gets a US release, and many expansions.   My new favorite game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is quickly becoming one of my favorite games.  Fast, funny, and brutal.  The base game could use some more direct player interactions though, I'd love a way to shoot/sabotage/mess with somebody else.

RATING: 5
Joc de col·locació de losetes en temps real en el que els jugadors han de construir una nau mitjançant un "stock" comú de peces (losetes) situat al centre de la taula. El joc té dues fases ben diferenciades, una primera en la que es construeix la nau, i un altre en la que s'envia la nau a realizar un "enviament" per guanyar diners (guanya el jugador amb més diners recaudats). Aquesta segona fase té molt d'atzar (tirades de daus, cartes agafades de forma aleatoria amb events), tot i que durant la construcción de la nau els jugadors tenen la possibilitat de veure el 75% de les cartes (perden temps per a la construcció de la nau...). Es juguen 3 rondes, cadascuna amb una nau més gran i amb events més "poderosos".
Experiencia de joc molt divertida, tot i que molt caòtica.

L'experiencia previa en el joc és molt important, amb 8-10 partides les naus que es fan a la primera fase son molt semblants entre si, de forma que decideix l'atzar.

RATING: 6.5
After my first play (basically a learning game), I'm not sure what to make of this game.  I like the aspect of building your ship, and the simultaneous play keeps the game length down.  But I like to have more time to strategize, and it's hard to do that when the timer's running.

Also, I generally don't like games with dice, because they can be so random.  I tried to use strategy to overcome this -- I put side guns on row 7, hoping to defeat meteors that rolled 6,7,8, but they got taken out by rolls from front!  Annoying.

Overall, I think it's fun and worth trying again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A light/funny game which combines a few elements: tile laying (when building your ship), light racing game (when going thru the "adventure deck") and resource collecting/management (energy and cargo).

Although it may be played by the entire family, there is nothing anyone can do to prevent an experienced player from winning, not to mention that the element of luck is rampant.

In the last game I have played, the experienced player never had more than ONE empty square on his ship!  In the third race, he had a laser in EVERY column, and only one empty square still...  It becomes extremely difficult to get the proper tiles as everyone draws from the same pool, so there is a large element of luck during the draw, as sometimes you will get a good piece you can't use, and of course someone else will grab it.  The experienced players will know which pieces NOT to return to the center.

Best (fun) played versus players of the same level.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Fun game with a bit of friendly competitiveness. Any game that gets my boys laughing at each other is great in my book.
The tense building phase and then watching the outcome as your ship succeeds or fails provides for a unique gaming experience. Despite the rather complex appearance it's actually a fairly quick game to teach and learn. I'm sure this will become a family favorite.

RATING: 6
Well, I like the concept but I'm not sure I like the execution. Constructing your space jalopy takes a lot of effort that is just thrown out the window with the extreme randomness that follows. It's fine for a light "experience" game-- the disasters that inevitably happen are truly amusing-- but even at that it's pretty long. A miss for me, but I can definitely see the appeal and I'd play again in the right mood.

(1 play, 5 players, expansion included)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
3-13-10
My biggest fear with this game is it'd be too random and chaotic.  To a certain extent, that was true.  Random cards of bad happenings with random dice rolls for ship explosions and random tile picking for ship building.  It feels like you just build a solid ship and hope for the best.

It is a lot of fun though.  The light theme, the fairly quick gameplay and ship creation is fun.  The randomness pretty much decides who wins.  In my first play, I went from only getting $1 the first round to $49 the last round in cargo alone.  It just so happened the planet cards came out with me ahead and I got some nice cargo.  It doesn't feel like I earned it by any strategy or skill.

The fun makes up for a large part of the huge luck swings though.  It's like Killer Bunnies - you don't really play to win, you play for the experience.

RATING: 6
2008 (20E Spellenspektakel) Making a fast puzzle is not my thing. But it's a real fun game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
First, I admit that I have difficulty grokking Vlaada's games. The rules are almost always enough of a barrier to gameplay that even though it is clear I have a well-crafted, well-thought out game, the play is difficult, or slow, or tedious because of the chrome, the catches, the amount of tracking or difficulty budgeting for things.

Galaxy Trucker is probably as difficult to play (well) as his other games, but it's the first Vlaada game I could love at first play.

It plays quickly- the timer and the spaceship tile draft make players move (as well as think) with some haste.  The resolution of adventures is quick (and painful) - and light-hearted.  The humor works here, even when half your spaceship is knocked off by meteors, and you are left a skeleton crew trying to salvage your goods and make it through.  My learning play took about 1 hour; of course I couldn't complete many trips which made things faster (Ow!).

It's accessible- build the 'Millenium Aardvark', then try to fly it to the Spice Mines of Kwyxil and earn some kind of a bonus.

It's tight- just what you've come to expect from Vlaada. But it's also got a little luck, as well as manic planning, and it looks and feels fun on the table.

I haven't given up on Vlaada's other games, but now I know why this one is well-loved.  I'm starting this at a 7.5, but expect that with madcap fun this one may go up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.9
Not a game for me.
I like the ship building, its franticness, the fact that you create something. I feel like that part would however feel old pretty quickly, because there is not that much variety overall (even with a bagillion parts, they're mostly the same).
I hate the race part. It gives everything to the lead player, helping him get more headstart than he already has, and others don't do anything in the meantime. It's crazy! You get other people to come play, you get them to build a ship, but you don't let them play with it. Or just a little bit. I hate this mechanism.

I'll sell the game away. More race-oriented people do like it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is an interesting game within a game. The first part is a real-time race to build a robust space ship, with components drawn from a communal pile of stuff. The second part is fun as players race their hastily put-together piles of junk, that pass for space ships, around a race track, while having same said ships gradually get trashed as they run into asteroids and pirates. I'm glad I played this game. It is novel and unique, but it is not my cup of tea.

Update (01/31/12): I didn't realize this is one of Vlaada Chvátil's early designs, but can see where he got the inspiration for Dungeon Lords, where both demonstrate his linear thinking. In both games you build something up, whether it is a spaceship or dungeon, and then your design is slowly destroyed by asteroids or human adventurers in a linear left-to-right fashion. It didn't click for me in Dungeon Lords thematically, but it seems to work for Galaxy Trucker.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Man, what a letdown.  This looked great, and I feel as if I should love it, but it really felt flat to me.  I'm not sure what it's missing—it just came out as a mechanical exercise instead of the nail-biting, fate-hanging-on-the-turn-of-a-card experience it promised.

Perhaps I just need to relax and get into it more, but the cartoony art provides a speedbump I just can't clear.  Maybe... maybe if we had a more intuitive grasp of the rules so the game flows instead of clumps.  Nice idea, but that would require more plays, and this one's slipped far, far down the list.

UPDATE:  So we're playing and I'm bumping along the bottom and we make it to stage III and then I get a work call that forces me to step away from the table for a bit...  Upon returning I find out I won.  

[i]Huh.[/i]

UPDATE:  6 --> 7  Jeez, I don't know what my problem was.  This game's a riot with the right people!

UP-UPDATE:  Couple things.

1.  Don't let the engineer in your group endlessly noodle with the iPad app—he will build perfect ships no matter what tactics are employed against him, like "bogart all cannons" or the classic "sand timer cartwheel".  And then he'll double all your scores.  [i]Forever.[/i]

2.  It takes a certain kind of emotional fortitude to not weep openly when you finally finagle things to punch it to the front of the pack and run down the four-dollar pirate, putting salvo after salvo of beam weapons through his papier-mâché flying saucer, and then you're not even buzzed from your first celebratory Zgwortz when you warp around a neutron star and straight into the teeth of [i]Voidbeard the Pirate[/i] with his nonstop fusillades that peel your battery nacelles, fountain crew into the silent black, and pick your guns and engines off one after the other and so on until you're just screaming for it all to stop [i]stop STOP![/i]  And then the iPad-practiced engineer comes in and mops him up for the 12-dollar bounty.  There are words to describe that sensation, but they carry far more meaning when screamed inside an isolating helmet rather than read off a dumb screen.

[imageid=2347067]
[size=7]Fig. 1 — [i]The four-dollar pirate suddenly realizes
that macaroni, glue and glitter make for terrible
starship armor.[/i][/size]

[size=7]NOTE 1:  Normally I hate it when people use the generic term "dollar" for all intermediary economic exchange units in games when there are already perfectly appropriate game-specific designators like "ducats" or "galacticreds" or "orphan femurs", but it turns out that "four-dollar pirate" is funnier than the thematic alternative.

NOTE 2:  Voidbeard the Pirate, so-called due to his hideous predilection for weaving curdled space-time into his beard to strike terror into the hearts of his victims.  And man, does it [i]ever[/i].[/size]

RATING: 7
For close to a decade, my wife has wanted this game but between life, finances, and lack of table space, we never got around to picking it up.

We finally did in 2016, and it has hit our table many times, and we always regret not buying it sooner.

There's a lot of luck and randomness, which I usually don't like unless the game is short (see: King of Tokyo). On the other hand, everyone is laughing for much of the game, so I feel like the fun more than makes up for a few niggling aspects.

-----

Note: I only started tracking in January of 2017, so please ignore the play count.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The way I described this game to my friends was "This is not a game about doing the best, it's a game about doing the least-worst". Bad things WILL happen to you in Galaxy Trucker, but the game embraces that concept to HILARIOUS effect. This game is like the cardboard equivalent of stage improv: it's not about keeping things straight, it's about making things go off the rails as amazingly as you can.
Building your ship tactically will help you, but when an unlucky die roll lets a saboteur hit your center cabin, blowing up HALF of your ship in the first round, all you can do is laugh. If you have any sense of humor at all, then this game will leave you laughing the entire time; because you and your friends will know that the terrible thing that happened to your friend last round will probably be happening to you this round.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I played the first round of the game after a rules explanation.  I didn't think that it was that interesting, and it felt really, really random.  I suppose it's an 'experience' kind of game, but I don't like those.

RATING: 8.6

The rule book is well written and contains humorous anecdotes and nice design throughout. I would suggest watching one of the youtube playthrough videos before your first game to help give you a jumpstart on learning the mechanics and rules of the game.

RATING: 7

It's not hard to adopt simplified rules for children and simpler rules for adults to get a more interesting gaming experience.  Work up to the full set of rules as you gain experience.  However, the "grab what you can" element of the game needs simple rules, otherwise the game becomes a chore.

RATING: N/A
8 maig 2016
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Fun game.  Building your ship is stressful and fun... and then you get to see how it fares out in space.  There are fewer meaningful decisions in the second half of each round, and I can understand how luck might ruin some people's day, but I find it refreshing and fun.  Can't wait to play it again!

The only issue I have with the game is that it gets a bit stale once you've mastered ship building.  However, "the Big Expansion" fixes this by adding new ship boards, new tiles, more aliens, new rules for games with 2 or 3 players, and all sorts of nasty events in the "Rough Roads" and "Evil Machinations" decks.  There's also a variant to handicap experienced players when playing with new players.  The expansion really makes this game much more replayable, and I'd highly recommend it.

Purchased from German Games, June 2012.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really fun game concept.  And a game that works for both the family and for the gaming crew.

Spacecraft building is a terrific mechanic.  [As the engineer, I found this part of the game particularly enjoyable.]

There's just enough random elements - i.e., building a ship from "found" parts, what cards (encounters) will occur during a mission and in what order - to provide a very healthy replayability.  [On the flip side, the random elements combined with a modest amount (but not a lot) of decision-making once the ship is built keep the game from being categorized in the "deeply strategic" class - which is perfectly OK given the game's high "fun factor".]

Somewhere inside this game is a of part Carcassone and a part of RoboRally . . . both of which are good for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
with Big Expansion and Another Big Expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Cumple David Burgos
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Much better than I expected.  There are a few too many fiddly rules for my tastes, but the overall experience is quite enjoyable.

I like building my ship as quickly as possible and as large as possible.  I thought the connection rules made a lot of logical sense.  I also enjoy trying to weather through all the calamities that come your way during the race portion.

I didn't enjoy the finer distinctions between meteor strikes versus fire combat attacks.  I also didn't enjoy the events that penalized people who were already in last.

I dont take this game seriously either. It is an overrated, fun game which could be used as filler between heavy ones.

RATING: 6

RATING: 7.5
Ideal Players: 2-4

Description: Build your space ship out of tiles, then try to survive three missions!

Pro: Fast and fun scramble to build ships. Great graphics. Completely unique game concept. Every game is unique, and players get better over time.

Con: Lots of random elements. In most games the ship you've worked so hard to build will be completely destroyed.

RATING: 8.5
It seems that people either love or hate this game the first time they play it. There is alot of luck involved, and some people might feel sour grapes over having been screwed by the game. But its one of the few games where I feel loosing is just as much fun (and utterly hilarious) as winning. It's chaotic, its random, with just the right amount of accountability and skill that you can still get better at the game. As a tile laying mechanic lover, this game also gets a few bonus points from me. Only downside is it doesn't really work as well a two player, although i wish it did. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With the right group willing to laugh at each others failures this game can really sing. It has a lot of bits and pieces but all is pretty easily understood to let you sit back and enjoy the ride.

RATING: 7.5
My rating: (out of five)
Strategy: 3.5
Luck factor: 5 for starters, but experienced players can do pretty well.
Players interaction: Medium, mostly passive.
Play/Wait Ratio: No dead time. Game is simultaneous, and even if you finished early in the building phase, you have the hour glass to speed the other players up. 
Replayability: 3. The building is fun, and different stuff happen in every game, yet it is very random and it might tire you after a while.

RATING: 8
Okay, so some aspects of the game are random but this is way overshadowed by the sheer fun one has playing it.  There are also some neat new mechanics that also make it a nice change of pace.  I think this will be a big hit for younger new players.  I was also very sceptical about having a timer, which I hate in most games, but find it works very well in this game.  There is some pressure to get your ship built but it doesn't lead to total chaos.  Without somekind of timing mechanism I could see some players taking hours to fine tune their ship making the game become way too long for what it is.  As it is, I find it a good mix of presuure, building strategy, and sheer random/luck adventure.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Galaxy trucker is, indeed, loads of fun. Well, it is if flying a spaceship made from sewage pipes through meteor storms and past space pirates and slavers is your idea of fun. Galaxy Trucker is very well-themed (with more than a hint of the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy) and rather original. The Ship Building part of each of the 3 Rounds resembles Factory Fun. It is where most thought is required and is the heart of the game. The Flights seem to me like an afterthought as your success in the game is largely be determined by your ability to quickly contruct a beautiful, well-armed and fast spaceship. I am a poor spaceship designer and so I have come last in every game I've played - though last time, at least, I made a small profit!

RATING: 8
Love the theme and the gameplay. Solid 8, almost 9. (Dec 2016)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is what Factory Fun should be.  In a period where many board games are beginning to feel alike (let’s build a castle by impressing the Moat man’s younger cousin), this one is unique and a blast to play (pun intended).

The game is divided into two phases:  Build a ship, where you are racing against the other players to design a ship ala Factory Fun.  Unlike FF though, this is much more chaotic and it is not just an optimization puzzle.  The second phase is to fly your ship and hope you make it till the end.  Sometimes it’s easy and others you will crash and burn.  

The game is definitely built around the first phase with the second being the let’s sit back and see what happens.  Both make the game what it is.  Though it is a little pricey, definitely one you need to try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Even if the theme may not be very catchy (a trucker, really?) the game is excellent. I love it, the mechanics and how it works, and, above all, it is very very fun to play. Another huge advantage of the game is how easy is to explain, there may be some tiles that require further explanation but the idea couldn't be easier: take a tile, decide whether you like it or not, and put it in your ship. Let's see now if you are prepare for the galaxy madness.
I recommend this game to everybody: expert players, new gamers, non-gamers, for a family afternoon when there is nothing else to talk about... Really, I recommend it completely, it should be a must in every gamers' group.
As a summary, some positive and negative aspects of the game:
Positive:
1. Superfun
2. Easy to explain
3. Recommended for every type of player
4. Good duration of the game, usually less than 90 minutes
Negative:
1. The basic game is a bit short on variety, it requires the expansion. The first one at least
2. I don't really like the fact that, for phases 2 and 3, the clock has to switch that many times before activating the end of the building phase (an in-house rule can be applied for this)
3. Many gamers may think that this is a minor game and not the great game it is
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Perhaps my favorite board game.  Period.  Perfect combination of skill, luck, and theme.  The fun of the game is watching your hunk of junk struggle to reach the end in one piece coupled with pressuring your slow friends by running down the clock.  Best played with people you're comfortable with in an environment that lets you yell obscenities.  A very social game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pretty cool game although it does have a good bit of that new novelty effect that may wear off as it is so VERY original for now. A FUN game if not taken seriously, the best of all the building race games I have played to date. 

Spatial orientated so spatial people will tend to fair a little better, it's a very well put together game and has great components. 

PROS: 

- Great theme
- VERY original
- FUN
- Great components

CONS: 

- Large random elements
- Limited control
- Very little decision making
- Almost no Strategy (tiny bits in building)
- A little long for weight

Much better than factory fun because of all the added elements here, makes a good gateway game with most rules pretty simple.  Lots of things done right here and not too much wrong, really nothing other than the luck and strategy but this is a game where you are playing for the fun and other elements so it doesn’t detract as much as it otherwise would. Rating may fall a little unless it has staying power as a gateway.

RATING: 7
a game of painstakingly building a beautiful ship and then taking it into space where it gets totally trashed.

pretty long for what it is, because you basically play two games each round (up to 4 rounds): build the ship; destroy the ship. each round takes longer, as you have a larger ship and more space to explore.

round 4 is my favorite, as it's usually the one where there's enough competition for pieces that you all screw up during construction. and then you go into space and get super fucked. love it!

RATING: 8
Meh, I'm just not good at speed games like this, and the speed is really just too huge a part of it to ignore and still enjoy. Going last (or almost last) is perpetually frustrating, and not exactly fun.

Edit: After more plays, it is fun, but playing with people who are just way better than you really isn't, and there's a big learning curve. On top of that, there's really not a good way to penalize the good players. Even with the rough road cards, they'll still toast you. I guess the moral is to get good, it's just not that fun when everything always goes to the dogs. Maybe I just mind losing badly too much.

RATING: 7
Has ranged from fairly fun to ridiculously hilarious - the latter occurring when everyone's ship gets blown to bits...  I would like it more if it were harder, more often than not my ship gets through relatively unscathed.

The game/laugh quotient here is unmatched.  I may not remember that I killed the pirates, just as I can't remember a thing about my last game of Puerto Rico (other than using a building strategy and coming in 2nd), but I sure as hell will remember forever the evening that I pointed out a very, very weak spot on someone's otherwise well put together ship, only to watch the first die roll on the first card of the round hit that exact weak spot, essentially destroying half of their ship.

Some games of Galaxy Trucker go by with little fanfare or excitement.  If these games were the norm, it'd be a 6, and I would have traded it away given what I paid for it... but the other half of the time?  If you hate rooms full of laughter, you would truly despise this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The game just never gets old, even after many playthroughs. The ability to push the hourglass during building allows for easy scaling as your group gets better at the game.

RATING: 7
2012-03-08

Initial Rating: 8.5 (October 2010)

Another hit from Vlaada. What I most like about his games is that they are utterly different than anything I have played before, and Galaxy Trucker, is no exception. 

It is a very fun and innovative game. You have to build your ship and later you have to see how it is blown to pieces. It is a light game but it offers lots and lots of laughs and I love the theme.

Bottom line, Galaxy Trucker is a very solid game, not for constant play but I can see myself playing Galaxy Trucker for a long time.  

Current Rating: 8.0

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
After reading all the hype surrounding this game, I thought that it would be at the top of my want list.  After playing once, I've placed it on the 'just no fun for me' list.

The reason?  I'm terrible when it comes to games that require manual dexterity... especially if there's a timer involved.  My old brain just doesn't work that fast... and, no matter how fast I am, someone else is ALWAYS faster!  Probably why I don't like Ligretto/Dutch Blitz or Factory Fun either.

For example: I see a piece that someone else discarded, look at my ship and find a perfect spot for it, reach for the piece... and someone else grabs it!  Over and over and over again!  I end up with a ship built by luck of the draw and limp through round after round, losing part after part because I was unlucky enough not to get that crucial cannon or shield or engine or cargo hold.

Too many random events, little or no planning (if you have no reflexes) turns into no fun for me at all.

If you're 12 years old with lightning reflexes... this game will be one of your favorites.  If you're past your prime like I am, just watch others play and kibbitz... it will definitely be more fun.

If you throw away the timer and change the 'build ship' round to allow sequential moves, it might make it more my kind of game.  But that would probably add an additional hour or more to the play time... and then we're into a whole 'nother problem.

For the time being, I'll give Galaxy Trucker the only rating that fits... a '4' "Not so good but could be talked into it on occasion."

As a side note, I've traded away my copy for Volldampf... I think that I got the better deal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A very simple, fun and hilarious game! Heard so much about it but hesitated in getting it as i was not sure whether my gaming group will like it, plus the price of this game is not cheap. Then i received it as my birthday present recently and having played it one time, the feeling was absolutely fantastic! The randomness can be hard to handle but not discouraging at all. It is a very unique game that requires a different mindset to play it and enjoy it. Give it a try, you will never know. Excellent effort in board game designing and credits to Vlaada Chvatil!

RATING: 7
This game is insanely fun!  Whether playing with first-timers or other experienced pilots, building spaceships only to see them blow up is hilarious.  This is the first game that I scored over a dozen plays within my first week of owning.

So after several games, I've realized that this game is now NO fun with players of varying skill levels.  I've taught the game several times and wipe them clean - no challenge.  Experienced players rarely suffer severe ship carnage and so the fun factor lessens.  The overall rating was lowered to 7 because of this - a 9 with relative skill level and a 5 with newbs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Rating after 1 play.

I was expecting to see a stepped up version of Factory Fun since you not only get to build your ship but fly it around too. Unfortunately the "trucking" portion of the game is unsatisfying as cards are flipped to determine what events players are going to face and then resolved in player order. You can look at the cards that will come up in the current "trucking" round if you'd like to know what awaits you out in space or you can just build your ship. 

As for the building part of the game players simultaneously flip over tiles in the hopes of finding some that they would like to place into their spaceship. Any unwanted tiles go back face up for others to be able to claim. As long as you find what you want that's great if not throw it back. So being able to look quickly through tiles is important. 

The game just doesn't get me on either count. The race falls flat and the building is nowhere near as exciting as Factory Fun.

RATING: 7
Digital iOS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The breadth of Chavtil's talent as a designer is most impressive. This one strikes a good balance between challenging play and harrowing chance. Often the odds against your hastily built, shabby little space frieghter seem overwhelming. So when your hapless crew reaches the end of a journey with a few meagre goods in tow, the relief you feel is legitimately earned. I usually don't care for games with timers, as it feels like an artificial way to build game tension, but here I don't mind it as the bulk of the tension comes after the timed segment.

RATING: 8
This game rocks.  It's great to have in my collection, where it balances other, more heady or strategic options.  
Galaxy trucker is as fun as it is fast, quaint as it is quick, and hilarious as it is hurried.  

If you want the antidote to getting bogged down in serious strategic gameplay where turns last for an eternity and the gravity of every move threatens to overtake your soul, then look to Galaxy Trucker, where your decisions count, but you never fear the repercussions -- you'll be laughing too hard and enjoying yourself too much to worry about it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Galaxy Trucker does so many things right there's only one question remaining: will it stand up to repeat play? Put another way, is there a degree of depth underneath this lighthearted romp through space? All the anecdotal evidence indicates that there is.

The game is played in three rounds, each with two halves. First, you build your ship from a common pool of tiles. Second you see how much cargo you can scrounge while warding off space pirates and meteor showers. The fun is all in the ship-building: how many thrusters, lasers, shields, batteries, cargo bays, crewmembers, and alien comrades can you fit? In what proportion? In what configuration? Can you build your dream ship quickly enough? Have other players already grabbed the tile you're hunting for? Should you settle for something less than a marvel of engineering?

The game is undeniably well done. My only reservation is that the game heavily emphasizes high-speed pattern recognition and frantic tile grabbing during the ship-building phase. This is one of those things that many players will have no desire to get better at, and that some players will naturally do well at. You may get some furrowed brows if you have savants and casual players at the same table. 

Update: Never really got off the ground for me. Very well designed, but the frantic tile grab and ship assembly is almost more fun to watch than to participate in. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun, chaotic and quite unforgiving.

Very amusing from my first play.  More of an experience game than a strategy game.  Race to draw tiles and build a decent ship - a game driven by connections.  Then you draw cards to see what happens to the ship on its voyage - where there is barely any control at all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The best part of the game is putting your ship together in the beggining.  It's sorta lego reminiscent and I find a sense of satisfaction in the problem solving.  However, after that point it becomes more about luck than anything else.  My ship gets hit in the same spot as my buddies over here, the difference is my ship just got split in half and he only lost some batteries.  It's saving grace is that it's ammusing all the same.  
As you watch the remnants the space craft, which you had too much of an emotional attachment too, drift off into space, you turn with a grin as you know it's only a matter of time before some angry dreadnaught cruser or meteor storm turns your friends spaceship into a regurgitated sandwich.

Sure, it's super-light but still satisfying with a surprising amount of decision-making for its weight class.

RATING: 9
I really like casual games... and make no mistake this should be considered a casual game. But it's the type of casual game that strategic board gamers can enjoy... and I haven't really played anything else quite like it. Maybe only an 8 by how it plays, but I'm bumping to a 9 because its the only game I've played like it and that means I'll play it more than my other '8's if I get the choice.

Upgraded to Anniversary Edition.  Gave this copy to Mom. :-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun and Funny
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Like many others have said, this bears a definite resemblance to Factory Fun.  I like the speed element of the game, which can be a little nerve-wracking as you approach crunch time.  It's not as frustrating as FF though, since there are so many tiles that you have quite a bit of freedom in the setup of your ship/truck.  This half of the game is essentially the strategic part, especially if you look at some of the upcoming cards.

The second part of the game is quite chaotic, showing that you really can't take the game too seriously.  It's fun to see your opponent's ship fall to pieces, fun enough that you don't mind when it happens to you.

The rules are relatively simple and very well laid out - even funny in parts.  I was impressed.  I would say that those that don't like speed games or puzzle games (or especially speed puzzle games), or those that can't stand chaos would definitely not enjoy Galaxy Trucker - it's not for everyone.  My main knock on the game is the play time, though with an experienced group it should get quicker.  There would also be a pretty large gap in performance between new and experienced players that would be hard to bridge.

I think if you have the right group, Galaxy Trucker can be a lot of fun.

Update, 3/15: Traded away now that I own the Anniversary Edition

RATING: 7.5
A fun little Star Control 2 type boardgame. This game is mainly about racing with others to build your ship up, and then throwing it against the Adventure cards to see if it survives. Some player-aids would've really helped in this game, but I think most people grasped the use of the different tiles in the end. The quirky rule book was well-written and the components were fantastic albeit a little small/fiddly. 

I only wished the Adventures were not so varied. Some Adventures could leave ships devastated, while others were pretty boring with almost no excitement or dangers.

RATING: 6
We got this game right after Essen via mail order and it is actually numbered; we think it might be part of the original run, something that always delights game collectors like us. Not only is it a great item in our collection, but we actually love playing this game! It can be played on many levels; with our 8 year old, we have played "build the coolest space ship in three minutes" (a great way to familiarize yourself with the component tiles in the set) and we've played it as directed. Our house rules do not use the timer until the next-to-last person has completed their ship; we're not that competitive and haven't played it enough to want to limit ourselves so much by building really crummy ships. Great game with fun game play; I can easily imagine expansions to this one which will be a "must have" for us.

RATING: 4
Nice looking game with great components.  The concept sounds fun, but this one fell flat with my group. The first part of the game, ship building, was kind of fun.  However, it lacked the intensity I expected.  

So now that we built these spaceships what do we do with them?  The answer... not much and that is the biggest problem with the game.  The second part of the game largely plays itself.  Flip over the cards and execute the events.  What decisions there are to made are obvious.  In my play there was little of the schadenfreude that the game promised.  Too bad, because I think there was the potential to present players with some interesting choices.

A disappointing game that I would play again if someone really wanted to play and I was feeling generous.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game was one of the first games I played when I started getting heavy into gaming.  This game can be an excellent, fun, hilarious game but ONLY if you have the right group to play with.  This game is so much more fun if you rush the ship building part and not have a fortress going into the travel step.  The whole point is to have your ship get beat up and see what wreckage you have left to land!  Many times I've played with newer players who simply will not finish their ship until they have as many parts built as possible with no connectors showing and tons of guns and engines.  I will admit that most of my plays have been with players who are new to the game.  The game does not scale well and plays much better with 4 than with 2.  I don't like the first round as the ships are small and you can't do much with them and the cards are simple and basic; meteors usually miss or bounce off, too many open spaces cards, too many planets.  I don't own an expansion and don't feel I necessarily need to.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Never played a full game -- It does look cool. Unfortunately, feel no desire to play this (even with the app which looks amazing)...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is easily one of my all-time favourite games. I really enjoy the chaos and sense of achievement when your Frankenstein of a ship clanks, groaning at every joist, into the final spaceport at the end of each mission. I even enjoy it when my ship disintegrates mid flight after failing to avoid an enormous asteroid. Incredibly fun game to play, with the difficult significantly ramping up with each expansion. There are many ship classes that I'm yet to successfully pilot into port but I still really enjoy each attempt. In addition, when I'm feeling bored I really enjoy putting together my "perfect" ship and taking her out into open space to see how far she can go. The tactile nature of the game and the sense of ownership and achievement of creating the ship add to the experience. What more could I ask for in a game?

RATING: 6
Galaxy Trucker is a unique game. You have to build your space ship by grabbing tiles and placing them on your board as fast as you can. Once you are done you find out whether your ship makes it or randomly gets shot to pieces. That's about it. Roughly... If this sounds fun to you, Galaxy Trucker is your game. If it doesn't, well then you'd better move along. For me it totally depends on the mood I'm in whether I fall in the first or the latter category.

Skip playing the game and just roll D6s to see who gets a higher number. It's more fun than galaxy trucker, and you have more influence on the outcome as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Anyone who doesn't love Galaxy Trucker is wrong.

The only thing more fun than the mad rush of building the spaceships is watching them get brutally demolished during the flight.  No matter how carefully you plan, you always end up leaving a weak spot that is only revealed when your ship falls to pieces.  I'm actually a little disappointed when my ship makes it back in good shape.

Galaxy Trucker lives on that perfect borderline where it's not a party game, but it's played for fun rather than competition.  Certainly, there is an element of strategy and everyone is trying to win.  However, unlike hard core strategy games, you will enjoy it just as much whether you win or lose.
