RATING: N/A
2-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A very unique and clever game composed of 2 phases. First, players compete to rapidly construct a space ship from parts (tiles) grabbed from a shared supply. The resulting ships are often of questionable quality due to time constraints and having been crafted from a rapidly depleting supply of tiles. Players next send their ships on a voyage where they are mostly helpless as they watch while they may be cleaved in half by laser fire, left adrift by slavers, or perhaps arrive in first place and pristine condition. This process is repeated three times (with the stakes increasing each time) and the person who has done the best at the end of the third round wins.

I especially enjoy the tension of racing to rapidly construct a viable and legal ship while competing for parts with the other players.  It is also quite entertaining to see how the ships that everyone has created perform (or how they get mangled as the case may be). At first glance there appears to be a lot of luck in this game but it is actually quite the opposite. Players with more skill will build better ships and they will do better consistently.

In fact, the only drawback of this game for me is that it can be brutal for new players against experienced players (or even for experienced players playing with a more experienced group). It is definitely a game of skill and if there is much discrepancy in skill levels, those with less skill can really end up getting rapidly left behind or obliterated each round. This can drastically reduce the fun factor for the less experienced player. Fortunately, the expansion offers a way to mitigate this. It contains new rules designed to make the game even more difficult (such as ‘Rough Road Ahead’). To balance the playing field for new players, you can simply apply these rules only to the experienced players. I've tried this with new players several times now and it really helps to keep the game competitive and fun for everyone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Never got the chance to play this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very unique and interesting real-time tile placement/ship building game. Not much quite like this, and something that scores highly just because of its uniqueness factor. The game itself is over all too quickly for my liking. The learning curve aside, this one is simple to teach and learn, but very difficult to master. As far as the real-time aspect, I enjoy Space Alert tremendously and it is one of my most favorite games, however, it is not a mechanic that I would want to engage in every single time I play a board game. I tend to play board games to sit back, relax, and think. Unfortunately, there is not much relaxing about Galaxy Trucker. Space Alert's time element does not feel as big of a deal as it is cooperative.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Another game that I wasn’t sure could live up to the hype. Ended up being a very fun space adventure where randomness somewhat exceeds strategy, but the fun factor manages to overcome this otherwise considered (by me) shortcoming.  Once the ships are built, the real fun begins with the different event cards that usually result in parts flying off or crew members jettisoning out into space. In this game, looks don’t matter but finishing the trip with an intact ship is paramount.

RATING: 10
There are plenty of games that are fun when you're doing great, but are boring when you're doing poorly. Galaxy Trucker is one of those rare games that are fun every time you play it, even if you're doing poorly, and especially when everyone is in trouble and struggling to make even a single cosmic credit of profit to make that trip worthwhile.
Experience does help in this game, a lot, but with the team play variant, you can pair a seasoned trucker with a newbie and have a more even trip. Or you could use the great (and free) rough road ahead -expansion as a compensation.

RATING: 4

I'll build some ships, then we'll draw some cards & roll some dice and see what happens... yeah, let me know how it turns out, because I'll be in the next room doing something interesting.

Maybe if the tiles were all face-up during construction, and the order of the adventure cards were all known?  I don't know.  As it is, this game just falls flat for me, even though it seems in all ways like a great game.

Update: gave to Darin 2012-03-01.

RATING: 10

RATING: 7
One of the rare boardgames involving a "real-time" element that I personally actually enjoy (not a usual real-time fan).  It is best approached as a party-styled strategy racing game.  Tournament players should probably avoid this unless you're okay with card randomness.  The design mechanisms of Galaxy Trucker isn't "off the charts", but the fun factor and enjoyment is out of this world and far, far away.  Who can get there spaceship to the end, and whole, without getting it smashed to smitherines?  Who will win with the most points?  Who will be the best ship?

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Possibly my favorite Essen '07 release.  While there might not be a tremendous amount of strategy (although I would argue that there is definitely a fair bit in both building a solid spaceship and looking ahead to see what lies ahead for the race), this game is just enjoyable to play.  There is something about picking up tiles and trying to build a well connected and defended ship to send through a hazardous journey.  Its really fun as well to see ships get destroyed as meteorites and laser fire cuts apart ships and connections die and seeing possibly half the ship get separated and destroyed!  (Well, as long as its not your own ship anyways!)  The bits are pretty nice as well!  I would recommend reading through the rules first and playing the full game instead of just jumping in as the rules allow you to do.  The basic game isn't as good as the full game.

As well, I enjoy a slight variant where the third and final journey is even longer with the usual 1 card from deck 1 in each pile, 2 cards from deck 2 in each pile, and 3 cards from deck 3 in each pile.  Makes surviving the trip even more difficult and much more exciting!

THIS GAME REQUIRES THE BIG EXPANSION FOR FULL ENJOYMENT.  I found the base game become fairly rote and dull after 12 plays or so in that I no longer really have to look at the card deck - there seems to be a general concept of what works well overall most times so why bother?  The big expansion takes that away and creates much more pain, angst, and excitement!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun game with the speed round of building the best ship possible while the timer is running out and other players are racing against you to trigger the end of the building phase.  The flight phase of the ship through space has wildly different results depending on the cards drawn; however, this is not a big deal since there are three separate ship building & flight phases.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Just rating the design, its uniqueness and gameplay, I would have to rate this game at least a 9. Very innovative! 
However, I have to admit that I am not a big friend of real-time strategy games - to me, the ship building phase is just too stressful. Another downside is its randomness, although the short playing time makes up for this again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The concept of this game is stellar. Design your own space ship with all kinds of interesting options, then send it out into the universe to face the challenges of the cards, and compete with other players. I should love this. So what's the problem? The part where you design your ship is implemented so horribly, one could risk invoking demonic possession just to describe the process. It's as if someone created a genius game, and let their 10 year old kid make the final design decisions. Okay, maybe not - I hear people do competitive puzzles, and making your ships is similar to this. I just can't help hating that aspect of Galaxy Trucker. I suppose I will play again if coerced, but I would not expect to have a hope of being competitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A complete blast...lots of rules...but once or twice around the block and this is pure fun.  We even keep track of who arrives at port with the worst ship.  Phase 1 of the game is a tile building race against time-how effective can you build your ship?  It needs guns, it need engines, it needs protection and storage, it needs living space for the crew and much needed aliens.  Phase 2 is the journey through space where you may encounter planets, pirates, meteors, other ships-how will your ship hold up, what cargo will you find?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife swears a lot when she plays this game. She hates this game. I mean really hates it. To be fair, it is partially my fault. She didn't like the idea of building a ship only to have life (adventure cards) tear it apart. I did not provide clear expectations that this is was was going to happen during the game. Opps!

To her credit, she finished the game.

As for me, I liked it. It reminds me of raising children. You can raise them the best that you can (build the best ship), but sooner or later they have to go into the world and make it on their own (face the adventure cards).

The other reason I like it is because it reminds me of the television series [i]Firefly[/i]. In this series, a small group of adventures move from job to job, scraping by a living delivering cargo, dealing with those make their livings by nefarious means (pirates), all while trying to keep their ship together. Galaxy Trucker follows these ideas fairly closely.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A unique theme that is evoked as your spaceship slowly falls apart, a good mechanic to avoid AP, and some cool battery and astronaut pieces can all be found in this game.

The spending time to perform actions and actions being resolved in the order of the ships, along with wanting to be the most intact and fastest ship adds meaningful interaction to the game besides a race to complete your spaceship first/to snipe other people's spaceship pieces.

The only major negative is once your ship starts to fall apart, it becomes progressively more likely it will get damaged, although the 3 rounds means you can certainly make a comeback. It's weird that small asteroids only affect you if you have exposed joints, as otherwise you can avoid much of the damage thrown at you.

Be very careful not to have easily exposed weak joints in your ship, as having a large part of your ship fall off at once can be devastating. I took several 4 junction tiles even if I couldn't utiilize the ability just for the sake of ensuring structural integrity.

RATING: 6
The game starts with the collection of tiles to build a spaceship.  Once the ship is assembled, you then go off and travel to other planets where you gather resources to deliver to other planets.  You can be attacked by aliens or evade asteroids.  Your ship is damaged along the way and can be destroyed unless you have adequate defenses.  It is reasonably fun, but it is tough in that there is a timed puzzle element to assembling your ship.  If you don't like putting together a puzzle under a timer, you may not like this game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
A fun game about space ships cobbled together from junk yard pieces. Pretty unique and different from most other games I know. 

The game is played in two phases. Phase 1: build a ship. Phase 2: watch it fall apart.

1) All players simultaneously build their space ship by laying tiles on their personal board: cockpits, cargo holds, engines, canons, shields, alien life support, etc.

2) The players undertake a long journey. The cards in an event pile are flipped one by one. The ships all get to pick up merchandises if they can afford to, but they will also encounter pirates, smugglers, corrosive star dust and meteorites. The ships slowly fall apart into pieces as they are hit by meteorites and enemy attacks. The cards affect the players in order, according to a time track that is updated when players suffer delays or make use of their engines: the first player gets first pick on the merchandises, but is also the pirates' first target!

Once all event cards have been played and their effect applied, the players have arrived to their destination! Any merchandises which were not lost along the way can be sold for victory points. Players also have to pay a penalty for any ship equipment that was damaged during the trip, and receive bonuses depending on their place on the time track, and the state of their ship. There is no penalty for deceased crew members or lost alien passengers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
All you need to see is the batteries and you will buy it too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
No doubt this is a fun game. However, it can't get a score higher than 7 because of its replay value. You're going to face similar events over and over again, the only difference being the sequence only. And the funniest part is not scoring more than your opponents, but watching your/ opponents' ships fall apart, which can't provide the same amount of humour the second time you saw. Very fun if played rarely like once per year, not a keeper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Very fun game about building a ship, and then watching in horror as all your plans swirl down the bowl as your creation is slowly or instantly destroyed by the adventure cards.  Despite not having a lot of strategy, basically being pretty colors and pieces, it's still a lot of fun.  Because the flights go relatively quickly, the destroying part of seeing what's happening to your and your friends' ships doesn't detract too much from the fun of building the ship.

Figure without this being very deep, rather just a fun romp, I would gladly use this to introduce new players or people that just don't want to think too much to a fun game.  But there's also other options to fill that niche, options that would also have a little deeper gameplay that could also fill my personal tastes.

Traded Zombicide to a guy in Canada for this and its first expansion.

Traded away in Origins 2013 Math Trade

RATING: 9.5
Build your own spaceship from sewer pipes and fly through various encounters! This game is a real blast and you can determine how many rounds (how long) to play. Each consequent round is more longer and more fun of course as the encounters get worse. I just love the balance of stress and fun in this game; first you stress as you try to build as quick as possible and once everyone is finished and the adventure starts it's a real blast to see other's (and your's as well) ships get torn into million pieces.

Previous experience helps a lot in the game, but there are variants in expansions that can be used to mitigate this.

RATING: 8
This feels like two games in one.  The first half you are racing to build a spaceship with cargo bays, lasers, engines, batteries, and places for your astronauts.  The second half you are taking your ship into flight and hoping it holds up enough to reach the destination.  It is a really fun and hectic game and you just hope your ship doesn't fall apart as its being slammed by asteroids and shot at by fighter ships.  Tons of fun.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Really cool and different game mechanic - you dump common tiles into the center of the table and then players in real time race to build their ships in the most economical way; but if you don't do a good job, you'll be blown to bits as the game advances (and there are attacks, asteroid hits, etc).  Only played this game once but thought it was really different and cool.  Some people don't like the real time element since it makes it too stressful, but I personally think that makes it fun, different, and creative.  Vlaada rules.

RATING: 10

Play this game only with people who get a kick out of just having a hilarious time and not taking much very seriously. Then you will have a rockin' good time, it's super duper fun.

RATING: 8
Join the convoy and head across the Galaxy in search of riches and adventure. I wasn't sure at first, but this has quickly become one of my favourite games. You spend about 2/3s the the game "building" your ship and the 1/3 traveling through space. There are many obstacles to over come, such as meteors, space-pirates, slavers, galactic viruses, and even open space. 
Be cautious while building your ship, to many laser and you will sacrifice cargo space, not enough and you can't fend off dangers.
In truth if you finish the game with a positive dollar amount you have won. Of course there may be others who have more, but I have had at least one game where I didn't even get to finish.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Like my son pointed out, I build spaceships in real life, so I was bound to like this one! :-) And I do, even though realtime games aren't normally my thing. (There isn't too much realtime pressure in this one.) The voyages provide a narrative that's entertaining, and there is a lot of cheering & groaning going on by all truckers. Another good sign. The only downside is that this is kind of a computer game done in boardgame format. By that I mean that the cards & dierolls, even the pieces knocked off your ship are "cardboard technology" for processing steps that a computer or videogame does so effortlessly. You see this more in 1970s and 1980s wargames, and here it is in a modern Euro boardgame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Galaxy Trucker is everything I wanted it to be: pure, chaotic fun, and fun even as you watch your shoddily built spaceship fall apart after mishap after mishap. I lost my first game, but had a blast losing -- a hallmark of a great game.

I love that GT is unlike any other game I've ever played. I usually hate real-time games, but the timer system is so well-implemented that it just works perfectly. The change in tone from fun, tense chaos during construction to "Aaaargh!" (but fun) during the flight is also neat, and I like that every game gives you three cracks at building a decent ship.

Toss in the fantastic components I expect from CGE, and this is one hell of a cool package.

My group had mixed reactions to switching from the basic rules to the full rules for round two; one player in particular really hated the game after that. I like the full rules, many of which look like they'll shine after a few runs when you know what you're doing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like the "building space ship" part... then going through the racing part is secondary for me.. Im an engineer.. so do love putting the pieces together making my ship.. its like lego and then you put it through its paces! brilliant :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
JUEGO CON TEMATICA NOVEDOSA, ATRACTIVO VISUALMENTE POR SUS COMPONENTES Y TABLEROS, RAPIDO DE APRENDER Y MUY FLUIDO.
LO MEJOR, LA DINAMICA DE JUEGO, EN TODO MOMENTO ESTAS ENTRETENIDO, NO TIENES PAUSAS, ES DECIR, LA PRIMERA FASE CUANDO MONTAS LA NAVE, SE HACE TODOS A LA VEZ, Y SI TERMINAS PRIMERO LOS DEMAS SOLO TIENEN DOS MINUTOS (TAMBIEN ENTRETENIDOS VIENDO COMO PIERDEN LOS NERVIOS), Y LA SEGUNDA FASE DEL VUELO, ES TAN DIVERTIDO LAS ACCIONES QUE TE TOCAN A TI COMO A LOS DEMAS.... POR TANTO UN 10 EN ENTRETENIMIENTO.
LO PEOR, CREO Y ESPERO ESTAR EQUIVOCADO, JUGABILIDAD Y ESTRATEGIA. AUNQUE APARENTEMENTE TIENE MUCHAS POSIBILIDADES, PARECE INCIALMENTE QUE HAY POCAS FORMAS DE "PUTEARSE" MUTUAMENTE, AL FINAL LAS TRES VECES QUE HE MONTADO LA NAVE I, HE COLOCADO CASI LAS MISMAS FICHAS.... EN PARTE POR LA ESTRATEGIA.

FINALMENTE CREO QUE ES NECESARIO EN CUALQUIER CASA POR SU TEMATICA DIFERENTE, SU ENTRETENIMIENTO A CUALQUIER NIVEL, Y SU FLEXIBILIDAD DE TIEMPO (UNA NAVES, DOS, TRES....)

LA PUNTUACION ACTUAL SUBIRA SI CONSEGUIMOS LLEGAR A TENER UN CONTROL SOBRE LAS ACCIONES DEL VUELO, QUE PROVOQUE PELEAS POR LA FICHAS Y NAVES REALMENTE DESTROZADAS Y A LA DERIVA.... EN DEFINITIVA UN JUEGO DE TABLERO SI NO HAY COMPETITIVIDAD NO ES NADA.... por muy bonito que sea

RATING: 9
Great tile-based adventure game.  I would not recommend the game for two players, but I would recommend it for small groups of people that have a great sense of humor, and don't mind having their ships blown in half.

I've rated this a 9, but I do not think the base game by itself deserves that.  When combined with The Big Expansion, this game becomes one of my favorites.  The expansion is a must-have because it adds more variability to every aspect of the game: more ships, more encounters, more components, more aliens, and even more game modes.  The best expansion I've ever bought. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
3 / 5 - Good.

Absolute lunacy but highly entertaining. The fairly unique "grab a component" gameplay of ship building does an excellent job of being stressful, brain-burning and enormous laugh-out-load fun all at the same time. The journey afterward is more sedate - sometimes all hell breaks loose and it's great, sometimes no-one interacts with most of the cards and it's a bit dull. The accounting phase right at the end is needlessly fiddly, would benefit from a bit more interaction (but I'm not buying the expansion for the machination cards alone!), and the fact only one person at a time can run through the adventure cards is a shame but these are small blips.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Backordered April 2008
Arrived Dec 2008

My son and and I played a few times and it hit the table once with my game group but...meh...where's the fun?  Lucky for me it has a high trade rating so traded it for an OOP Pro Ludo version of Keythedral still in the shrink.

RATING: 10
2nd best game of 2007 and one of my favorites.
Unique game with very little downtime, you'll be having fun from beginning (frantic speedbuilding phase) to the end (see how badly your ship will suffer). Replayability is decent with basegame and great with expansions. The expansion tiles can be hard to teach to newbies though, so it suffers a little from same problem as Space Alert.. best fun will be had with players of same skill level who explore the game together. Still it's a 10. It's a classic.

Expansions:
+Galaxy Trucker: Big Expansion
+Galaxy Trucker: Another Big Expansion
+Galaxy Trucker: Rough Road Ahead
+Galaxy Trucker: Latest Models
+Even-Steven Cards & Bonus Cards

2-Player Comment:
*Galaxy Trucker is great 2-player game. The fun scales well. Remember to follow rulebook recommendation and remove random handful of tiles when playing with expansions to keep it tight.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In this game, players simultaneously flip over tiles showing ship components and add them to their ship to create the ship most likely to survive the challenges of deep space travel with the most goods/rewards, then watch together as event cards are flipped that reward players with the most guns/people/rockets, or threaten to destroy your ship before the paint has even dried.
Despite the hype, I don't care for this game, and for several reasons. First, players familiar with the game have a huge advantage in anticipating events (based on their unbalanced knowledge of the event cards) and building a more appropriate ship (based on their unbalance knowledge of the tiles) that survives the event cards and reaps better rewards than players who are not familiar with the cards and tiles. This leads to my second complaint, which is that this game suffers from "get in the lead, stay in the lead" syndrome. If you fall behind or get one (or more) stroke of bad luck, you are done. I got hit with "stardust" in rounds 2 & 3 (solely because I was unaware of this card and its consequences), which moves you back 1 space for each exposed connection, and moved back about 10 spaces and out of competetition both of the last 2 rounds... nobody could even pretend that I had a chance. So, for 2/3 of the game I had to sit back and watch the others play as I could not even dream of competing, but yet I continued to also suffer negative consequences of some of the event cards, thus adding insult to injury. I felt like a Galaxy Trucker pinata. If I had been eliminated from the game entirely, I may have maintained a shred of dignity. But alas, the game refused to release it's death grip on me and I was forced to continue "playing", if you could call it that. 
A game that can do that to a player and end with scores ranging from 99 to 0 (which ours did) is broken.
I don't mind games with player elimination... I just want to know ahead of time that that is a risk in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good fun here.  A two-part game of prepping your ship, then taking it through a space ride.

Simple and easy for most, but experienced players will have a big advantage.

Rules are a little corny, but OK.

We play without being able to look at the adventure cards ahead of time.  I think it's more fun in the card reveals, but it does increase the random factor a bit, as far as constructing your ship (you have to be prepared for anything.)  I might try revealing maybe 1/3-1/2 of the adventure cards before ship assembly (just face up for everyone) to see if that skews fighting over certain ship components.  More in-fighting is good.  :-)

The space trips can be very anti-climatic or incredibly brutal.  I've seen how someone could initially be really bored or really frustrated.

So, a good, fun, light game with not a lot of player interaction and game depth.  High sugar content, but not long lasting nourishment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
played a few times, always fun, tad expensive 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: Race to grab pieces from the junk-tile pile to piece together a ship. When time runs out fly your ship across the galaxy and see if it holds up to the random card events along the way.

Played as: 2,4 player

Pros: Nice sturdy game with a fun look and conceptual-draw to it. The building part of the game is the main draw and shines more with a greater number of players as parts are more tightly contested and grabbing can become fiercely competitive. A unique experience for sure.

Cons: I really wanted more player interaction. Instead this game brings an attitude of wanting to live in my own little world only to have it become annoying when others invade it. The flying of the ships is slow and clunky compared to the excitement of building. While not essential, it would be nice to feel like I was piloting the ship more, but really it felt closer to slowly going along for the ride. There's a juxtaposition in the game in that I believe it's supposed to be taken lightheartedly but still has a scrappy competitive nature. I believe that sets some people off as it's hard to watch all your tightly contested effort flutter away into inevitability. Plus some people just suck at building ships. It's hard to explain to beginners "sorry your ship sucked too bad and is un-flyable at this point, so you'll have to sit and watch for the rest of this round" and expect them to want to continue playing.

Other: Chalk me up as another person who really wanted to love this game (and still do) but came up a little disappointed so far. It just didn't hold the tension I wanted eather in games with less players or during the flying portion period. It's certainly unique enough that I'd be happy to explore the game more and may change my tune over-time.

Best Use: Non-competitive players and uncompromising control-freaks need not apply. Better with more players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my gateway games. There is a lot of luck in this game with the events and it does feel like you are just grabbing for pieces and throwing your ship into space. I do hate the fact that I am very slow in grabbing tiles. I have one friend that grabs all the engines/missiles and the other that grabs all the batteries/missiles, so I feel that your ship can suffer from this. You could view what events are coming to counter the randomness. Only reason I am giving this game a 7 is because of the dexterity needed to grab tiles as fast as possible, though the rating could go up if I give the game a few more plays and find a way to counter the players I play against.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Chaotic game that's sorta fun but a lot of frustrating.  I can see that a lot of people really dig this game but it didn't seem to mesh with how my brain works to well.  I understood what was going on but couldn't compete.  There's basically two parts to the game: 1) build a ship 2) survive adventure through space trying to collect the most income.

The first part of the game is much like Factory Fun.  There are a ton of tiles turned face down and you frantically pull tiles and try to add them to your ship in a reasonable way.  These include shields, cabins for crew, lasers and power supplies.  There are placement rules and I had a tough time remembering them all.  Also, I'm just not to quick when it comes to optimizing for an adventure I know nothing about.

After the ship-building phase you venture off to space.  Cards are flipped and something happens.  Depending on how your ship is built you get points or parts of your ship are blown to pieces.  The second part of the game is virtually programmed by the first part so just sit back and cross your fingers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/617350/im-so-glad-i-got-insurance]Galaxy Trucker Review: I'm so glad I got insurance[/url]

I really enjoy playing this, I just wish I could get it to the table more often.  I think the biggest thing affecting that is that I got several other good games right at the same time as this one.

My favorite part of Galaxy trucker is the first phase.  The game is played in 3 rounds, each round your ships get bigger, the flight is longer, and the danger (as well as rewards) is greater.  The first phase is where you build your ship.  There are a bunch of tiles containing the parts to use for your ship in the middle of the table, and it is an all out free-for-all as people grab parts and build their ships.  You need cabins for crew, canons to shoot with, shields for defense, cargo holds for goods, batteries to power, rockets to fly, etc.

After your ship has been built it is time to inspect it.  If you have parts that weren't connected properly those places have to come off, and you can't replace them.  You also get penalized at the end of the flight for these parts.

After inspection it is time to fly.  The randomly drawn cards determine what will happen on the flight.  Pirates might attack (leaving you loot if you can beat them), meteors will strike, there will be planets to trade with, combat zones, etc.  If you have built your ship well you should survive and come back with a lot of cargo on hand, but if you built your ship poorly it can be blown to bits, with cargo floating off into space, crew members being left behind, etc.

On return you are awarded money based on what order you came back, the "best looking" ship will get some bonus points, and everybody gets paid for the cargo they have.  Of course the worst part is paying back the company for all those parts that got blown off during the flight.

I gave this game a 7 mostly because of the randomness to it.  I generally don't like random elements, but it is so much fun to build your ship that it overcomes the randomness.  Also, while building, you can see 3/4ths of the cards that will be in the flight, so that helps you build your ship in a way that maximizes your points.  This isn't a serious game that will get those hard core gamers excited, but it is a lot of fun to play and I wouldn't get rid of this one.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 3-4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Played once. The game lasts for three rounds; at the start of each round players build a ship that they hope can survive the numerous negative events that get thrown at them later in the round. 

I find the ship building element of this game to be very stressful: a number of possible ship tiles are placed upside down on the table, and then all players simultaneously select tiles to add to their ship. When doing this, players must choose one tile at a time, turn it over and look at the tile and decide whether they want in their ship. If they do want the tile in their ship, they must immediately place into their ship, and this placement is permanent. If they don't want it in their ship, they must place it face up on the board, so that any other player may take it (or they may take it later too). Complicating matters are that the tiles must connect to all other tiles, and of course all the tiles don't actually make legal connections to each other. Given that this ship construction is limited in time by other players (once one player is finished all other players have a minute left). I find it difficult to make the best decisions, and often find myself making mistakes (e.g. thinking that I have two pieces that interconnect, but they don't actually). Given that making the wrong connections or having sub optimal ships is punished harshly, this gets frustrating.

Once the ships are built, the game turns into a giant round of somewhat random "take that." Players turn over cards that have some good events (getting cargo, which gives you victory points), but which more than likely are negative events (getting attacked, etc.).  Negative events can be extraordinarily harsh, leading to the destruction of large parts of your ship (which can create a positive feedback cycle that leads to very negative scores and players being eliminated from the round).  Players do have the ability to look at some of these cards while building their ships, but given that ship construction was so stressful I never found myself able to do this.

There is also no shortage of rules, which ends up slowing down the gameplay significantly (as players try to figure out exactly how various cards are resolved or specific damage to a ship is dealt with).

If this game took less than an hour to play, the above frustrations (stressful ship construction, overly complicated rules, possibility of elimination, and random "take that" mechanics) would be fine, but it takes multiple hours to fight through all of it.  

I'd be willing to try this again, but unless it speeds up significantly I don't foresee this game being worth investing the hours to play it each time.

[update: After thinking about the game more, I wonder if simply removing the time limit on ship construction might help the game a lot.  You'd still have the stress of missing out on good ship parts (as other players picked them), so would want to go fast, but wouldn't be worried about being screwed by time.]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.6
Galaxy Trucker is a thrilling adventure:  first, you outfit your ship in a hectic, real-time race against other players and a sand-timer.  Then you captain your hastily-built masterpiece through the chaotic and hostile depths of the galaxy - where it is bombarded by asteroids, boarded by pirates and slavers, caught in the crossfire of cosmic warfare, plagued by space dust and subject to all kinds of abuse.  Also along the way you visit unknown planets, pick up and trade exotic trade goods, explore abandoned ships and starports and cruise the milky way!   Both parts of the game are funny and cinematic.  This game is great fun in it's own oddball way -- which is neither strategic nor tactical.

(Includes Expansion 1)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
+2 The 'racing to build a ship' mechanic is novel, adds a 'skill' element, and is very fun. 

+1 Timer/die/events all add different levels of tension. Makes the game feel varied and eventful. 

+1 Limited batteries/event cards allow for some meaningful decisions post-launch. Adds a layer of strategy over the skill-elements. Feels like you can affect your fate. A little.  

+.5 Light, playful theme done well - but it's not built into the mechanics. Could reskin this as a boat game/cowboy game/post-apoc game and it would play the same. 

+.5 Lots of stuff in the box, for the price. But, components aren't amazing. Wood blocks for cargo, crew are one step up from meeple. I like the energy pips though, and the ship boards are nice. 

+.5 accessible for beginners, despite it taking a while to teach. 

-.5 limited player interaction... but cards introduce some. 

-.5 Dying randomly, suddenly and without recourse is par for the course. Mitigated by rounds and light theme though. 

-.5 Artwork is mostly functional but 'plain'... Cartoony style + open ended dramatic theme = lots of untapped potential for cool art. 

-.5 perfectionists/power-gamers tend to hate the 'Inevitability imperfect ship'. Builds tension but drives some players insane. 

-5. Heavy enough game. Lots of components, setup and a "Takes a play-through to 'get' it" learning curve. Rewards with strategy, but not a disproportionate amount. 

-.5 Rule book. Tutorial style. OK for first play-through, bad for reference. includes flavor text among rule explanations - so needlessly confusing at times it seems deliberate. 

-1 3 rounds can get repetitive. More could've been done to provide variety (e.g. themed instead of graded decks) 

A fun, fast, frantic game with lots of nail biting and catastrophic losses... once you get past the learning curve. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Mit Galaxy Trucker geht es ab in den Weltraum, denn die Spieler verkörpern 8wie der Name schon sagt), waschechte Weltraum-Frachtführer. Doch dafür benötigt man zuerst einmal ein Raumschiff. In Echtzeit müssen die Spieler aus den verschiedensten Teilen, ihr Raumschiff zusammen stellen. Dabei gibt es unglaublich viel zu beachten: Laserwaffen schützen gegen Piraten, Schilde gegen Meteoriten, ein schneller Antrieb kann auch nicht schaden und die Crew braucht natürlich auch Platz..achja und bei einem Transportschiff sollte auch genügend Frachtraum zur Verfügung stehen. In der zweiten Phase muss sich das soeben zusammen gebaute Schiff dann beweisen und gegen allerlei Widrichkeiten bestehen. Am Ende jeder Runde gibt es dann Siegpunkte. Galaxy Trucker macht eine Menge Spaß, wenn man auf das Echtzeit-Raumschiff-Bauen abfährt. Ich hatte auch schon Spieler dabei, die mit dieser mechanik absolut nichts anfangen konnten. Denn Abseits davon, hat Galaxy Trucker keinen taktischen Tiefgang. Alles weitere ist nämlich dem Zufall überlassen. Trotzdem ein spaßiges Spiel.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great game for about 3-4 plays.  After that you've experienced all you're ever going to with the base game (the expansions may help add some longevity).  There is only so many times you can build a spaceship before you play it on autopilot.  The game is also in my opinion one round too long meaning it can sometimes drag on.  Especially when it soon becomes clear who's going to win. 

Great idea that is executed very well.  Unfortunately there's just not enough game here to keep me coming back to it.  The app is better and plays in a fraction of the time.

RATING: 8.5
Kisgyerekként imádtam legózni, sok-sok űrhajó épült a készletemből. Kicsit ez az érzés fogott el, amikor először játszottam vele! Azóta is imádom, de nehéz vele összehozni egy partit, családom lány tagja valamiért nem annyira szeretik, mint én a fiammal. :(

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I can see from the thematic point of view why so many people might enjoy this, and I do enjoy the theme and idea immensely. Just a shame it feels like I could play it 100 times and still never get any better at it then the people that are already 50 games ahead of me.

What does it feel like when I play? Rush to blindly grab the ship pieces with everyone else and cobble them together as quickly as possible so you aren't left with 1/8th of a ship when the better players have finished, then sit and watch the game play itself  for 20 minutes. Repeat two more times.

I feel like every element of GT is completely out of my control, and as a result often finish each session with a sensation of mental frustration and stress.

It also has the worst kind of player elimination- one where rather then you being out and out you must still continue to play, even though both you and all other players know that the best possible comeback will not catch you back up.

One of its best saving features is that one of its copious expansions has made handicapped boards for more experienced players as a way of equaling the balance between them and less experienced- this has saved the game for me, as I can now play and enjoy GT much more against the owners of the game and still feel like I actually have a chance of winning!

I love the theme and idea, but its damn frustrating!

Additional note- the mobile device version of Galaxy Trucker is an incredible implementation of the board game. It introduces alternative play styles and a single player campaign. Its very addictive and has vastly improved my attitude towards this game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic game of chaos and destruction. In fact the more destruction the better...even when it is you. 

The game is split into 2 key phases...building your space trucky/ship and then seeing what events cross your path and seeing if it can stay in one piece.

The building is done in real time against all other players, so their is competition for ship parts and this lends the game its frantic/anxiety building nature. Every component has its place from lasers and shields to cargo bays and life support systems.

This game is really about the laughs that take place at people's misfortunes. Somewhere around the 10 game mark players gain a level of understanding when it comes to building a ship and that can make it hard for newbies to compete and the mishaps go down considerably due to good ship design.

This makes the 1st expansion a must if you want to go past the 20 play mark and beyond.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Junkyard Wars, the game! Or at least, that's what it feels like. There are two parts to the game, one where you build your ship, and one where you fly it (and watch it fall apart). Can be frustrating to new players, but the humor inherent in the game often makes up for any hard feelings. Very fun with experienced players, and expansions provide additional rules to make the game more interesting and more replayable.

The game definitely favors more experienced players, but expansions provide handicaps to help balance player experience levels.

Ship building in real time is great fun as some people obsess over having the "prettiest ship" or "all the guns" (regardless of which way they face) or just finish as fast as possible.

Two house-rules suggested for introducing new players to the game: remove the construction timer for all phases (not just the first one), and if they have invalid tile placements in their ship when they're finished, have them remove tiles as damage until their ship is valid like usual, but then let them, if they want, forfeit their placement token (or not, whatever) to return to construction to fix the holes this leaves in their ship. Basically, let them make the ship they want and see how it goes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Galaxy Trucker is a game where you are handed a ship that consists of empty blocks that you must fill in with chits that portray cargo areas, rockets, engines, living quarters, and other things.  After you and your friends build your ship you take it through space for a race.  While the race is going on things appear out of the deck such as meteors, space pirates, and many other events that will effect the outcome of the race and your ship as a whole.

I love this game and cannot wait to play it a few more times.  Last time I played my ship got demolished and I never had more fun!

RATING: 7
A game that is super fun the first time but loses a bit on subsequent plays -- it gets repetitive. The combination of phases, first a Mondo-like free-for-all shipbuilding phase followed by a series of events to test your newly built ship, is brilliant in concept and provides for a broad game-playing experience (2 games in one!)  
The delightful manual lays out a "test flight" scenario that's perfect for teaching -- highly recommend doing this before playing a real game with new players.
-----
Upping the rating a bit -- playing with 4 players and minimal explanation makes the game more enjoyable.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
You first build a spaceship and then encounter some events and must try to a) keep ship in one piece b) collect goods & cash. The building part is done simultaneously in realtime fashion. Everyone takes pieces from the same pool but if you don't like the piece then others have chance to use it. You can reserve pieces but if you cannot later place them onto your ship then you're penalized. The little problem here is that some are fast and good at this and some slow and bad. That means that with some groups game isn't really fair. But if there is enough randomness and more importantly fun while playing that it hasn't mattered in my playing groups yet.

You can build spaceships in different fashions and depending on the events (and their order) the others are better than others. Because you're allowed to look through most events you can have idea of which way to build. Problem is that the time going through events is taken away from your building time. After few games it feels that cannons might be a bit too powerful overall, hard to say.

This is a very good and especially fun game to play. Sometimes you can get through events without a scratch (if you've build your ship well!) and the other times you have half of your ship left when the round is over. For some reason it seems that I'm usually in the latter group... but still enjoying the game a very much. A very fun game where space ship building skills are needed but there is so much luck involved too that you just might get lucky with not-so-elegant designs as well.

The game works great with 2-4 players but it's better with 3 or 4 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The strategy here is pretty simple.  Its a quick puzzle building game.  Loads of hilarity.

As quick as you can, find the ship parts you need and put them in the right place.  To have a better idea of what events are coming, you can take the time to review up to 75% of the upcoming events (the remaining 25% are random).  You want to be the first to finish your ship if at all possible. People who finish last are less likely to get the best rewards.

I own the iOS app and while its no substitute for the board game, its fun.

RATING: 1
Puzzle
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
David
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This mixes a frantic and sometimes highly competitive stage of building your ship in a timed session with a racing stage where a deck of event cards determines how rich you and your crew will be after that stage. You then get to do it all over again!

The timed shipbuilding stage is a puzzle game where every player is going into the same pile of tokens at the same time trying to build a ship that has it all, but hopefully doesn't fall apart enroute. You need to make sure that all the connections line up or you will lose that piece before the race stage even begins. The order players finish their trucks determines which order they start the race in. To me, this is the funnest part of the game with the potential for some blocking elbows and cringing faces of dismay trying to find some piece that will get the ship to hold together. 

The second phase is where players race around a board based on event cards. The ships are in order and that order determines who gets to play an action on that card first such as grabbing goods from planets, charging the engines up, fighting off pirates, or dodging asteroids. At the end of this phase, whatever corporation runs the show pays you for the goods, gives you a reward based on what position you finished, and another reward for the best looking ship. 

I will say that the game is a blast with the typical learning time of around 20-45 minutes, though the instructions are wise enough to have a starter mission for first-timers. There is that element present in many Victory Point games at the end where one player wins 36 to 35 points and no one can quite figure out what the secret winning move was. It's almost as if you just need to be near the front of the pack and hope that lady luck shines on you. This isn't a detraction from the game per se and maybe it's even why we play games; you just won't walk away with a victory with the full knowledge that your superior self bested everyone based on expert tactics and strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesome game that I will play almost any time it is available.

RATING: 5

RATING: 6
[b]Galaxy Trucker[/b] was traded away for Firenze 3/26/14.

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (6):[/COLOR]

[i]I realized recently that the expansion killed this game for me. It added way to many rules/mechanics with very little pay out. I actually enjoyed the base game and I am now looking for a copy (mostly because my son loves this game). I finally picked up another copy for my son and have enjoyed some plays of it. Still not a game I'm clamoring to play, but it is much better without the expansion we had (which was the second one).[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (7.5):[/COLOR]

[i]First couple of games were shaky, lots of rules to remember. I thought this was going to end up being a poor purchase decision, but even though my kids ships are getting trashed they still want to play. Also this has been the worst game, by far, to punch out all the cardboard chits. Even when using a razor blade I still had a few pieces tear.

I think this is a fun family game, my kids really enjoy playing. They love building things (hence our huge collection of legos) and this game offers them a chance to do that. My daughter Madeline (who just turned 8) can hold her own. Her ships are not always as well built, but she has won because she always builds ships with tons of storage. They both handle it well when parts of their ship are destroyed, we usually have a good laugh. I would recommend this as a good family game, especially if your kids love to build things.[/i]

RATING: 8.5
By far one of the most unique games I have played in a while. I sold it to my wife by calling it space Carcasconne but that is not entirely accurate. It actually feels like a board game adaptation of the hit computer game Faster Than Light. It has a tile laying aspect. But what i think really works about this game is its intuitiveness. Its funny how all of Vlaada's games remind me of some computer game or another.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
Wow! Totally impressed with this game! Build your ship...as best you can...as quick as you can...and with the most components that you will need for your space mission! That's it really...then you are sent into space...maybe your ship will hold together...maybe not! And for your hard work...you might earn just a few galactic cents...gotta love that bit! The base game is nice, but you will really need the big expansion to make the game really complete! I'm sorry to say...you will have to shell out some more cash for the expansion...but you will outgrow the base game far too quickly...you will need more challenges. This is where the expansion will come in handy! You see...every time you introduce new players, you will need the base game...but you the experienced player will need to have more challenges to even the playing field! That's why you will have to do it! No no...you must!

I find that most peoples complaints about this game is the timer and how it prevents you from building a really complete ship. I do believe that this game is meant to be a fun yet devastating romp in space, where you go in with a somewhat dilapidated ship and you see if you can earn a few galactic cents from the journey through the complete luck of the draw of cards. If you know going in that you probably won't survive the trip, I think it helps ease the tension of trying to build a perfect ship for winning.

RATING: 7.5
心得:
都在玩APP，還蠻好玩的
策略點主要在知道這次會遇到什麼狀況後
在去選擇如何拼湊自己的太空船
但是抽到版塊順序很運氣，還要競速
然後探險也很多運氣成分
整體而言是機制特別，但是算比較運氣的遊戲
規則:
1.抽版塊要過圖版才能翻面，拼湊從起始往外拼
2.引擎只能對後面，砲口前面不能有版塊，隔一塊可以
3.沙漏機制是漏玩每個人都可以隨時翻面，時間到就要停止
4.違規版塊要拆掉 且要扣錢，保留版塊沒用也扣錢
5.不是往前面的砲口，算武力時要除二
6.大隕石要用砲彈打掉，左右的砲可以加打上下兩格
7.小隕石不能是缺口，不能用砲打掉，可用護盾檔
8.小爆炸只能用護盾檔，大爆炸一定掉

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Currently at the very top of my list of "games my wife asks to play." So much fun. This was my second-ever realtime game (first being Space Hulk), and it immediately sent me into a lovefest for all things Vlaada. 

Really smart design, the puzzle-building is rewarding, and the theme is light enough that it's not so awful to watch your ship get torn apart during the actual mission. And this will happen! If you're not on board with having your ship destroyed *for fun*, you won't enjoy this game. 

Honestly I think the game only becomes really enjoyable after you've dialed in your ship-building skills. Then at least you're not feeling so invested when the asteroids and space pirates come along and blow you away.

RATING: 4
"WAY too long for what it is (both of my plays have run 90-120 minutes). Silly ship assembly followed by drawn-out random sillyness. I would rather play a 'real' game (or 2 or 4) in the same amount of time."

What I liked:
- Goofy fun
- Creative and unusual design

What I didn't like:
- High randomness
- Too many small rules
- Tile design could have been much clearer
- Runs way too long (90-120 minutes) for such a random game

It's all in good fun, but I see it as more of a time-passer than a strategic game. As a 30-minute game, I would probably enjoy it. But at 90-120, it just feels like a huge waste of time, during which we could have played a "real" game. 

Initial rating of 5 lowered to 4 after my second play. 

There are a lot of little rules (this only activates if it is next to that, but these can be anywhere; this turbo destroys its thing but that doesn't), which for me pushes the weight well above the 2.3 BGG rating. I would say more like 2.6.

RATING: 8
This game is really enjoyable but incredibly chaotic. With the game being broken into two rounds you have one where you race to construct your ship and then another where you take your ship into the dangerous final frontier.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Un gioco fresco, leggero, originale (caratteristica primaria delle creazioni di Vlaada Chvatil) e molto sottovalutato: per me è il gioco del 2007. Si ride con gli altri e degli altri, mentre gli altri ridono di te. Le regole sono facilissime da spiegare a quelli che non giocano mai ai giochi da tavolo. La prima volta che ho letto le divertentissime istruzioni (scritte come la Guida Galattica di Douglas Adams) ero perplesso dalla costruzione della nave: azione contemporanea, asimmetrica, caotica, governata dal culo e con poco tempo a disposizione. Poi l'ho provata e mi sono ricreduto: è il modo più divertente di giocare, con l'ambientazione che giustifica questo tipo di svolgimento (i disgraziati frugano tutti insieme in un magazzino, alla disperata ricerca di pezzi da attaccare al carrozzone che li porterà a destinazione). La seconda parte è ben pensata (e il fatto che si compiano tre viaggi alza il morale agli ultimi, che possono rifarsi), con gli eventi che coinvolgono tutti (e quelli del terzo viaggio sono davvero pesanti da risolvere). Mi è piaciuto il sistema che gestisce l'ordine di arrivo, e la qualità degli eventi casuali. Anche il viaggio è governato dal culo, ma puoi limitarlo sbirciando il 75% degli eventi durante la costruzione della nave (e realizzare qualcosa di adatto alle situazioni che ti si pareranno davanti). Inoltre, una nave ben costruita evita una buona parte dei guai che possono capitarti durante il viaggio. Un difetto? L'esperienza fa fare astronavi migliori, e in una partita tra giocatori con esperienza variabile, difficilmente la lotta sarà all'ultimo credito. Un altro difetto? Dopo un po', c'è il rischio che tutti conoscano tutte le carte evento a memoria (ma per questo, c'è l'espansione). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Build your ship out of junk and race through the galaxy!!! Fun game, with nicely designed pieces. There is a certain guilty satisfaction in watching your opponents ship fall apart because of a loose connection or a badly-placed meteor :)
Only real drawback is that experienced players have a massive advantage over new players - the race to build your ship is a lot easier when you know what to look for! This can be ameliorated by introducing a handicap - unfortunately, I don't know if the rules suggest a good way of doing this, as my version is in German!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Galaxy Trucker is a very bizarre game for me. The first few games I absolutely loved it. My ship was being torn to pieces, we were all groaning the entire time and it just felt like an uphill battle. A few games later and the base game became very boring. It's WAY too easy to do well once you have ~6 plays under your belt. We were often left with little to no damage to our ship and it became who could build a better ship overall in a shorter amount of time. Blech.

I will say though, adding in the first expansion really brings this game back to it's roots for me. I feel like it's essential to make the game interesting again.

Includes the Even Steven cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very original game: players have to simultaneously grab tiles from a common pile and use them to build a ship. Then they must take it on a journey full of dangers. A good ship will be prepared to deal with all the threats and get away without a scratch in the paint. A bad ship will be literally teared apart. 

When I first heard about Galaxy Trucker I was put off by the simultaneous/timed aspect of the gameplay. However after playing it I was conquered! The game is just so much fun! The building phase is tense and engaging while the travel phase is fun and chaotic. 

Experience is really important and even though there's a fair amount of randomness present the better players will win easily against newbies.

I had some concerns about replayability but I'm almost at 10 plays without any signs of getting tired. I have the expansion but I still haven't opened it yet.

One word game review :- FUN!

Build your spaceship as best you can and then watch it all get blown away. If you're lucky you've built a stable and sturdy machine and you'll land at your destination brimming with goods, on the other hand you end up drifting in space with no toilet roll.....

The game manual is the best I've ever read, well written, very amusing (think Hitch Hikers guide to the Galaxy) and seems to cover all you need to know to get up and running quickly.

Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
To start, Galaxy Trucker is my kind of game.  It's got the right mixture of planning, chance, interaction, 'bit love', excitement, and just plain fun and the only complaint is that the game doesn't sit 6.. (but it could with an expansion ... nudge, nudge, wink, wink)

The skinny on the rules: Galaxy Trucker is played in three rounds, each round consisting of a 'ship building' phase, followed by a 'ship flying' phase.

In the ship building phase, players compete to build ships on player board with carcassonne-like squares following some basic assembly rules.  Players will want to ensure that their ship has adequate guns, adequate thusters, adequate shields, adequate storage (for stable and unstable goods), adequate shelter for both human and alien crew, and finally batteries to run the whole thing.  Of course, there's typically only enough space to safely address a few of these needs.

In the second half, players take their newly built ships and contend with increasingly difficult and increasingly longer missions to earn money.  How do you earn money?  Mostly by landing on planets and getting goods, then selling them at the end of the run.  Alternatively, you can get money by killing pirates or slavers, or by sacrificing crew on an abandoned space ship.

In short: Again, I think this is a fantastic game.  There are many many components and CGE uses the four basic game foodgroups to make their pieces: plastic, wood, glass and cardboard.  I don't think I could ever turn down a game of Galaxy Trucker (fondly called 'Space Truckin' around here).

It will be interesting to see the Rio Grande reprint.  I'd be surprised if the reprint has the same kind of components.. but I also think that this game is in good hands with Rio Grande.  It's the kind of game that could benefit from several expansions, and I'll bet that Rio Grande is more than happy to make it happen if the game continues to be successful.


---
[b]Game Duration:[/b] (Very Short) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Very Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Simple):star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Player Interaction:[/b] (None) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Lots)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (NonGamers) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Theme:[/b] (Cardboard) :star::star::star::star::nostar: (Lush)
[b]Conflict:[/b] (Coop) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Hated Enemies)
[b]Randomness:[/b] (None) :star::star::star::star::nostar: (Chaotic)
[b]Sobriety:[/b] (Judge) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Skunked)
--
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::star::star::star::halfstar: (Worth)
[b]Overall Smilie: [/b]:D
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Well, there might not be much in the way of strategy here, but the fact is that this game is pure FUN. There are many laughs mingled in with the tension...not an easy balance...and I love it that way.

Basically 2 games are present here, but they interlock so beautifully. After setup comes the "Contruct Your Vehicle Puzzle". Put together the tiles of your ship, preferably before your opponents, gathering as much power, speed, and storage as possible, in as tightly and safely constructed a manner as you can, while the sands of time run out on you. A quick check to see if your ship is space-worthy...and if not you will pay some penalties...and you move into the second part of the game, the "Journey Across the Galaxy with Your Ship Made From Sewer Pieces". This consists of piloting your ship across the galaxy, trying your best to avoid Meteroic Showers, Pirates, Slavers, and Epidemics, while also picking up as much cargo as you can, all while trying to keep your ship as intact as possible. Events described above are enacted by card draws and it can truly get to a point where each draw becomes tension filled as your ship flies apart event by event. 

My rating represents, first and foremost, the "Fun Factor", but also the fun graphic design, the lovely bits (Especially love the Tic Tac batteries), the nicely meshed mechanics that drive the game forward, AND the very funny rule book. 

This game is not for everyone, clearly, as others have written, but it is definitely for me. Great stuff.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
good real time game.  fun to watch the your ship blow up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a frenetic, fast-paced game with a trading pit atmosphere when you're building your ships. This can be a lot of fun with the right crowd, and the rules are structured very well to allow the amount of time your group would like to take. Watching your ship get assailed by the adventure cards during your trucking experience is a lot of fun, even when you're getting the short end of the stick.

One caveat is that this game needs equally experienced folks. Otherwise you should use the team play option to make the game more balanced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A game of 2 halves, and both of them play brilliantly.

The frantic ship building is just challenging enough to stay interesting without becoming over-taxing, and there always seems to be someting you know you could do better next time.

Then, the journey itself follows, which is sometimes hilarious, always gripping, as you will your ship to survive to the end! There are also a few (important) decisions to be made here, such as whether to dispatch crew for points/credits, or jostling for position on the track, etc. So it doesn't actually just feel like you're along for the ride.

The game as a whole runs about the right length for what it is, but the (excellent) rules even give some ideas for how to adapt the game for shorter/longer timescales, for partnership play, etc.

The components are great, and the box is (for once!) actually the right size for the contents.

The only slight drawback of the game is that there are quite a lot of concepts to explain to new players. But, again, the rulebook ingeniously contains a section which guides you through an introductory game with trimmed-down rules - however there is still a lot to take in for a novice gamer.

OWN: 1st Edition (Czech Games Edition)
NOTE: 2ND EDITION DUE LATE 2008 has improved components (everything but the glass & plastic bits).

UPDATE 2015-01-21...
NOW OWN: 2nd Edition (Rio Grande Games) - along with all expansions! Had to re-purchase newer edition because expansions weren't fully compatible (many changed components).

RATING: 9
[b]Galaxy Trucker[/b]: ˈgæləksi ˈtrʌkər
[i]n.[/i]

1. Awesome fun times
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Although I haven't played Factory Fun, I guess I would be right in saying this game is what happens when FF meets Starship Catan. I like puzzle aspect and the tense race to perfect a ship in the first phase of a round. But I really, really do not like the second phase where you fly your ship through a card scripted adventure (as in Starship Catan). This part of the game is fiddly, dull but most of all can be really destructive, which is where most of the "fun" lies. It is like an '80s design and made me feel as if I was building a sand castle before the tide comes in , only to get someone to walk through it. Now I'm not against Schadenfreude (I even laugh hysterically when I think of my mate being sick on a fishing trip) but I think I dislike it in Galaxy Trucker because I exercise my mind and effort in construction, only to have my creation crushed. 

Update: I needed to play a second game as first play with 3 seemed flat as there was no real competition for ship building as it was fairly easy to have no exposed connectors. So the next game with 4 saw alot of damage and some fun with thte ships breaking apart bigtime. I also concerned that an experienced leader can get too much of an advantage.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Reminds me of Factory Fun a little bit. The grabbing of tiles, the timer, and the dice rolling make the game less appealing for me. The required visual quickness in the game favors players with that natural and innate ability, as is the case in the game of "Set".  But I think repeated plays drastically improves the speed of tile assessment and better and more efficient tile placements. Review is after only one play.

-

RATING: 9.89
This is what happens when you merge a light-strategy game with party games, and the result is beautiful. You want the most points, and you want the best built ship possible to go racing round the galaxy, but take too long in building your ship and you risk it being left behind in the dust as your opponents take the parts you need and leave you with a withered skeletal construction. Be too hasty in your ships construction and you risk it falling apart on launch. Either way it's always tremendous fun trying to cobble your ship together and connect up all the parts of the ship before time runs out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Galaxy Trucker is amusing to play, puzzle with random results.

The first phase you are assembling your ship contraptions as you try to match up tiles to build out from a central core with things like engines, guns and completed sides to the outside While you have crew cabins, energy pods, cargo holds somewhere in the ship. 
The use of a timer to control this aspect of the game makes for the needed urgency to complete the build phase.

The second phase is when you face the random dangers of the galaxy with things like planets to get goods, abandoned ships to take for money or get goods, pirates, slavers (which seem to be too strong), war zones to get through and of course the ever present meteors. 
The cards have the direction from where the meteor or hit will come. The ships are built on grids which use dice to determine the location of the hit. Your decisions if any is to determine when to power you engines, guns and shields and if you want to take advantage of opportunities on the way at the cost of time.
The first goal of this "race" is to survive, with the added benefits to be the leader and picking up trade goods along the way. Being in the lead is a mixed blessing yes you get first crack and the good stuff, but you also get first crack at the bad stuff as well.
This part of the game pretty much plays itself, the amusement comes from watching your creation fall apart from the damage. This is game where you have to enjoy watching what happens to you and the other players - it is best played with a sociable group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nothing's more fun than creating a pristine ship with no exposed connectors only to have it blown to pieces by pirates!  This game is a great time, especially in a non-competitive crowd that's looking more for a good time rather than winner take all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
player interaction is great. Not a very hard game to play. Only real disadvantage is that playing with beginners there is a big gap between your pace in building and theirs. Off coarse it's covered in the rules but the switching board doesn't really work. We use to team up and build two ships with one team, everybody flying apart but with communication possible. This makes it fun because it gets more tactical and takes down a little luck.

RATING: 10
This is the real deal. There's nothing else quite like it in board games or video games (though I hear that Faster than Light comes close in the video game department). It is frustrating in that one small building error or one unanticipated event can totally wreck you, but if you accept that possibility then you are in for one wild and awesome ride. My videogamer friends were raving about this one after I showed it to them and talking about making it their first board game purchase. I haven't tested it on nongamers yet, but I fear it might be too intense for them. Gamers who can tolerate chaos and calamity will love it, hands down.

EDIT: I tested it on nongamers, and it was too intense for them. I still highly recommend this for gamers who have any sort of kooky side.

RATING: 7
Zany fun. Real time building of the spaceship is a kind of crazy experience as you madly rush for ship parts that not only fit but are the right types of things that you want on board, all while trying to beat other players who are doing the same. Then you fly these shoddily built things through a series of missions, often to hilarious results with components falling off or getting blasted into oblivion. There is some strategy and plenty of tactics that mean good play is rewarded, but there are also plenty of random elements. If you're looking for a game with some meaningful decisions and a host of zany side effects, this could be great. If you're looking for something very deterministic, stay far away. 

I am not always in the right mood to want to ply this, but when I am this is a great time.

RATING: 9.5
Ship building was exactly what I hoped it would be. Scoring was a bit unintuitive (why do we keep going backwards?) but after a couple plays I had a much better sense of what to expect. Now I know what firepower/crew I'll need to have the best odds of surviving an adventure. Bigger ships are actually easier to build as you can fit more necessities onboard. There was a bit of a learning curve, so I had a LOT more fun with my fourth ship than my first. Definitely a game that rewards multiple plays. Into my Top Ten.

RATING: N/A
The yin/yang of this game is I guess technically in balance, but maybe this is how I learned I simply don't like yang. The first half of this game is fun, frantic, and active. You build your ship and it's fast and wonderful and everyone has a great time. And then the second half is helpless and passive, and I didn't enjoy it nearly as much. I found little to enjoy about sitting there and making very few meaningful decisions. And I get why the passivity exists, thematically, but that doesn't make it fun. Yeah, watching your ship get destroyed technically captures the helpless feeling, but so what? I'd rather do something than nothing. 

I'll probably play it again in a few years. I'd totally own this if the second half of the game were even remotely enjoyable. But it was a lot of rules and fiddle for what was essentially a passive experience. No es bueno. Maybe playing it once instead of three times would be OK? It's not like anyone cares who won anyway.

RATING: 5
I'll rate this a 5 after one play.

I'm told that the first time is the worst time with this game, but my problem was that the game didn't seem random enough.

I'll give Galaxy Trucker kudos for being the most unique game I've played since X-Bugs.

Experienced players seem to build most excellent ships.  Widescale destruction is for the newb.  I was expecting the threats to be bigger and more devestating.

There's acutally quite a bit to think about while turning over cards.  Is it more important to spend time to grab something now or wait until later?  But this seemed more in the realms of the person who was first.  The person in last place sits around waiting for the people in first place to decide what they want to do.

I was expecting more "whiz-bang" out of the game with stuff blowing up all around.  Instead it seemed rather procedural with too few things blowing up.

I would like to try it some more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tile placement with a twist.  Very fun, but it seems you either love it or hate it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
UPDATE: Lowered rating from 7 to 5.

It appears that there's only one ideal way to build your ship that would be able to withstand almost all event cards: Either tiles have a specific place where they should be placed (i.e. lasers always at the front, engines always at the back), or they could be placed anywhere (the rest of the tiles). There really aren't any tough decisions along the lines of putting a specific tile here would give me one advantage, while putting a tile in another place would give me another.

Because of this, there really is only one "solution" to the puzzle at hand, and once you've figured this out (which is easier than it appears despite the large amount of rules for this really light game), then the game becomes a race to see who could find the more important, rare tiles first, and the first to spot how tiles should fit together.

What somewhat mitigates this are huge bonus cards and very nasty events that reward a surplus of one tile over another. But I don't think it doesn't adequately increase the difficulty of the puzzle part of the game for experienced players -- they simply take advantage of the rule of peeking through the event deck and build their ships accordingly.

One other unfortunately flaw is that this game severely punishes beginners (meaning those who have built really bad ships) quite badly. Since this is one of those games that greatly rewards experience, this might give newbies a bad first impression.



===================

Tentative 7.

Cons:
* For a game this light, it has way, way too many components.
* Rules are very, very fiddly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Epicooo! Questo spettacolare gioco spaziale, simpatico e "caciarone", che mi ha fatto scoprire l'autore Ceco: Vlaada Chvàtil e quel geniaccio inesauribile che è, in grado di passare da un genere ad un altro portando sempre innovazione. Infatti dopo anni di giochi che mi sembravano uguali o troppo simili fra loro, finalmente compare qualcosa di diverso e soprattutto divertente, con una componentistica dei materiali (le piccole batterie in vetro a forma di Tic-Tac, sono graziosissime) ed una grafica (incluso il manuale delle regole in stile simpatico e spassoso), che non hanno nulla da invidiare a titoli più blasonati. Sostanzialmente ci sono due fasi di gioco: la prima, in cui ognuno crea la propria astronave assemblando pezzi in lotta contro il tempo, rappresenta infatti un'esperienza impagabile: un'emozione infantile, primordiale, prepotente, vivida, entusiasmante, tirando fuori l'ingegnere meccanico che è in ognuno di noi. Si ride, si grida, si spulcia, si solleva, si scarta, si rubano pezzi da sotto le mani dell'avversario; mentre la seconda, quella del viaggio di esplorazione, in cui ognuno sognerebbe di mettere finalmente alla prova la qualità e la tenuta della propria meravigliosa astronave, assemblata arraffando pezzo dopo pezzo, si traduce in nient'altro che sciagure, dove è un piacere veder volare nello spazio pezzi di navi (altrui!) distrutti e/o sconnessi da meteoriti vaganti e "laserate" di pirati, per farsi delle "grasse" risate! Fino a quando qualche astronave si divide in due pezzi e si cerca di tentare di rientrare alla base con il carico e quel che rimane dello scafo e... allora via a "spanciarsi" dal ridere. Uno dei pochi giochi in cui ci si diverte quando si perde! Il gioco dovrebbe piacere senz'altro a quasi ogni tipologia di persona, peccato che è limitato ad appena quattro giocatori, quando avrebbe potuto senza troppi problemi venire esteso ad almeno cinque.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

received in trade for Atlantis Rising. 4/29/2016.
