=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Galaxy Trucker is like Sci-Fi Carcassonne on meth.  This is not an insult.  Build a ship--fast.  Take it through an obstacle course designed by Satan of the Stars.  Do it over again only the next time, you have to build it bigger and better.

This game rewards people who can laugh at themselves and who don't mind it their whole ship falls apart.  The main problem with this game is that if one or more people build far inferior ships, they can end up sitting around doing nothing while the people with well built ships (i.e. players with experience) play the game.  It's no fun to wait in space dock while everyone else galavants among the stars.  Even so, Galaxy Trucker is awesome; it's sugar coated bliss on a stick.

***Update***

Now that I own Galaxy Trucker, I am convinced of its greatness.  I still really enjoy the frantic shipbuilding aspect, but I've now got a greater appreciation for the flight phase.  There ARE decisions to make in the flight phase.  What kind of cargo do you pick up? Do you leave some of your guys on abandoned ships? do you power all of your engines or cannons?  These are no obvious types of decisions that make the game quite exciting!  The ship building phase is still awesome though.  I love the feeling I get when I've finished my ship and I examine it and realize that I could have built it so much better and smarter.  It's an excited disappointed feeling that makes me smile when I think about it.

***Update***

I've lowered the rating again because Galaxy Trucker is really difficult to teach.  The real-time nature of it (the part that's fun) makes it frustrating to try to bring new people into.

***Update***

My impression of Galaxy Trucker is sliding lately.  I really loved it at first; it was an instant nine.  But the more I play it, the more it starts to feel the same.  Plus I tend to get really sore hunching over the table sorting through pieces, and I invariably get a headache when I play.  While that's not the game's fault, it's started to lessen my desire to play it.  It feels a bit repetitive and while I enjoy the silly fun, it's less cool than I initially thought.  It's gone from being in my top ten to being number 25 on my list, and I'd be willing to guess that it will completely fall out of my top thirty.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I'm really enjoying Vlaada Chvatil's games.  He seems to embrace manufactured chaos, and I seem to enjoy it, so it's a good match ;)  I tend to find that the building aspect of this game is the really fun part, and mostly focus on building the most perfect ship I can, the rest of the game is fun, but kind of tacked on to give purpose to the building part.  This isn't a complaint though, mostly just an observation.  I've been seriously tempted to buy a second copy of the game just to get the extra tiles, since I enjoy having a lot of options available, but I haven't done that yet.  I've played this with more cutthroat players who really push the timer and it's still a lot of fun, but not quite as enjoyeable for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like most Vlaada games, Galaxy Trucker is fantastic. The rulebook is well organized and entertaining. Perhaps the biggest surprise for me was that the game itself isn't actually very complicated and is fast to teach to new gamers. It also plays in a short amount of time.

Perhaps my only complaint is that real-time is a huge part of Galaxy Trucker's charm and it takes a couple games for new players to be less intimidated by it. Experienced players will definitely make less mistakes due to rushing.

Overall: Galaxy Trucker is awesome. Vlaada really is a genius in the way he creates such challenging, sometimes punishing games that I don't mind losing at. Can't help but smile when your ship blows up.

RATING: 7.75
While I find this game a fun play, it doesn't hit the table that much anymore.  The group I play with dislikes the way the ship building phase is designed.  I think the biggest issue is that its very difficult to play with someone of a different skill level (or someone who isn't good at putting a ship together quickly).  Someone who is good at that sort of thing (or more experienced with the pieces) will come out with the best ship and start first.  This leads to frustration from other players as it tends to punish the players who are less familiar with the games pieces (or more prone to analysis) and turn them off to the game.

RATING: 8.8

The second is not time based, but each player will have their ship facing challenges based on cards. I think the time length for this game is perfect (about 1 hour), it just ended at the right time. If you like this you may want to look into expansions, however they may over complicate the game for newer or inexperienced players.

RATING: 9
Great fun.  Fast paced, involving, and intuitive.

You can slap this down on the table with newbies, explain the rules in less than ten minutes, and be having a screaming good time in 15.

And it doesn't matter if you win or lose, it's still fun.  Great big hunks of your spaceship are blasted away, and you're laughing about it!  So you can play in a crowd of disparate skill levels and everyone's having a good time.

Just finishing with a positive score is challenge enough for a newbie.

RATING: 7
So utterly different from everything else Vlaada has done - and indeed from more or less every other boardgame out there - but this still manages to be great fun, even for someone such as me who generally hates real-time games. It's great scrabbling desparately through the pool to try to find more guns/engines/cabins, or the one type of connector that you need - and then see your totally inadequate ship get blown to smithereens in the subsequent phase of play. Definitely a unique game - and not one I'd want to play to death, but still enormous fun.

RATING: N/A
+ Captures the Dwarf Fortress (videogame) philosophy of "Losing is Fun" perfectly
+ Realtime ship construction, in a world of turn based boardgames with the occasional bit of simultaneous actions, it's nice to have a true realtime game in your collection
+ Most laughs from a game by far
+ Ship construction is very intuitive, enjoyable and stressful all at once
+ Family friendly (unless your kids hate seeing their creations crumble and get torn to pieces in front of them)
+ Not strategic but the whole point of this game isn't to be mentally taxing so this is not a con in my mind

- Rulebook could be written in a somewhat more logical order, if you get rules wrong for the first few playthroughs, it is understandable

RATING: 5
Pick up tiles, build a ship - would rather play Factory Fun.  Flip a series of cards for a random encounters - would rather play Diamant.  But combine those two, and the result is greater than the individual parts.  GAnd in this game, that combination just hits the right spot for me.  Not too serious, not too light - a fun game for 4 players.  There is a skill to building a ship to survive the journey - especially when one takes the time to peek at the upcoming adventure cards to be better prepared.  There is also some thought to be had in the adventure phase - do you want to race to the lead and face the risks first?  Or hang back and hope others will shield you.  And it is great fun to watch bits of your ship fall off from the various events.  Don't get too analytical with this one, just enjoy the ride.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Really unique game--both with the real time element and the whole damage removes pieces off of it.

And the rulebook is truly funny.  ;)

RATING: 6
Got to learn this from the publisher at Pionek in Gliwice 2007-12-09.  Real-time turning over tiles and choosing whether to add them to your spaceship grid reminded me a bit of Factory Fun, and sure enough FF was apparently an inspiration for this, which removes the occasional too-long pondering and is much faster moving.  Build your ship with various gadgets hooked together, then everyone flies them on a trade run, suffering various random events.  Despite the wide variety of random events, there is clearly skill in the ship design to attempt to handle the various stuff that can happen during the flight.  It was fun and interesting and had some clever ideas; I would need to play more to be more sure of my rating.

RATING: 8
I feel like I should like this game more than I do.  I enjoy the ship-building part but, despite all of us being new to the game at the same time, there was a definite discrepancy in skill level - and it's no fun playing with people who are frustrated that you can build faster than them.

The actual flight was kind of tedious.  I understand that it's necessary to "evaluate" how well everyone built their ships but it dragged.

I would play this game again - but only with the right group, and I likely wouldn't suggest it even then (as this mythical "right group" would probably play RoboRally with me - and I like that better).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
This game could easily be named Mayhem in Space because that's what seems to happen when we play it. First, each player chooses ship components as quickly as they can from the pile in the middle of the table. Will you add extra crew compartments or lots of engines? How about guns along the front or maybe the sides and rear? And don't forget to add a few cargo bays so you can deliver some goods and earn some cash! It seems like that one ship component you need...was just picked by the player to your right! And that's just the ship building phase. Now head out into deep space as a convoy and do your best to survive all the pirates and meteors and challenges that space has to offer. Lots of interactive fun, especially when you arrive at your destination and your ship is one third the size as when you set out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I wanted to like this game. It sounded like it was right up my alley with chaos and exploding ships.  Then, I experienced the adventure first hand, and thought to myself, "That was it?"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I was very excited about this game, as I enjoy real-time mechanics.  However, this game fell flat. Basically an experienced player can know what the ideal layout is and just quickly reveal and aim for those specific tiles while less experienced players are still trying to figure out a good layout.  I think a tile-drafting desing like 7 Wonders, where you each pass around Scrabble-like trays of tiles and must take and play one tile each turn, would have been a better design.  After that part, the game basically plays itself as you reveal different events and see what happens - boring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Christmas 2007 - inbound from italy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
----------

I love building the ship; I'm an engineer, so puzzles and quick-thinking really appeal to me.  

But, the flight stage is b-o-r-i-n-g... I know that it's supposed to be exciting to see your ship get blown to bits, but i have a LOT more fun building than flying.  Also, I've only ever had one ship that got somewhat destroyed.  I guess the game isn't any fun if your ship never has problems.  

Sure, I could get the expansion to make the flight more difficult, but I don't want to spend money on such a light game.  Furthermore, I've tried enacting some house rules to make the flight more difficult (i.e. every player must announce whether or not they are going to use a batter BEFORE the dice are rolled to resolve where the threat is coming from), but flight still feels like a chore.

Nevertheless, this is a fantastic game for newbies and gateway gamers.  Everyone that I have introduced it to loves it!  It's definitely worth the price for the fun factor, but replayability IS an issue.

RATING: 8
[b]Unique Component[/b] - Not really any unique components.  Mainly just tiles.  There are few odd small bits, but that is not the interesting thing about this game.


[b]Unique Mechanic[/b] - Players are timed to puzzle together a spaceship with the tiles.  Then they must fly those ships through dangerous areas of space in a race to pick-up and deliver goods.



[b]Quick Thoughts[/b] - This game is amazingly simple, yet amazing difficult and fun at the same time.  Great game.  Puzzling together a good spaceship is not as easy as it sounds.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
The Android app is great; I would buy this if I saw it for a great price, but it's not a priority currently as there are other games and the app does quite nicely.  I suspect it will be very different to play in person with a physical copy, however.  

This is a game of fun, frantic scrambling to optimize your ship made of junk, and do your best to deal with random hazards.  These hazards, drawn from a deck, will surely upset some of the gamers who make it a rule that "random events" are a bad game mechanic.  I think random events can mar an otherwise strategic game, sometimes, but in this case, mitigating the effects of these events with clever building (and a few choices in a push-your-luck capacity) is the entire game, and I think that's perfectly fine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Shad

A játék egy galaktikus csillagok közötti utazásra invitálja játékosait. A szabályzat elolvasása után rögtön egyértelművé válik, hogy itt bizony egy olyan játékkal állunk szemben, amit egyáltalán nem szabad semmilyen szinten komolyan venni. Alapvetően a társasjáték rendszere két részre osztható. Az első részben magunknak kell megépíteni az űrhajónkat kis különálló csempékből, melyeknek mind külön tulajdonságai és funkciói vannak. Ennél a résznél ki kell emelni, hogy nem körökre osztott, hanem minden játékos egyszerre építkezik egy közös kupacból aminek legtöbbször káosz és kapkodás lesz a vége, hiszen mindenki a legrövidebb idő alatt szeretné a legjobban megépíteni az űrhajóját. Ezután az általunk megépített űrhajóval kell különböző küldetéseket megoldanunk az utazásunk során. Nyerő stratégia nincs, tökéletes hajót gyakorlatilag lehetetlen építeni, sok esetben már az is sikerként könyvelhető el, ha a játék végére egybe marad a hajónk és nem esik egy kalóztámadás vagy egy meteoreső áldozatává...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Yeah, this one is just pure fun. A bit stressful building your ship, but it's a wild ride. Make the best puzzle you can in about the same time as your fellow space adventurers, then test how it holds up to the rigours of a space journey.

Less fun if the players aren't pushing the pace. Errors and poor ship design = more fun.

Needs the right crowd to enjoy it. This one has fallen flat with people who already have enough stress in their daily lives and are looking for something fun. Which is interesting because the game is only fun if you're not taking it too seriously and are looking for fun.

We like to trash talk other players and their engineering skills as we make silent noises while their ship pieces fly off. In space no one can hear you scream, but you are allowed to scream if an epidemic hits you twice during the same flight.

Rule reminder: If a card effect says you have to give up goods and you don't have enough then you lose batteries instead.

RATING: 10
It's everything I want in a game. Ship building requires a great deal of skill, and since there is never enough time to build the perfect ship, you will spend the whole building phase panicking and flailing about, and your ship will ultimately look pretty terrible. Which is hilarious.

Then the flight will begin, and either you will watch your ship be blown to bits, which is even more hilarious, or you will beat the odds and end up turning a profit, at which point you can feel proud of yourself.

Galaxy Trucker is immensely fun whether you win or lose, and that makes it the perfect board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I really thought I'd like Galaxy Trucker before I played it. I thought building a ship under time pressure would be fun, and seeing it torn apart ([i]or managing to survive[/i]) through asteroid bombardment and pirate battles would be a blast ([i]bad pun intended[/i]). But, it just didn't do anything for me. I found both portions of the game very dry and uninteresting. I didn't have any sense of attachment to my ship so I didn't care too much about how well it fared in its journey. I've also found that, in general, I appear to dislike games where you build something up only to have others ([i]or the game[/i]) tear it down. I actually disliked the experience enough to do something I almost never do - I stopped playing after the first round. I still feel bad about that but, fortunately, a player leaving really doesn't have an impact on the other people playing the game, or I would have kept playing regardless of how little I enjoyed it. I think I'll be unlikely to try it again.

RATING: 10
This game is ridiculously awesome. It has two problems:

- It's less fun if players have different skill levels. Although the game has a silly, somewhat random feel, it rewards skill overwhelmingly.

- If you get too good at it, your ship often doesn't suffer much damage at all.

Both these are helped quite a bit by the Big Expansion, which lets you increase the difficulty and allows handicaps.

The game is not meant to be taken seriously though and it is amusing to see how the best constructed ships can be torn apart by unfortunate card draws.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
Galaxy Trucker -- Played three- and four-player.  The components are just so [i][b]fun[/b][/i]!  The batteries are like dilithium tic tacs.  And the other components foster a whimsical feel, without ignoring practical concerns.  For example, the crew tokens are downright cute; and they're small enough to fit on their compartments, and squat enough that they're not likely to fall over.

I found that I really enjoyed this game, but I was also concerned that the play is much more involving for those in the lead.  There's a silly, haphazard, [i]light[/i] quality to Galaxy Trucker that precludes any real satisfaction in winning, but that's not why one plays this game.  It's not about winning -- it's about [i]surviving[/i]!  And for me, it's the crazy components, the Sanford and Son spaceships, that draws me to play.

Gaining the lead is arguably too powerful, and since no ship can have all the components in just the right places, building a slapdash ship quickly to take the leader position may be as valid a strategy as constructing a strong, fast, cargo-hold-heavy, well-crewed, well-shielded ship.  Of course, not [i]too[/i] slapdash.  But you may want to prognosticate (look at the cards) to determine which ship components to focus on and, if you're in a hurry to finish your ship first, let some other components go.

I won a game by abandoning ship* before the really nasty stuff hit, so the win wasn't very satisfying.  But I stayed involved as banker/dice-roller/announcer of doom.  

So why is my rating lukewarm?  There are some games I'll play almost any time.  This game I enjoy quite a bit, but only when I'm in the mood for something haphazard.

*Okay, I didn't exactly abandon ship.  I used almost all my crew to get significant coin, thereby taking the risk that another card might demand more crew than I had.  I had seen lots of demand for crew during the construction phase (thanks to Corporation Incorporated's prognostics division), so I knew there was a very high likelihood I'd lose my crew.  I just decided to profit from them before losing them.  (Apparently I'm an evil, evil Corporation Inc. employee!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Looks like something of Tales of Arabian Night vibe, minus the stories, meaning: no true decisions, relaxed laid back ride with no interactions apart from laughing at each other. Each person plays on their own, first against time to build a ship, then against the random event deck. In short: looks like fun meaningless nonconfrontational activity to pass some quality time with your friends.

EDIT: Scares new players! Oh well. Best with laid back attitude. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played the android version to see if I would enjoy the physical version. The android version is done very well and I highly recommend it to anyone interested in this game. That said, I did not care much for the game itself.  The game feels like someone tried combining two smaller games to make a new game. There is a building game followed by a card drawing game.  Both phases are moderately entertaining but I feel it would have been a lot more fun if the two phases could have somehow been integrated more. For example, instead of simply building a ship for the anticipated card drawing stage, I would rather have to draw cards and then be given a building option based on the card that was turned up. That would have added more strategy and tactics to the process. As it is now, you build a ship based on what you think might happen, then just draw cards to see how it performs. So the first phase is a lot of guessing what you might need for the second phase, and then the second phase is mainly sit back to see if you did a good job.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
cada jugador tiene que contruir su propia nave, cogiendo las piezas del centro de la mesa (están boca abajo).
Una vez que se termine el tiempo, se mandan al espacio, y vann pasando cosas, como lluvias de meteoritos, ataques de piratas estelares, planetas donde se pueden cargar mercancias para conseguir puntos de victoria, ect...
El juego tiene 2 partes muy diferenciadas:
La primera, en la que tienes que montar la nave, muy estrasante, por que vés que el tiempo corre, y que los demás jugadores también.
Y una segunda, donde solo tienes que mirar como tú nave y la de los demás, van pasando por un montón de calamidades.
Le veo poca rejugabilidad, y hay jugadores que se les dá demasiado bien (puede pasar con juegos como el Ubongo).

I adore real-time puzzle games. If I were rating games based on sheer fun factor, this would be close to the very top, if not #1. I love the stress of trying to build that perfect ship, but it never seems to turn out as you want. And then the reveal of the cards as you hope your ship can remain intact is just gravy. Absolutely always have a blast playing this one. Even when I do poorly and my ship falls apart completely, it's still hilarious.

RATING: 8.5
Fun games that meshes the crazy tile-building frenzy of Factory Fun with a Starfarers of Catan exploration card system. Players tool up ships (adding crew, power, specialists, gun, shields etc) and try to survive various card-driven encounters. Ships get bigger and the player who gets most $$$ from shipping, trading, defeating pirates etc wins!

The game clips along nicely and it's great fun to see ships fall apart.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I am really enjoying this game! Each play is divided into two rather distinct phases. In the first, you and your opponents try to build your space ships from the common pool of components before the time runs out. You are competing here not only on the basis of time, but also for choice components, such as shields and large batteries, which are not plentiful. This part of the game is very reminiscent of Factory Fun (which I also like), and I think it's just a blast. Often, the timer runs out and one or more players haven't really finished their ships, so they just have to run with what they have so far.

The second phase of the game involves everyone's ships trying to make it through a gauntlet of obstacles and encounters to reach a destination. This part of the game can be rather hysterical, as heavy cannon fire can shear off whole wings of ships. Invariably, especially in 4 player games, someone will get blasted to bits or only coast in to the finish on inertia (having had all their engines blasted off), or lose their last crew members to slavers.

There is a fair amount of "strategy" in Galaxy Trucker, both in how you construct your ship, and in where you try to position yourself on the journey (ships in the lead position have more opportunities, but also face more dangers). But really, this game is about having fun with your friends. Galaxy Trucker is well worth the cost. We obtained a copy of Pandemic (a super game) at the same time Galaxy Trucker arrived in our house, and when it is just the two of us, my wife has been choosing Galaxy Trucker.

The components are generally good quality, and their variety and abundance  explains the price tag. A few of the ship pieces tore a little on being punched out of their frame, which is irritating. I was careful too. Oh well. The box is also not a very good one. I bought the game brand new, and the sides of the box are already bowing. These are quibbles, though, and shouldn't keep you from acquiring this outstanding game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
This is a polarizing game. Strictly, for those that want to see what happens, and not for those that want to react and change their future.

Cobble a ship together.

Sit back and see what happens to it.

There is a minor amount of pushing your luck. Most of the game is to see if your ship can take a beating better than other players.

Random and frustrating.  Little control.  Poor get poorer. Not much "game" to speak of. Worst of all because there is so little to actually do after building the ship, it's rather boring.

The more I think about it the more I dislike Galaxy Trucker. It's weird, because I am a fan of experience games and will give them all the slack that they need, but it's just too random (with both tiles, cards and rolls), little interaction or real decisions within the game itself and is topped of with just about zero narrative. Ugh.

RATING: 5

If you're going to be very upset when half of your carefully-crafted ship goes floating off into space (and into the debit column of your balance sheet), then it's probably best not to play at all.

RATING: 4
"Galaxy Trucker" is highly random, which I usually don't enjoy, but my dislike of it is born from something else. I'll call it the "3/5/7/ gameplay. 

First round attempt to prepare your ship with 3 of each system, as desired. Enemies will require 3 weapons, so make sure you have 3 weapons. 

In the next round enemies will require 5, and in the final round 7.

Once you discover that all system types follow this general guideline it spoils the the ship building aspect and makes each game feel relatively the same.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Half game, half random mayhem. The ship-building part is kind of fun despite the fact that it's a puzzle -- mostly because it's a relatively easy puzzle. The time pressure also makes it kind of fun. Then you just sit back and watch the random destruction that happens when you flip through the encounter cards.

The components are all pretty good, except for:
- the box insert has crappy cardboard dividers: ours were warped when we broke the shrink! There aren't even enough compartments to be able to give each type of bit (and each denomination of money) its own space
- the cards are pretty bad: they seem like just coated card stock, without a nice linen finish. Also, in the BRAND NEW game, color is coming off the edges of the cards already!

--- Summary ---
The first half (of each round) everyone races to build a spaceship made of various pieces (cabins for crew, guns, cargo holds, engines, shields, and batteries to power certain pieces). Unlike most puzzles, where you may have hundreds of similar-shaped pieces to look through to find the one piece you need, here you can put each piece in several different places. Your placements are only limited by simple connection and placement rules -- i.e., single- and double- connectors may only connect with like connectors or universal connectors; can't have a piece directly behind the engine or in front of a gun, etc. The ship needs to be as solid as possible (no free connectors sticking out) and built to withstand the random series of events in the 2nd half. These include pirates (fight with your cannons), meteor showers, planets to stop at and pick up goods, etc, many events costing you time. It's a race to the end, with faster players earning more money. But you also then sell the goods you've managed to collect. Most money after 3 rounds wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This has been on my radar for some time. Got my first trial game in this evening.  Had a blast...literally.  My first ship was annihilated, destroyed, obliterated on the second card draw of the game by!  Had me laughing out loud, which is what I was hoping this game would do.  A genuinely funny game by the look of it.  My initial rating is 8.  Could go up or down but after one play...I like it.

Update: played a couple of times now.  For some reason the last time I played it I didn't enjoy it at all, and I have no idea why.  7.

RATING: 6
Rating after 1 play, so grain of salt territory here.  It felt a little bit too long for what it was, and the fast-paced frantic part of the game was balanced out by the bits that seemed to drag a little too long.

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Boy, am I glad I sprung for the Anniversary Edition of this game.  Not only because it seems to have sold out and gone out of print quickly making my copy a little more valuable (despite the fact I can't imagine myself parting with it) but because I absolutely love this game and am glad to get everything printed for it in one go.

The game is simple and easy to teach people, at least if you start from the base game and introduce the expansions slowly.  You grab tiles and put them on your space ship to make the most well-balanced ship you can.  The rules for where you can put pieces and how they have to connect are the hardest to explain and for new players to grasp but once they've got that down everything else should be easy to learn, especially through experience.

The next step is simply putting your ship through the ringer.  This is where the most learning comes in, you start to discover how much cannon power you really need (hint: it's more than you thought), how many batteries you really need (hint: it's less than you thought), how many crew members, engines, etc. and what the array of possible obstacles is.  You can't really throw this at everyone during the learning stage if they aren't willing to look up the rules themselves, so trial by fire is really the best way to play.  We had one player who after the first two races HATED the game and just wanted it to be over but by the end of the last race was actually asking to play it again because he had learned the ropes a little bit more and had had fun despite still getting mutilated in the final race.

That's the greatness of the game to me, too.  The fun is in putting together your ship and I love it whether I win that leg of the race victoriously or get completely demolished.  It's almost more fun to get destroyed and watch your ship break apart in the vastness of open space.

This is one I can see myself pushing on people for quite a long time, it is such an enjoyable experience (for me at least) win or horribly, horribly lose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A unique twist to board games - a real time game! The game is surprisingly fun in my opinion as you try to build the best ship possible. I find it even more fun if you just simply watch other players build their ships frantically and get destroyed during the event phase.

A lot of the fun comes from surviving through the events - you will actually find more enjoyment when not one - but everyone is being destroyed by meteors or raided by attackers.

The game does have it limitations as the uniqueness of the game quickly dies off - you will find that you will be using the same pieces over and over until they become stale. Also, the events while at first may seem numerous - they are actually very little unique events. You will always be pretty much doing the same events - landing on planets, defending from raiders and avoiding meteors.

Most of my points come from how unique the game is - while it does quickly lose its shine (like most other games), it can remain a fun game if you and your group have an epic time during the event phase.

RATING: 9
My new favourite game. How could anyone not like Galaxy Trucker??

Well, I know how someone could not like it... there's little strategy other than "try to get the best ship you can", and once the game starts it's really just reacting to all the horrible stuff that gets thrown your way.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Making the ships is awesome.  Flying the ships could be better.  

Its an interesting game, because it could have been one of the best games ever, but its killed by the fact that you don't make a lot of decisions when you fly the ships.  SO you sit there and watch your ships be blown apart, which is fun.  But it is all too passive.  You should be able to react more when flying, so that the same panicky feeling that you get while building is maintained.  

Its also too long if you play by the full rules and I would recommend picking a ship and making one flight.  Then if you feel it, start a new game and pick a different set of options.  Fling three ships in a row and totaling is suboptimal fun.

I went through a period where this problem turned me off, but I've recently come back to the game, and it is pretty good.  You can get through the flight quickly once you get used to it.  The expansions improve the game.

Worth owning.

RATING: 9
This is one game we play where it really doesn't matter who wins--it's all about the experience. Building spaceships and getting them blown up, what could be more fun than that?

When I saw the length of the rulebook, I was afraid it was going to be too much for my 6yo and 8yo to play, but to my surprise, my 8yo was so interested in the game that she sat down and read through the whole rulebook before I did and taught us how to play! RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I've discovered the secret recipe for this game: take Roborally, add a dollop of Ubongo, mix in a lump of Speed Scrabble, sprinkle on a pinch of Alhambra, and bake on high for about an hour.  Delicious!!  Galaxy Trucker is what I like to call an "Experience Game", which is perfect because I am what I like to call an "Experience Gamer" - that is, I take pleasure in the joy of playing, not just in the mental exercise of working through strategies.  This is certainly not a heavily strategic game, and you are certainly at the mercy of a lot of randomness.  (Really, it's more of a puzzle game than anything.)  But that's okay, because it's fun!  And although there are a lot of little bits of information to learn from the outset, it's quite a simple game when you know how all the parts form to create the whole.  The game itself has some cool, unique-looking bits, although I think they could have done even more with those aliens and the plastic ship markers.  Over all, I'd have to say that playing Galaxy Trucker is an enjoyable experience, though perhaps a little too much effort to set up for what the game play provides.  Game design: 3.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 3/5  Total: 6.5/10

RATING: N/A
Szalona gra ale dostarcza zabawy na kilka rozgrywek. Zbędny zakup.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[Czech Games 07 Edition] {Space; real-time, dice-rolling, utility cards, modular board; optimal 4p} Galaxy Trucker is an interesting family game.  It needs some time to teach the rules - a player aid or cheat sheet to illustrate the function of each component and each kind of event adventure card is preferred.  The game time is a little bit long (may last over an hour) but it is still acceptable.

The first part of a round is particularly fun, in which players rush to build a good spaceship for the adventure.  The second part is less interesting.  There are tactical decisions for the both parts - players have to smartly build a ship and choose what to do for each adventure card. The second part of the game can also be fun if players can imagine they are adventuring in a galaxy.  

For me the biggest problem of this game is that there are almost no linkages between the 3 rounds.  Therefore, there is no long-term planning.  Some players say that the second part is a little bit scripted after everyone has built their spaceships but I haven't experienced similar problems so far.

The components are top class. The plastic figures are very cute and colorful. The illustration is funny. Very good production value.

I am very happy that I own this game. It is really a good family game for casual play.

[Expansion cards] The expansion cards are nasty! It makes the game more fun when all players are familiar with the basic game.  I am looking forward to trying them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
That's a nice ship you have there :) it would be a shame if the game surgically removed the single piece in the middle keeping it together.

Welcome to Galaxy Trucker, where spacemen get sucked into the cold void, smugglers steal your cargo and pirates blow up what's left while you desperately try to keep as much of your ship intact while racing for the finish. Great fun, usually plays in under an hour, easy to explain and near impossible to master; just make sure that - if your friends are as competitive as mine - everybody knows what they're getting into; I can see how some people can feel disheartened when the game just kind of decides your ship's time is up.

The point of the game is to laugh at your friends as their shiny new spaceship gets blown wide open, their cargo sucked into space, their crew abducted and their engines knocked out and it succeeds admirably. It's the least competitive game ever designed and because of that it works just SO WELL. It's silly, it's cute and it's just a joy to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really, really want to love this game. It just seems like so much fun. Maybe I havent played it with the right people, but I feel like I never will. 

I love the theme, the mechanics, and the idea of the whole thing. It just bombed in my group. I need to find a solo variant because I want to play it more, hell, I need to play it more (I paid good money for it!).

With the right group, this would be a solid 9 or 10. With my group, it wasnt fun and I would give it a 6, or even a 5. But I (and I seem to be the only one I know who does) just think its awesome! So it gets a 7 due to its heavy reliance on being played with the right people at the right time.

Traded.

RATING: 8
I'm sure the fast moving puzzle style ship building followed by highly random disasters will be unappealing to many.  I think its great!  Building the ship is a lot of fun; its a planning and spatial challenge to get all your pieces in, and involves tricky decisions about what you should focus on and what to skip.  The journey is fraught with frustration - but each flip of the card is filled with suspense!  My record getting clobbered so far?  A ship with nothing left but one cargo hold!  Plays ok with 2 players, much more interesting with 4.
Problem after repeat plays; once you've got the hang of it, its too easy to build highly effective ships, and offers very little opportunity to pull ahead - a player who starts with the worse ship will just do worse the whole trip.  However, 'rough road ahead' and custom variants make it exciting again!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Highly original space transportation game. It takes place over three rounds each divided into two very different phases. The first is a frantic effort to build your space ship that entails blindly picking component tiles and trying to make them fit which is all done against the clock. The second phase is where you attempt to fly your ship and watch it fall apart as you encounter various hazards whilst trying to collect and deliver goods for victory credits. Like a lot of designer Vlaada Chvátil's games it doesn't feel like any other game you'll ever play and doesn't take itself too seriously either. Others have said that they much prefer the building phase to the transportation phase but the former only makes sense when combined with the latter. The game does feel a bit too random at times, especially during the build phase when you cannot obtain the components you desperately need for your ship whilst your opponents seem to miraculously keep turning over the ones they require (which are often the ones you want too), but it goes against the nature of the game to become too frustrated with it, it's got far too much charm to allow that to happen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Played a friends copy at last gaming night. After an introduction round where we got used to the 'real-time puzzling' (and knowing what you need on your space-ship) we started for real.

Went smooth and straight for the first two rounds, getting tied with my more experienced friend for the win going into third round.

Made one construction copy so a third of my ship never left the hangar and from there on it all went downhill and managed to finish dead last. Never had so much fun losing a game. Laughed until I had tears in my eyes upon the total destruction of my proud 'vessel' that got hammered on, beaten, shot at and pounded until there was only one alien with life support and some pipes left (forcing me to give up and start waiting on Sigorny Weaver).

Brilliant concept, makes me long to have my own copy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Delightful game. Once the rules are squared away, it plays quickly and gets everyone invested. From reviews I was expected the actual "trucking" portion to be a little underwhelming, but I found that my friends were glued to our boards as we watched our creations get rattled with meteorites and cannons and diseases and so forth.

It's a quite elegantly designed game with an absolutely fantastic rulebook loaded with jokes and farcical in-world rationalizations for various rules and gameplay suggestions.

I wish it could take five players, just because that's the sweet-spot number for people wanting to play a given game in my particular gaming group, but there's always the expansion.

RATING: 5
An experiential game, not unlike Arkham Horror, but far better designed. The timed tile laying extremely disadvantages those not spatially oriented. As a spatial puzzle, Factory Fun is far superior. The complete reset of ships between rounds removes any RPG-like character building. IF you have the desire and imagination to imagine yourself a space trucker (and somehow with that imagination, need a game as an aid to your imagination) you may want to replay this game; otherwise, not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An interestingly chaotic game about flying monkeys through space in ships made of mismatched patchwork plastic plumbing.  How can you not love that theme.  The game itself is basically 2 separate light filler games that blend seamlessly together.  The first half involves a mad scramble for Carcassonne style tiles. As spaceship construction is done in real-time, the pressure and the necessity to build a functional ship on a timer against other players will either delight or mortify players.  It's a lot of fun, but as long as you aren't the sort to have to spend a long time thinking about tile placements and can think on your feet. It's overall an interesting time sensitive puzzle game that involves making high risk choices and split second decisions. 

Then the game begins.  A large part of the fun is flying your monkey driven junk pile through space and praying to your space primate gods that the duct tape holds.  This is an event driven race game for the most part, rife with interstellar peril.  Depending on your attachment to all that hard work you put into the frantic first half, the last section of the game will either endear you to this title or cause you to absolutely hate it.  All those titles you fought for and struggled to strategically placed are about to be hurtled through the galaxy with a high chance they will be blown to smithereens. Watching these fates befall your opponents will of course result in considerable laughter and amusement.

At the end of the day, Galaxy Trucker is a frustrating but overall fun game. Theres certainly a high level of skill, which you will pick up the more you play it.  The first play is likely going to be a bad experience for most, but a second or third play will give this one time to shine.  It's certainly a unique game that deserves a few plays to appreciate even if you can't handle a little misfortune and pressure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Fun design. Crazy play. Nice use of time.

RATING: 6.5
Its a timed puzzle game against other players in real time. When you each finish, there is a bit of random chaos that pits each ship against a handful of random events that test each of your ships. Then you repeat twice more on progressively "harder" boards. Its goofy, very random and pretty fun.

** After playing the turn-based version on iOS, I've come to the conclusion that I prefer that method of play and also in letting the CPU handle the events. Not dying to sit down and play real time. The chaos is fun, but also make me less interested in the time to play three races.

RATING: 4
What a crazy game. The building phase is interesting, but not nearly as tense as I thought it would be. Perhaps my opponents were not as adamant about pushing the time limits as they should have been, but I typically felt as though the time limit was a bit of a non-issue. I needed to be quick, but it wasn't dire. All that said, once your ship is built, you put your fate in the hands of a random deck of cards. So be it. As a zany game that is mostly a puzzle about building your ship, Galaxy Trucker is somewhat enjoyable. As anything more, I'll pass. I can't believe there are so many expansions! I see no need for any of them. The base game is already a tad too complicated for what it is.

RATING: 7
This is a fun and slightly frantic game of building a spaceship that will survive the rigors of an upcoming trip.  Generally speaking, I'm not a big fan of the slapjack mechanism (where everyone may be reaching for the same stuff at the same time.  It works pretty well in this game (and in Factory Fun, which has a very similar feel).  You have to balance offense, defense, carrying capacity, energy storage, and other factors in building the ship, not the least of which is whether or not a piece even fits!

RATING: 8
Another fantastic Vlaada game.  I'm a very visual/spatial person and an engineer by trade, so the ship construction may be the most interesting aspect of any board game I've played.  Trying to match the connectors while optimizing ship components while under the clock is pure heaven for me.  I've heard complaints that piloting the ships is a total let down after ship construction, but I enjoy both aspects of the game.  Rating could increase to a coveted 10 after more plays.

Update: My last few games have fallen a bit flat.  I'm too good at it and none of my friends can compete.  If I had the expansion(s) and a regular group to play it, this could be a 10 for me.  But until that happens, I can only give it an 8.

RATING: 9
This game is just plain fun.

However, in order to like you should be able to laugh if your well-built ship is turned into trash. Furthermore it defintely has no catch-up mechanism, quite the contrary, if you are alredy lying the game will kick you again and again ;) Therefore you shouldn't take it too seriousely.

Update
Still a 10, however this game has another problem, if one of the players knows the game well he can win easily since he can build ships with won't he affected by the bad cards and he is usually faster than the other players. However, just use the  print-to play expansion (also included in the big expansion) to give him a handicap. Problem solved.

Another update:
I still have the same opinion about the game, but I'm updating my ratings so that they fit the rating guidelines. Therefore an 8.

Update again:
Raised it to a 9. Great game. I'm eagerly awaiting the announced secon expansion.

RATING: 10

As of today, this is my new number 10.  Between the chaos of ship building, the timer and than the destruction, Galaxy Trucker really is one of my favorite games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
How great is this game? I was a bit nervous by the sound of the component grab but it's a less barbaric (fearing Snap! type gameplay!) than I dreaded. After building your ship, knowing your weaknesses and finally raising your head to envy everyone else's - there's always one who manages a perfectly finished uber-vessel, and then flying the mission to see whose ship really does stand up to the test of space flight.
All of this is great fun and real interaction between players. I've played this twice now and both were great. Now having the expansion I'm sure there's extra life, but I'm keeping thescore at 9 until a few more goes to see if it has longevity...

RATING: 9
Do you watch Futurama? Of course you do. You know how Professor Farnsworth went through several Planet Express crews before he got one that didn't die? That's basically how this game goes. You are professor Farnsworth, and you are trying to build a ship that protects its occupants from the routine dangers of space trucking.

This is one of those games where you have to play a few times to get any good. But it's funny when you do poorly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Quirky, colourful, innovative, and unique (well, spaceship construction is very similar to Space Junk).  There aren't many decisions to be made (mostly risk-management against the clock), but it is great fun to watch a hastily made junker get blown out of the sky (so long as it's not your own).  It's more of a party game specifically designed for strategy gamers than it is a strategy game.  

Maybe it runs a little long for such a chaotic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic game with a real-time element I finally enjoy. I actually enjoy a lot because it doesn't end up in some sort of stressfull frenzy but in a positive stress to build the best space-ship possible. Great, great rulebook! There should be more like this one. I am usually the person to read the rules and teach friends to play and I can say I had a great time going through the book. Fine humour, nice language skills and great structure. There's lots of luck involved but the game moves fast and you don't you just love to see pirates hit the weak spot of your opponents' ship and have meteor fields tear it to shreds. On the other hand you can also have a blast if it happens to your ship. This game promotes good sportsmanship and provides fun with high quality components. The artwork is stunning and never before have I seen cuter spacemen than in Galaxy Trucker. At a playing time of below an hour this almost hits the filler criteria. We got two plays in two hours including rules explanation. If only you wouldn't want to play this all night long. Will become a favorite of mine in no time, this I am sure of! It really is that good.    

--> Few more games in that make me raise my rating even further by a notch. This is a near perfect game for reasons of a thing simply called fun. Tremendous effort, I'd really play this anytime with any crowd. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After first play, I give this a tentative 8.  Could go up or down with repeated plays, as the first game was only with one other player.  I reckon the game needs to be played with 3-4, as with 2 it was a little easy to make a tighter ship with less chaos.  Still, the game resounds with fun, which is really key in a game--the bottom line is that it is a very enjoyable experience.  There is no sure-fire way to win, as disasters can strike from anywhere.  What makes the game work, in spite of its unpredictable cruelty, is that the disasters are dealt with by everyone playing--no one is immune.  More strategy is present here than at first glance, as are the presence of impactful decisions.  Highly recommended--it is one of the most unique and fun games that I have ever played.  However, if you want complete control of the odds, if you like games to be distilled down to stark strategy, then it likely is not for you.  I would urge anyone to at least give it a try though--doubters will likely still fall for the charm and laughter factors.

RATING: 9
Possibly Jackie's favorite game, and one I always like to play.  It's silly, it's chaotic, there's a learning curve (especially once you add the expansions) but there's no denying the laughs and the tension that this game generates.  It's also just a very tight design.  Everything works the way you think it should, and the color-coding on the tiles is subtle but incredibly useful to new players.  
The rulebook is also worth mentioning.  Most Chvatil rules are worth reading carefully.  This one merits being read aloud several times.  It's hilarious.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love everything about Galaxy Trucker.  Okay, I do grumble when Deja Vu comes up when using the Rough Roads expansion cards, but I'm still excited on the inside because it means the round will be longer!  The quick strategizing when building a ship under pressure, the randomization of events, the losing every one of your ship's components except a cabin and praying that you'll survive the last three cards in the deck and that none will be Open Space -  Even when you're being blown to smithereens despite your best efforts and planning, you're still having fun and this is what I love most about Galaxy Trucker.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Tons of fun in this simultaneous-play puzzle race thang.  I like both the building phase and the flight phase, as I enjoy watching what happens to the ships as they are slowly (or sometimes not so slowly) torn apart by the mishaps along the way.  Not everyone in my game group is of the same opinion, so it doesn't get a lot of play there - but my daughter loves it, too, so I do get a chance to play now and then.  As with Dungeon Lords, the rules inject a lot of humor - but don't leave you with a game that's just a gimmick.

There's not too much thinking here, but the race to get the parts you want and finish first, combined with the (often self-) schadenfreude of watching best laid plans go by the wayside keep me coming back for the ride.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Vlaada is the most diversely talented designer alive and it is not even remotely close.  Most designers you play one of their games and you can sense who designed it.  Rosenburg or Wallace or Dorn or Gerts, you just know as the rules are getting explained.  The only reason you know a game is designed by Vlaada is because it seems so insanely unique that you think that drugs have to be in some way involved.

Galaxy Trucker is no exception, I love putting the ships together, if you just put the game away after that I'd still give it an 8, it's just very amusing.

The mission piece if pretty forgettable, but it's a game to experience, if only for it's complete uniqueness.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic. This game is very different than any other game I can think of. At its heart, the game is about building ships from a jumble of parts as efficiently as possible and then testing how well you did by throwing ever possible hazard you can at it. It is definitely at its best when played with others at the same experience level.

RATING: 8
Believe the hype. This is a gripping fun filled experience. Always a smash hit when brought to the table, for new players and old alike. Quite a bit of randomnes, but you won't care much.

After 5 plays I can't really speak for replayability, but will update. Personally, I will probably soon feel the urge to spice it up with some expansions. 

The rule explanation always generates some eye-brow lifting, but as soon as you get going it always prove to be intuitive to most. Wouldnt spring it on complete non-gamers, however.

People with very poor spacial and/or design sense should keep away.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Plenty of games are mean to you. They'll make it tough to get money, they'll make it easy to get your troops killed. They'll throw Rats at you at the worst possible time. But Galaxy Trucker has a special sadism that not only destroys your belongings, but it takes that which you worked on, stressed over, and built with your very hands and crumbles it chunk by chunk by pummeling it with meteors, cannon fire, and the occasional sabotage. The cards have a special way of finding that one open connector and tossing a small meteor in there, destroying the unfortunate component that happened to be holding on three cannons on one side and your sole engine and 12 credits' worth of goods on the other. You learn from your mistakes, and this next time you'll make sure you don't have such vulnerable components like that. Then the Robosmokeys take out your battery component while Explosive Batteries is out, and you lose eight other central components, leaving you with a sorry third of a ship. As good as you can get at the game, there will always be that card specifically designed to make your labor blow into bits right before your eyes.

And you know what? That's awesome.

Galaxy Trucker keeps bringing me back. Whether it's the challenge of building the perfect ship next time, or the joy of seeing tons of explosions, or the intense time pressure of the building phase, this game delivers. And if you're lucky, so do you. For now there's no way I can turn down a game of this. Lots of fast action, lots of just all-around fun. The expansion gets almost necessary for appropriate toughness after several plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I was blown away by how fun this game was the first time I played it.  Building the ship is pure and frantic fun.  It feels like a fast-paced puzzle with a lot of interesting decisions that players need to make quickly.  Seeing how the ships fare against meteors, enemy ships, and combat zones is entertaining and very random.  This isn't a game you can take too seriously, there is strategy involved but at the end of the day, if you get an unfortunate series of cards and dice rolls, your ship could end up in bad shape.  There are ways players can prepare for the hazards though (looking at the cards during building and choosing tiles accordingly), but this takes practice to do quickly.  Because of this, players that have played the game more times will usually build much better ships and do very well because of that.  Overall, I love this game, but it certainly isn't for everyone.

Read my full review here: [url]http://www.partyhatpotato.com/reviews/2017/2/galaxy-trucker-review.html[/url]

RATING: 6
Terrific fun of smashing up a cobbled-together creation you barely had time to think about as you constructed it.

The absurdity of strapping battery packs (with their appropriately whimsical artwork) and shields and connections into a ship, and then trying to fend of pirates and cart space goods from point A to point B makes for a very entertaining concept.

Desperately needs a cooperative 'convoy' mode - perhaps that's in one of the many expansions, though I've not seen it if so.  Unfortunately able to be badly imbalanced by a more skilled builder being able to just out-construct the other players.  With an odd number of players, the proposed team variant can't help - not that it really solves the problem anyway.

Still, zany fun for all kinds of groups.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
The only game I hate worse than this is Fluxx.  I dislike puzzle games but not as much as I loathe real time tabletop games, so this one really never had a chance.  To be fair, I can see why someone who likes the above genres might rate this higher, but not higher than maybe a 7.  Putting together a puzzle like space ship under the pressure of an hour glass timer is only half the battle.  The turn based portion of the game involves flipping cards that include a variety of potentially devastating elements, including meteor swarms, getting blasted by aliens, or ripped off by space pirates.  The mayhem is often fueled by random dice rolls that can make even a well planned and put together ship a pile of junk.

RATING: 6.5
Good:
-Quick game play
-Interesting decisions
-Ridiculousness
-A meta game quickly establishes

Bad:
-People taking it seriously
-Not as strategic as it seems
-Selection moves too quickly for some
-Not for everyone

Overall:
A fun game that can mislead players into thinking it is a highly competitive game.  As a result, you must prepare your group before bringing it out and remember that it is best played in moderation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
01/2009:8
A unique theme and excellent game play. There is a dexterity element to the game as players scramble to build their spaceship by putting together the components of the ship from a general pool of tiles. Hence, a quick eye and good spatial recognition is crucial to building a good craft. I find this mad scramble for tiles quite unique and fun. The second part of the game feels a little like In the Year of the Dragon where more bad things than good things happen to your spaceship. Whomever can weather the space hazards best will win. This game is actually quite fun with two players as well, although with more players, I can imagine the frenetic pace of ship building. I like this game because its a breath of fresh air, both in theme and in mechanic. Kudos Vlaada!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is an expensive, challenging game, and you should have both extensions (the anniversary edition includes them). You have two phases. First, you built a spaceship. All the players grab parts on tiles one by one and place them, and you need to have some of several different kinds of parts and organized in the right way. Takes a lot of thinking, and under time pressure. The first one to finish their ship gets a bonus. Then you test the ships, flying them amidst meteor storms, space pirates, and so forth. This is an intense game, so I have to be alert and in the mood to play. It's a long game, well over an hour, with 3 rounds, but if you wish, you can play the game with just one round or two. Great for exercising lots of cognitive skills
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Some might might say that I am giving Galaxy Trucker a low rating simply bcause it is precisely the sort of spatial relationship game that I find close to impossible. From Alhambra to Vegas Showdown, my brain just doesn't process spatial relationships in the ways these games demand. But, despite my inability to play competitively, I still find many of these spatial games enjoyable: I love Factory Fun and Ubongo! So my complaints against Galaxy Trucker are honestly unrelated to the fact that not one of my spaceships made it to the end of the round (ugggg.) And, actually, I really enjoyed the 'building my ship' phase of the game. If Galaxy Trucker were all about building a SpaceCraft and then either: (a) letting a computer run the event deck against it letting everyone know in seconds how it all turned out or (b) running an event deck that actually had a narrative structure (rather than just random bad things) I'd give it an 8 or maybe even a 9. But I found the resolution phase of the game deeply unsatisfying, even depressingly boring. This second phase, resolving the events against the spaceship the players built, is long and banal, with almost no meaningful decisions made by the players. Many games (notably those called "Ameritrash") are low on decision analysis but high on narrative. And interestingly Galaxy Trucker merges the two types of gaming experience into one game, with the first phase representing analysis and the second representing narrative. But here the narrative isn't very deep or coherent-- rather it is just a bunch of random events one after another. If this phase had the arc of good narrative or the tension of a real story, I think it would be significantly more enjoyable for me. So, as the game stands, I'd eagerly build ships again (fun!) if I can be excused from the tedium of being bombarded with space flotsam. Just wake me up and let me know how it all turned out. (** The bits are beyond great. The game gets an extra half point in my rating just for how gorgeous it is.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Who knew it could be so much fun watching your ship get smashed to bits?  Always a blast every time I play.

RATING: 7
I thought this was fun.  In each of the three rounds of this game there's a 'speed' phase, in which you build a spaceship from a common pile of components, then an event card phase that test the building decisions you take.  There is some tactics and opportunity for risk-taking in the second phase, but the enjoyable part is the construction puzzle.  It's a novelty game I don't pull out often - but I own too many conventional ones for which the same can be said.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Only interested in complete games in Excellent condition.  Thanks!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Absolutely love it! Great, silly fun when play with a good group of people.  Not a game you pick to flex your brain, or even with an aim to win.  It's just light-hearted, fast-paced fun.

I don't think I'll ever bore with building ships, it really taps into my lego-building childhood.  The race against time and your opponents makes it exhilarating.  The second half of the game, where you fly through the event cards. That's where I fall off a bit.  It can be a lot of fun sometimes if you're jockeying for position, there are some tactical decisions you have to make towards conserving resources and position, but it can feel like it drags a bit after the dozenth meteor roll.

After initial plays, the game has lost some of it's lustre.  I'm overjoyed to have it in my collection, but sometimes it falls flat with new players, there's a huge gab between experience level that it's not fun for the old hat playing it against newbies.  I still always crave a more engaging experience for the second half of the game.

RATING: 8
Galaxy Trucker lives only to smite its players, drive them before it, and listen with churlish glee at their sobs of grief and sorrow.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Innovative and fun twist on real-time gaming.  There's enough difficulty in building your ship and unpredictability that you're constantly trying to balance what you need to plan to keep your ship from falling apart versus what you need to make sure that you can store enough goods.  And, of course, don't let yourself finish too slowly...  You won't be able to get enough goods if that happens.  And make sure you are aggressive about pushing the timer, because you can't let the other players have too much time overengineering their ship.  This isn't a deep strategy game, but it's a wild ride that's great for groups looking to unwind.  

Once players get good at this game, the ship-building will become much more cutthroat, as there are some components which are much better than others.  If you're going to play vets vs. newbies, I would suggest some kind of handicapping mechanism, or else the vets will win every time, even more so than in most games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This one is a ten.  It's that good.  Why?

1.  You get to build something.  Few games give me such a real sense of building as this one does.

2.  The thing you built?  It's gotta work.  You get to fly it through space and see how it actually performs.

There's a catch-up mechanism built into this game, as well as the very real possibility of failing totally.  I love it.

Galaxy Trucker gives me a primal sense of accomplishment or the hilarity of watching something I built, probably very poorly, smashed to pieces.  It's got the fun/strategy/interest combo just right and it's also totally unique.

RATING: 8.25
After finishing a few plays of this game, I still feel like the timed shipbuilding plays quite well into the theme of trying to build the best, yet unavoidably imperfect, ship with the materials that you have. And the scoring can be humorous as you watch your ship fall apart. However, the core concept of the game (i.e., decision optimization based on quick spatial reasoning) is far from my strong suit, so I don't think I would necessarily prioritize this game over some of the others in our collection.

RATING: 6
For what it is, an excellent game. I think for people who like this type of game, Galaxy Trucker hits a home run. The event phase can be pretty boring though, just waiting to get through the cards, rolling dice over and over to see if you got hit by an asteroid. Oddly, I felt unengaged during the building phase as well, and on the whole just wanted the game to end. It's possible however that with more experienced players at the table (and without a long rules explanation prior to commencing) the pace would be quick enough that I'd find myself more engaged. Thus the rating could definitely go up from here with repeated plays, which I do hope to get in sometime.

RATING: 7
This game can be crazy fun.  It is very unique.  The game is for people who like to build things, but you also need to enjoy seeing your masterpieces fall apart.

There are some issues though:
- Doesn't have huge replay value.
- Not fun when some players are experienced others are not.
- With experience the game becomes pretty easy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is one of those games that I want to like -- and did like when I first played it, in fact -- but I went one whole year without playing the game, and honestly didn't miss it too much.  I still enjoy the ship-building portion of the game, but I get a little annoyed with the way the journey portion plays out.

I don't like that people who take great care to build an efficient, well-constructed ship are more likely to lose the game.  To wit, if you take a lot of time constructing your ship, then you'll wind up in the last position on the movement board, which means you likely won't get the opportunity to take the rewards from beating the slavers, finding an abandoned ship, etc.  It doesn't seem right that a player should be penalized for being careful.

I think Vlaada took a lot of care to set a balance to this game, but I don't know that it's enough for me to really REALLY enjoy it.  I'll give it a few more plays with the expansion to see if that might help alleviate my concerns, but I'm still not overly eager to play any time soon.

1 play: 3 players
4 plays: 4 players

RATING: 8.5
I love this game.  It's so chaotic and hilarious every time it hits the table in my group.  

Be forewarned, however:  Do not play this with people that can't stand failure.  There is a whole bag of failure in this game for everybody, and they will get upset fairly easily.  Also, disparity in skill level will be apparent in ship-building.  Be diligent about turning the timer over to not give experienced players too much time to complete their ships.

RATING: 6.25
Sell
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've only ever given two games a 10/10 here, and this is one of them. It's just ridiculous fun. The conceit is simple - build a ship in realtime, way faster than you should, then watch it get destroyed by a mix of how poorly you designed it and how poorly you reacted to all of those meteor storms.

It provides an adult version of "building a cool fun thing and knocking it over", which I never really did as a kid, but I'm sure as hell enjoying it now.

There's just enough meaty euro here to appease people I know who are obsessively into that, too. I mean, not a huge amount, but enough. Because the biggest way to earn points is actually some really clever resource management.

I'm never gonna turn down a game of this, no matter the situation, which is what a game needs to be to get a 10. This undoubtedly deserves it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In a galaxy far, far away... they need sewer systems, too. Corporation Incorporated builds them. Everyone knows their drivers -- the brave men and women who fear no danger and would, if the pay was good enough, even fly through Hell.
\13\\13\
Now you can join them. You will gain access to prefabricated spaceship components cleverly made from sewer pipes. Can you build a space ship durable enough to weather storms of meteors? Armed enough to defend against pirates? Big enough to carry a large crew and valuable cargo? Fast enough to get there first?
\13\\13\
Of course you can. Become a Galaxy Trucker. It's loads of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I liked it on initial plays, but the game is a bit too easily solved for my taste. After you figure out what a good ship looks like, it's mainly about who can cobble the same recipe together in the shortest amount of time. Which is... whatever?

The expansion helps to increase the decision space, but ultimately I don't really enjoy the timed mechanic all that much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Galaxy Trucker is a brilliant design, but a fragile one. The game is meant to be played frantically, with the players trying to rush each other's attempts to build a spaceship and force them into an unprepared launch. It is ridiculously fun with the right group of people that are playing it as intended. If the group as a whole is too careful, the game can become a little tedious. Ninety percent of the joy in playing Galaxy Trucker comes from watching other people's spacehips fail, so it's important to note that if things are built too efficiently that simply won't happen. There's not enough "strategic" gameplay to keep things interesting if everyone decides to play deliberately, so don't let them. Play fast, watch everyone blow-up, have a laugh and move on to the next game. If you play Galaxy Trucker with that attitude, it will be one of the highlights of your game night!

RATING: 8
Looking at the mechanics of this game, it semes like something I wouldn't enjoy, but I find it to be a lot of fun. My first play, I found the timer to be very stressful and didn't enjoy my ship being pulverized, but after that I decided to put my perfectionist nature aside for this game, and I found it to be a really enjoyable experience. It almost has a party game atmosphere to it, but with the mechanics of a fun Ameritra-um-Thematic Game. Bonus points for having one of the best rulebooks I've ever read; I literally laughed out loud at several points. Kudos to whoever translated it for preserving the humor.

Edycja Polska
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my current favorite game, even after playing 15+ times in the last few months.

The game is wildly funny, from the manual, to the destruction of the ships.
It is a fully self contained game that is accessible and challenging.

Big fans can also get "The Big Expansion", and actually get to play it, because it can be used only on the expert players, sparing the new players from severe complication.
The idea of an expansion that levels the playing field and adds no complication to the new players at all is just brilliant.  

Just don't expect to get through 3 rounds in 60 min unless everyone is very experienced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 9
Definitely a game for people who enjoy puzzles and spatial relationships and who don't mind a lot of chaos in their games.  I don't want all my games to be like Galaxy Trucker, but this is a nice break and makes for good variety.  I love building the ship even though I know it won't be perfect.  The random events are fine by me - if they were too controlled the game would lose it's fun, and part of the fun is watching your ship get blown apart or just barely make it through.  One round you might get blown to smithereens, but there's always the next round where you might skate by with barely a scratch. Luck, yes, random, yes, fun definitely.  

Control freaks should not play this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAARGGGGGGGGGGHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH

Yes, this is it the lowest region a boardgame can be.
Well in my opinion, you *might* think it's great, and in that case: do enjoy.

Anyway, I truely hope I never have to undergo this again.
First part, grab space parts and chuck them on the board.

*yaay* that felt totally irritating, pointless and the biggest reason to mount blades on your fingers.

Part 2 : auto-pilot...

Yeah, shit going to happen, destroying the thing you've just build. Well unless you are a genius of cardboard space ship building.  

The only good thing here (for me) is how the Game Designer got idea's to re-implement things in Space Alert, which above my expectations, I do like.

RATING: 9
I absolutely love this game. The components and the concept are simply outstanding. However, it hasn't gone well with anyone besides hardcore gamers. The learning curve is quite steep, especially when building ships. If you can get a group to commit (and maybe watch a YouTube video or play the app first), you'll be in for an incredible experience. Both phases of the game--shipbuilding and the flight itself--are thoroughly enjoyable.

RATING: 8
